summary: Paul Merson and Andros Townsend's disagreement resurfaced after Townsend's appearance for Tottenham in a 0-0 draw with Burnley. Merson criticized Townsend's inclusion in the England squad, but Townsend responded by scoring an equalizer for England against Italy, which made Merson admit his mistake. Despite the initial conflict, the tension between them seemed to ease, though Merson continued to make light-hearted jabs at Townsend on social media.

Chelsea have made a formal offer for FC Tokyo's 22-year-old forward Yoshinori Muto, and if the transfer is completed this summer, Muto will join Chelsea's Dutch partner club Vitesse Arnhem on loan next season. Muto, who has played for FC Tokyo since 2013 and earned 11 caps for Japan, has scored 16 goals in 37 appearances for his club. Chelsea's interest in Muto is not linked to their £200 million sponsorship deal with Yokohama Rubber. A potential £4 million transfer fee has been discussed, but Muto has not yet decided whether to join Chelsea. Yokohama Rubber will become Chelsea's official shirt sponsor from the 2015-16 season.

A large-scale study found that babies given antibiotics in their first six months are more likely to be overweight as toddlers. The research, published in Pediatrics, suggests that antibiotics may contribute to the childhood obesity epidemic by affecting gut bacteria, which can influence appetite and nutrient absorption. The study, which involved over 12,000 children, found that boys were particularly prone to weight gain after antibiotic use. While the study did not prove causation, it highlights the need for careful antibiotic use in infancy. The findings add to concerns about the overuse of antibiotics, which also poses risks such as the development of superbugs.

A Buckingham Palace guard slipped and fell on a manhole cover during the Changing of the Guard, an incident captured on camera by tourist David Meadwell. The guard, wearing full regalia, lost his footing, knocked his bearskin, and dropped his rifle before quickly scrambling to his feet. The mishap occurred in front of hundreds of tourists, who witnessed the embarrassing moment. The guard's slip is believed to have been caused by metal protectors on his boots. The Queen's Guard, while ceremonial, are fully operational soldiers. The Ministry of Defence did not comment on the incident.

The passage discusses the remake of the iconic miniseries "Roots," originally aired in 1977 and based on Alex Haley's novel. The new version, set to air in 2016, will be simulcast across A&E, Lifetime, and History networks. It aims to provide a contemporary retelling of Kunta Kinte's story, incorporating more from Haley's book and consulting historians for authenticity. LeVar Burton, who played Kunta Kinte in the original, will co-produce the remake. The project seeks to introduce the story to a new generation, reflecting on historical and contemporary issues of race in America.

A former royal footman, Christopher Lawler, claims that in 1978 he was subjected to an attempted sexual assault by staff members at Clarence House. He described being pinned to a chair and groped by a male staff member on his first day. The incident left him in tears and led him to resign immediately. Lawler later contacted palace officials in 2023 after inquiries began into historical allegations of child sex abuse by a VIP paedophile ring. His complaint was initially ignored but was eventually passed to Scotland Yard. The palace has stated it will cooperate with the police investigation.

An Oregon couple, Jesse and Melissa Meek, announced their pregnancy through a rap video set to the theme song of the 1990s sitcom "The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air." The video, which has been viewed over 1.7 million times on YouTube, features the couple rapping about their journey to parenthood, including their efforts to conceive and the surprise of discovering they were pregnant. The video includes a sonogram of their unborn child and was created to inform loved ones living far away about the pregnancy. The couple mentioned it took five takes to film and expressed that the video's success was unexpected. Melissa previously made a video capturing Jesse's reaction to the pregnancy news, which he learned about through a tag on their dog. This announcement follows a similar trend where another couple used the same theme song for a pregnancy announcement last year.

A dress worn by Vivien Leigh as Scarlett O'Hara in the 1939 film *Gone With the Wind* sold for $137,000 at auction. The jacket and full skirt ensemble was worn in key scenes of the movie and has faded from its original slate blue-gray color to light gray. The dress was part of a collection amassed by James Tumblin, who bought it for $20 in the 1960s. The auction also featured other items from the film, including a straw hat worn by Leigh ($52,500), a suit worn by Clark Gable ($55,000), and a bonnet worn by Leigh and Olivia De Havilland ($30,000). *Gone With the Wind*, based on Margaret Mitchell's 1936 novel, celebrated its 75th anniversary and is known for Hattie McDaniel's historic Academy Award win as the first African-American actor to receive the honor.

A two-year-old boy fell into a cheetah exhibit at the Cleveland Metroparks Zoo after being dangled over the edge by his parents. He was rescued by his parents before firefighters and paramedics arrived. The boy suffered minor injuries and was in stable condition at the hospital. The zoo plans to press child endangerment charges against the family. The cheetahs did not approach the child, and the exhibit was closed following the incident.

A speed camera in Birmingham, West Midlands, which had been pointing at a house and enforcing a 30mph speed limit, has been turned to face the house and is not working for over two years. The camera was part of a group of 300 speed and traffic cameras that were deactivated in March 2013 due to outdated technology. The camera's repositioning is a mystery, but the Birmingham City Council is aware of the issue and plans to visit the site, possibly removing the camera. The council confirmed there are no plans to include this camera in a new pilot program using digital technology. The house owners were not available for comment.

Usain Bolt will compete in the IAAF/BTC World Relays in the Bahamas from May 2 to 3 as part of the Jamaican team. Bolt expressed his excitement about the event, mentioning his fitness and readiness to run. He highlighted Jamaica's successful relay tradition and his commitment to making the country proud. The Jamaican team list will be announced soon, and the event is expected to showcase sprinting excellence.

Neymar and Dani Alves showed their support for Barcelona's basketball team by attending an El Clasico match, where Barcelona narrowly won 85-80 in the Euro League. Real Madrid remained top of the division by points difference. Neymar also played a key role in Brazil's 1-0 victory over Chile, enduring tough challenges. Before the international break, Barcelona had won their El Clasico contest, moving four points clear at the top of La Liga. Neymar's sister Rafaella attended the basketball match with him and Dani Alves. Neymar's team will face Celta Vigo in La Liga as they aim for a treble. Gary Medel was shown a red card for stamping on Neymar during the Brazil vs. Chile match.

Italy is dealing with an increasing number of desperate migrants from Africa and the Middle East attempting to reach Europe. From Friday to Monday, 8,480 migrants were rescued, with 20 boats in distress reported on Monday alone. Save the Children fears 400 migrants could be missing after a ship carrying 550 people reportedly capsized, but the Italian coast guard has not confirmed this incident and found no evidence of such an event. There has been a recent increase in migrant boats crossing the Mediterranean and rescues by the Italian coast guard. According to the International Organization for Migration, over 10,000 migrants arrived in Italy in the first three months of 2015, with many coming from West Africa, Somalia, and Syria, using Libya as a transit country. At least 480 migrants have died crossing the Mediterranean this year due to factors like bad weather and overcrowded vessels.

Arsenal manager Arsene Wenger is pleased that Alexis Sanchez chose to join Arsenal over Liverpool, despite not knowing the exact reason for his decision. Sanchez, who signed for £32 million, has made an immediate impact, scoring 19 goals this season. Wenger acknowledges that Liverpool's interest in Sanchez could have been influenced by their pursuit of Luis Suarez, and he believes Sanchez's quick adaptation to the Premier League highlights his exceptional talent. Wenger also downplays rumors of a potential transfer for Raheem Sterling, praising Brendan Rodgers' management of Liverpool.

Sir Bradley Wiggins, a four-time Olympic champion and 2012 Tour de France winner, will attempt to break cycling's hour record on June 7 at London's Olympic Velodrome. He aims to ride the furthest distance in 60 minutes, with the current record held by Australian Rohan Dennis at 52.491km. Wiggins, who recently concluded his Team Sky career, will be supported by a capacity crowd and the event will be broadcast live on Sky Sports. Tickets for the event, priced at £49, £39, and £29, will be available from April 19. Wiggins is targeting a British record eighth Olympic medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics.

Serena Williams, a twice French Open champion, faced a tough challenge against Sara Errani in the Fed Cup, eventually winning 4-6 7-6(3) 6-3. Despite her victory, Williams admitted she was not fully prepared for the claycourt season, as she struggled to adapt her game from hard courts. The U.S. team was defeated 3-2 in the Fed Cup play-off, leading to their relegation to World Group II. Williams' doubles defeat marked the first loss in her Fed Cup career, prompting the U.S. captain to emphasize the need for improvement. Williams, who has won 19 grand slams, aims to dominate all majors this year, though she has had mixed success at the French Open. The U.S. hopes to regain their elite status by securing two wins next year.

River Plate are interested in signing Radamel Falcao, who previously played for the club and has since struggled on loan at Manchester United. The club's vice president, Matias Patanian, expressed openness to Falcao's return. Falcao, 29, has scored only four Premier League goals this season and it is uncertain if Manchester United will keep him. However, he recently matched Colombia's all-time goalscoring record with 24 goals. Falcao joined River Plate at 15 and scored 34 goals in 90 appearances for the club over four seasons.

Ella Henderson, a 19-year-old X Factor finalist and pop star, has become the official face of the dry shampoo brand Batiste for their 2015 'Ready For It' campaign. This marks her first brand collaboration. The campaign features her with various hairstyles against a blurred city background, highlighting her long flowing hair. The partnership was facilitated by the MILES agency and launched with a TV ad featuring her single "Mirror Man." Henderson expressed excitement about working with the brand, which she regularly uses. Mark Hargreaves, CEO of Crown Talent & Media Group, noted that this campaign represents her first endorsement and highlighted the natural synergy between the artist and the brand.

A billboard featuring Officer Pablo Torres, who shot and killed Aaron Siler in Kenosha, Wisconsin, has sparked outrage among Siler's family and friends, who find it disrespectful. The billboard, funded by the Kenosha Professional Police Association, was meant to thank the community for its support, but family members feel it is inappropriate and offensive. Siler, who was wanted on a felony warrant, was shot during a police pursuit on March 14. The investigation into his death is ongoing, while Torres is on leave. Recently, Torres also shot a suicidal man, Terry Knight, whose case was deemed justified.

Eight Iranian border guards were killed in clashes with militants near the Iran-Pakistan border, with three militants also killed. The militants, associated with the anti-Iranian group Jaish al Adal, crossed from Pakistan into Iran. Iranian officials have asked Pakistan to apprehend any surviving militants. Jaish al Adal, active in Pakistan's Balochistan province, has previously claimed attacks on Iranian territory, including a deadly 2013 incident. Iran criticized Pakistan for not controlling the militants, while Pakistan condemned the attack as terrorism and pledged to investigate and bring perpetrators to justice.

The passage discusses a political discussion in Japan regarding the possibility of extraterrestrial unidentified flying objects (UFOs). Defense Minister Gen Nakatani confirmed that the Air Self Defense Force (ASDF) has never encountered a UFO from outer space, though they have detected other unidentified flying objects. The discussion was prompted by a question from Antonio Inoki, a former wrestler and politician, who claims to have seen a UFO but is unsure about the existence of aliens. The conversation highlights Japan's interest in UFOs and the legal implications of potential extraterrestrial threats, as well as Inoki's diverse background in sports, politics, and cultural diplomacy.

Passenger Jin Pai, 35, was hospitalised with deep cuts on his leg and buttocks after a toilet at Hefei Xinqiao International Airport collapsed while he was standing on its rim. Initially, he claimed he was squatting but later told police he was sitting, possibly to avoid compensation. Authorities deemed the incident an accident and reminded passengers that toilets are for sitting, not standing. Jin received several dozen stitches at the hospital.

A 56-year-old man, Kevin Rebbie, was arrested in Pennsylvania after a 15-year-old girl discovered a hidden camera in her bathroom, which traced back to him. Rebbie is accused of sexually abusing the girl and others over four years, filming them with the camera and uploading the videos to his computer. He faces multiple charges, including aggravated indecent assault and invasion of privacy. The investigation revealed 41 videos, 34 of which showed victims showering. Rebbie's preliminary hearing is scheduled for May 1, and he is held on $500,000 bail. The police chief described the case as particularly horrific.

A Japanese photographer, Yûki Aoyama, has created a series of photographs featuring fathers and daughters, where fathers leap into the air while daughters look directly into the camera with smiles. The series, titled "Daughter and Salary Man," showcases fathers in sharp suits expressing fun and excitement, while daughters wear casual clothing. Some fathers show pained expressions during their jumps, and the photos are taken in front of various Japanese landmarks. The images have gained attention online for their unique and quirky nature.

The passage discusses the dismissal of Paul Downton as England's managing director and the upcoming start of the county championship season. It highlights Kevin Pietersen's potential return to the England team, as he poses for the Surrey team photo before the new campaign. Pietersen appears deep in thought but is otherwise jovial, showing his eagerness to regain his place in the international set-up. His last appearance for England was during the Ashes tour in Australia, which ended in a series defeat. With England aiming to regain the urn this summer, Pietersen is with Surrey, hoping to make a comeback to the Test team. The team photo event took place at the KIA Oval, where Pietersen interacted with photographers and teammates, showing his cheerful side. Surrey is set to begin their campaign against Oxford MCCU.

Ceahlaul Piatra Neamt, a Romanian club facing relegation, sacked coach Ze Maria for the second time in a week. Initially fired after a poor performance, he was reinstated by owner Angelo Massone but was again dismissed after a 2-0 loss to FC Botosani. Ze Maria, a former Brazil defender with 25 caps, will be replaced by Serbian coach Vanya Radinovic.

Radamel Falcao's former Monaco teammate Nabil Dirar believes Falcao regrets his failed loan move to Manchester United, despite not being happy at Monaco. Falcao struggled at United, scoring only four goals this season, and the club is unlikely to make the transfer permanent due to his poor performance. Dirar suggests Falcao would have been better off staying at Monaco, where he had a better atmosphere and participated in the Champions League.

New Zealand police are seeking public assistance to identify a man who robbed a Christchurch dairy wearing a distinctive cartoon mask. The offender, described as very tall and wearing a fluoro orange sweatshirt, stole the till and approximately $1500 in cash on Saturday. The incident occurred at a dairy on Union St, east Christchurch, where the robber demanded cash from the owner's daughter. The robber threw the cash register to the ground and fled. Police have no evidence of weapons and are appealing for information to help identify the suspect.

Kaitlyn Granado, a 24-year-old math teacher at MacArthur High School in Irving, Texas, was arrested again after being accused of having sex with a 15-year-old student in her car on consecutive nights in January. She was previously arrested on March 19 for an inappropriate relationship with another 15-year-old student, during which she admitted to kissing the pupil and allowing him to touch her breasts. Following the second arrest, Granado was released after posting a $50,000 bail. The school district placed her on administrative leave, preventing her from working with students or being on school property. The case involves allegations of multiple inappropriate relationships with underage students.

A video showing a large crocodile swimming through a public marina in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, with a dead pet dog locked in its jaws has been viewed over 500,000 times online. The incident occurred when the dog, belonging to the local bike shop's owner, approached the crocodile out of curiosity. New Zealander Tim Weston witnessed the event and noted the crocodile held the dog for a long time before eventually releasing it. The crocodile is part of a local sanctuary and is a common sight in the area. Despite the alarming nature of the video, crocodiles are a natural part of the ecosystem in Puerto Vallarta, and they are also found on the resort's golf course. Social media reactions to the video have been mixed, with some expressing horror and others expressing dislike for crocodiles.

Steve Bruce is confident Hull City can avoid relegation from the Barclays Premier League despite a 2-0 loss to Southampton. Hull, who have only six wins this season, now have six games left to save their season, including tough matches against top teams. Bruce attributes their struggles to long-term injuries to key players. Southampton's Ronald Koeman faced disciplinary issues after Sadio Mane attempted to take a penalty that was initially assigned to James Ward-Prowse.

A teacher, Ian Guffick, was banned from teaching for two years after altering exam answers for pupils at Mitton Manor Primary School, which led to the annulment of the school's SATs results. Guffick claimed he only made answers more legible, but a panel found his actions breached exam rules. The Department for Education annulled the school's results, and Guffick admitted to the misconduct, expressing regret. The panel deemed his conduct dishonest but not fraudulent, and the ban was considered a proportionate sanction. Guffick has 28 days to appeal the decision.

Anders Lindegaard, the Danish international goalkeeper for Manchester United, has struggled for playing time since joining in 2010, making only 19 league appearances in five seasons and being restricted to cup matches. With David de Gea performing well and Victor Valdes joining the team, Lindegaard is now third-choice at Old Trafford. Despite his limited opportunities on the pitch, he has a happy personal life, married to Swedish model Misse Beqiri, with whom he has a son. They tied the knot in a romantic beach wedding in Mauritius last year and have been dating since 2012. Beqiri, who has Albanian roots, frequently shares modelling photos on her Instagram account, which has over 17,000 followers. Lindegaard recently shared a post on his Instagram page featuring Beqiri, highlighting their relationship and their time together in Cheshire. He has also been linked with a potential move to FC Midtjylland but no agreement was reached.

The passage describes the auction of 13 glowing blue letters from Yankee Stadium, which failed to find a buyer at Sotheby's. The letters, which had been above the stadium since 1976, were expected to sell for $300,000 to $600,000, but the only bid was $260,000 from a Sotheby's employee. The current owner, Reggie Jackson, a Yankees Hall of Famer, purchased them in 2008 for an undisclosed amount and hoped a new generation would own them. Jackson, who attended the auction, joked about buying them on a whim. Additionally, a New York Mets bullpen car from the late 60s was auctioned and sold for $112,500, exceeding its estimated value of $20,000 to $30,000.

Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers addressed Raheem Sterling and Jordon Ibe, reminding them of their professional responsibilities after they were caught using substances and smoking shisha. Although Rodgers spoke to them, he decided not to discipline them and wants to move forward. Rodgers emphasized the importance of professional conduct for elite athletes, not just for their welfare but also due to their responsibilities. He also mentioned that Steven Gerrard, who is back from a suspension, might be recalled for the FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa, but his main focus is on guiding Liverpool to their first FA Cup final under his management. Rodgers acknowledged the team's previous near-misses in the title race and cup competitions, viewing them as part of the journey toward success.

Mesut Ozil, Arsenal's playmaker, returned to London after the international break and posted a picture relaxing with his dog, captioning it "Home Sweet Home." He performed well for Germany in their Euro 2016 qualifier against Georgia, and is now focused on the Premier League match against Liverpool. Ozil, who joined Arsenal for £42.5 million in 2013, missed a recent game against Newcastle due to illness but is expected to start against Liverpool. He has been in good form since returning from injury, providing four assists and scoring three goals since January. Ozil has adapted to English football, stating he fits in "perfectly" and enjoys the frequent matches typical of the Premier League.

Barcelona club president Josep Maria Bartomeu confirmed that there are no plans to replace manager Luis Enrique, expressing satisfaction with his performance. Enrique, who took charge last summer and signed a two-year contract, is currently six games away from winning the La Liga title. Despite rumors of potential replacement, Bartomeu emphasized that Enrique is focused on the team's success and has a contract until 2016. Barcelona remains in a strong position to win three trophies, and Enrique's team defeated Valencia in a match where Luis Suarez and Lionel Messi scored.

Jordan Henderson has signed a new long-term contract with Liverpool, extending his stay at Anfield until the summer of 2020. The deal, valued at around £100,000 per week, follows discussions that began in the current season. Henderson, who has been one of the most improved players under Brendan Rodgers, is set to take over as club captain when Steven Gerrard leaves for LA Galaxy. He is the third major player to commit to a new contract, following Daniel Sturridge and Philippe Coutinho. Talks with Raheem Sterling are expected to resume in the summer, although he has rejected a new deal so far.

Filipe Luis has stated his desire to remain at Chelsea until the end of his contract, despite Atletico Madrid considering re-signing him. He signed a three-year deal with Chelsea in July but has struggled to establish himself as the first-choice left back. Mourinho is pushing the team to maintain focus and perform well in the remaining challenging Premier League games. Luis recently played for Brazil in friendly matches but is now concentrating on Chelsea's title run-in.

Nathan Hughes had his three-match ban overturned after an appeal, following public outcry. Initially suspended for recklessly colliding with George North's head during a match, Hughes was later cleared of foul play, with the incident deemed accidental. North, who was knocked out and required medical attention, has been advised to take a month off due to concussion symptoms. Hughes missed a Champions Cup match and is now free to return to play, though not in the upcoming match-day squad. The appeal panel concluded that no foul play occurred, and Hughes is expected to play again in a future match.

A fiery sunset observed in Seattle was caused by smoke from wildfires in southeastern Siberia. The fires, initially started by farmers burning grass, grew out of control due to strong winds, destroying villages. Smoke from the fires traveled across the Pacific Ocean, affecting parts of Oregon, Washington, and British Columbia. The intense red sunsets occur because smoke particles filter out shorter wavelength colors from sunlight, allowing red and orange hues to dominate. As the smoke dissipates, air quality will improve, and the red sunsets will fade.

Becky Schoenig of St. Louis, Missouri had her brand new 2015 Ford Fusion stolen from her driveway. The car was later returned by police after a tip from Mick Sexton, who had recognized it. The car was returned with new red rims and detailing, as well as orange accents on the steering wheel. Instead of being upset, Schoenig thanked the thieves on Facebook, calling the car "pimped out." She is now cleaning the car due to a strong smell of cigarettes and marijuana and plans to create a smoothie at her restaurant, The Hot Pot, in honor of Sexton, named "The Sexton on Wheels."

Manchester City players, including Sergio Aguero, David Silva, Joe Hart, and Yaya Toure, risk losing £500,000 in bonuses if the team fails to qualify for the Champions League. The club has incentivised contracts to ensure compliance with financial fairplay rules. Currently, Manchester City is in fourth place in the Premier League, four points ahead of Liverpool, with their European hopes still in the balance. If they finish fifth, key players could miss out on significant paydays. The team faces a tough battle to secure a top-four finish and potentially sign high-profile players like Paul Pogba. Manager Manuel Pellegrini has acknowledged the team's poor performance in the last three months and the need for improvement. Meanwhile, Manchester United, led by Louis van Gaal, is four points ahead and confident of adding top-class talent in the next transfer window.

Manchester United's Under 18s team won 1-0 against City in a 'mini-derby' at Altrincham's Moss Lane. Callum Gribbin scored the decisive free-kick, showcasing his skills after a viral moment earlier in the season. The match featured 13 English players, with 10 from Manchester, and was attended by nearly 1,000 spectators. Despite a competitive game, United's victory leaves them two points behind Middlesbrough, while City, suffering from injuries, lost both matches in the play-off series. The match highlighted promising talents on both sides, suggesting they deserve first-team opportunities in the future.

Joe Hart, the England and Manchester City goalkeeper, celebrated his 50th international cap against Italy, where Gianluigi Buffon, the Italian veteran, earned his 147th cap. Hart praised Buffon as a 'legend of the game' and an inspiration, acknowledging the Italian goalkeeper's achievements and expressing his own aspirations to continue representing England. Hart, who is 10 years younger than Buffon, expressed pride in his milestone and a desire to keep playing well for both his club and country.

Chipotle is entering the $70 billion food delivery market by partnering with Postmates to offer delivery in 67 cities, with a 9% service charge. This move comes after the restaurant turned down previous delivery offers. Chipotle has gained attention from presidential candidates, including Marco Rubio and Hillary Clinton, who have been spotted at their locations. Other fast-food chains like Starbucks, Taco Bell, McDonald's, and Burger King are also exploring delivery services.

The parents of Martin Richard, the youngest victim of the Boston Marathon bombings, are urging the U.S. Justice Department to abandon the death penalty for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, arguing that it would prolong their suffering and the trauma of their loss. They support a life sentence without parole and appeals waiver, emphasizing their personal experience of grief and the lasting impact of the tragedy. The sentencing phase for Tsarnaev, who was convicted on all charges related to the 2013 bombings, is set to begin.

This passage describes a custom-built Boeing 747-8 that has been transformed into a luxurious private jet for a billionaire. The plane, which originally could carry 600 passengers, has been modified over three years to serve as a home with multiple bedrooms, lounges, a restaurant, and an onboard kitchen. The total cost is estimated at £400 million, and it can accommodate the owner and dozens of guests. The interior is designed like a luxury hotel, featuring a dining room, conference room, sleeping areas, and a master bedroom with a large bed and seating. The plane is considered one of the most luxurious private jets ever built, offering an experience far beyond typical commercial flights.

SpaceX successfully launched a Falcon 9 rocket carrying the Dragon spacecraft to the International Space Station. However, the first-stage rocket failed to land safely on a floating barge, tipping over after landing. This was the second attempt for the mission, with the first launch scrubbed due to weather. The Dragon will deliver over 4,300 pounds of supplies to the space station and later return with over 3,000 pounds of cargo. This mission marks the sixth SpaceX mission to the International Space Station, and the company aims to reduce space travel costs by reusing rockets.

Priscilla Presley will serve as a witness at the first wedding at the new Elvis Presley's Graceland Wedding Chapel in Las Vegas, which is part of the first permanent Graceland exhibit outside Memphis. The winning couple, selected through a contest with NBC's Today show, will be married on April 23 at the Westgate Hotel, formerly the Las Vegas Hilton, where Elvis performed over 830 shows. The couple will also receive a free wedding reception, hotel suite, airfares, and concert tickets. Priscilla emphasized that the chapel is a serious event, not a joke, and stated that no impersonators will be allowed. Couples must submit a video or photos along with an explanation to be considered for the prize.

In a 2-0 victory over Newcastle United, Liverpool's vice-captain Jordan Henderson believes his team can challenge Manchester City in the Premier League. Both Henderson and goalkeeper Simon Mignolet played their 47th game of the season, tying the record for most appearances in the top five European leagues. After a recent slump in performance and results, Liverpool has regained form and is now four points behind Manchester City. Raheem Sterling scored the opening goal, and Joe Allen scored his first Anfield goal, securing the win. Allen also mentioned a missed penalty opportunity.

Roma ended a four-month home winless streak with a 1-0 victory over Napoli in Serie A, securing crucial points for their Champions League qualification. Miralem Pjanic scored the winning goal in the 25th minute through a swift counter-attack, while goalkeeper Morgan de Sanctis made several crucial saves in the second half. The win moved Roma temporarily four points ahead of Lazio. Napoli's five-match winless streak continued, and security was heightened due to tensions following a fan's death at a previous match. Roma played without injured captain Francesco Totti and forward Gervinho, but Pjanic's performance was vital. Napoli's manager Rafa Benitez showed signs of strain, and there were no major incidents during the match.

Doncaster Rovers had a dull season in League One, remaining in mid-table mediocrity. Their match against Fleetwood Town, which ended in a 0-0 draw, was so uneventful that the club's media team created a 27-second highlight video featuring only 14 seconds of match action, including the kick-off, a goal kick, and the final whistle. The video was presented as a must-see for football fans.

Cats and dogs can interact with humans through touch, but a man named Roland Giroux has a unique relationship with his blood parrot cichlid, a hybrid fish bred in Taiwan in 1986. He interacts with the fish by gently massaging it in the tank, and the fish responds by staying still and even swimming up his arm. Initially, the fish was bullied by two other fish in the tank, so they were removed. Giroux then began feeding the fish by hand and noticed it becoming more sociable. The fish enjoys being stroked and becomes frustrated if not played with daily. The video captures the fish's affectionate behavior, including following Giroux's hand to the surface when he removes it. Giroux regularly interacts with the fish for at least 15 minutes each day.

Ben Stokes is a fiery character in the England cricket team known for his aggressive nature, as seen in his clashes with players like Marlon Samuels and Mitchell Johnson. After a year of ups and downs, Stokes has fought his way back into the team and is expected to contribute runs and wickets. England's coach, Peter Moores, advised him on managing his aggression, ensuring it remains natural but controlled. Stokes is valued for his character in a game that often produces less exciting players. While there is an argument to play the second spinner, Adil Rashid, England wants to give Stokes and Chris Jordan opportunities to grow and reach their full potential.

The passage discusses Wales' Euro 2016 qualifier against Belgium, which has been sold out with a capacity of 33,000 at Cardiff City Stadium. Both teams are tied on 11 points in Group B, but Belgium leads due to a better goal difference. Wales' recent 3-0 win over Israel has boosted their chances of qualifying for the tournament. The Football Association of Wales reported high demand for tickets, leading to the sell-out. There was speculation about playing at the larger Millennium Stadium, but UEFA rules prevented changing the venue within 120 days of the match. The Wales squad prefers Cardiff City Stadium, where they have a more intimate setting and have not played since 2011.

England's Under-17 squad for the UEFA European Championship has been announced by coach John Peacock. The team, which includes young talents from Premier League clubs like Chelsea and Arsenal, is set to compete in Group D alongside Holland, Italy, and the Republic of Ireland. The Young Lions, defending champions, will open their campaign against Italy on May 7, with subsequent matches against Holland and Ireland. Notable players in the squad include Jay Dasilva, Ike Ugbo, Chris Willock, and Stephy Mavididi, with Willock making his first appearance in the squad.

Manchester City are interested in signing 14-year-old Anderlecht talent Evangelos Patoulidis, who is considered one of the best from Anderlecht's youth system. He has also drawn interest from Arsenal and Barcelona. Patoulidis turned down a move to Barcelona's La Masia academy at 12 due to his family's preference for continuing his education. City have spoken with Anderlecht chairman Roger Vanden Stock to discuss a compensation package, with manager Manuel Pellegrini aiming to invest in future talent.

A 33-year-old transgender escort named Vanessa Santillan was found strangled and beaten to death in a £400,000 flat in Fulham, London, at the end of March. She had moved to London from Mexico and worked as an escort in London, Paris, and Miami. A 23-year-old man was arrested in connection with her death but was bailed and is to be questioned again. Police are seeking information from anyone who may have had contact with her in the hours before her death. Detective Chief Inspector Rebecca Reeves is leading the investigation and is appealing for witnesses, particularly those who saw Vanessa in London on Friday or Saturday before her death.

A woman named Dawn, who has experienced seven miscarriages, was devastated to discover that her friend and housemate, Jamie, stole £207 intended for a gravestone for her stillborn son, Daniel James. During an appearance on The Jeremy Kyle Show, Dawn accused Jamie of the theft, and a lie detector test confirmed his guilt. Jamie, who has a history of burglary, admitted to taking the money but blamed his girlfriend, Carol. Dawn expressed her deep emotional pain and sense of betrayal, highlighting the significance of the gravestone as a gesture of love for her child. She was comforted by her partner, also named Jamie, after the show.

ISIS released over 200 Yazidis, primarily women, children, and the ill or elderly, from captivity in northern Iraq. The release was coordinated with Arab tribal leaders, though the exact reason remains unclear. The freed Yazidis were taken to Irbil by the Peshmerga forces. This release is part of a pattern of ISIS freeing Yazidis since their attack on the region last year, which caused significant displacement and suffering. Yazidis, a Kurdish minority with a unique religion, have faced persecution, including mass killings, enslavement, and rape by ISIS. The international community responded with aid and airstrikes, and the Yazidi population in northern Iraq is estimated at around 500,000.

Harry Kane, a standout player for Tottenham and England, is nominated for both the PFA Player and Young Player of the Season awards. A new animation titled "Harry Kane - PFA Player of the Year?" showcases his best goals and celebrations from the season, including a long-range strike against Chelsea, a headed goal against Arsenal, and his debut goal for England. The video, produced by Copa90, was released ahead of the awards ceremony, where Kane competes against Eden Hazard and Alexis Sanchez for the top prize.

Jamie Carragher supports Brendan Rodgers as Liverpool's manager despite a third consecutive season without a trophy and a likely finish outside the top four. Carragher, who recently received a Beacon Award for his community work, believes Rodgers should focus on improving the team for the upcoming season. He acknowledges the challenges faced by the squad and emphasizes the importance of making the right signings. Carragher also highlights his own community efforts through his foundation and expresses hope that his work will help young people in his hometown of Bootle.

A four-year-old boy, James Hayward, had his plastic toy gun confiscated at East Midlands Airport due to security concerns. The toy, which fires sponge darts, was flagged by X-ray machines and led to a pat-down search. His father, Phil Hayward, criticized the security staff as 'over-zealous' and described the situation as 'ludicrous.' The family missed their flight and planned to replace the toy gun upon returning from their holiday. East Midlands Airport apologized and offered to send the toy back, stating that security regulations prohibit items resembling prohibited items, including replica guns.

A lonely man named Rich, who lives in Humpty Doo, Northern Territory, posted an advertisement on Gumtree seeking a girlfriend or wife. The ad outlines his preferences, including a non-smoker and non-drinker who is fit, attractive, and enjoys the outdoors. He offers benefits such as a company car, phone, laptop, gym membership, and financial support. Rich, who describes himself as athletic, tattooed, and independent, also emphasizes his desire for a reliable, honest, and loyal partner who is good with their hands and a great cook. He stated that former partners should not apply and promised to consider all reasonable offers. Attempts to contact Rich were unsuccessful.

The passage discusses Greg Dyke's proposal to increase the minimum number of home-grown players in Premier League squads from eight to 12, and to redefine "home-grown" as training in England for three years before 18. Five former England managers have backed Dyke's plan, warning that resisting the changes could harm England's football prospects. They argue that the current pool of English talent is shrinking, and that young players like Harry Kane, Ross Barkley, and Raheem Sterling need more opportunities to succeed. The managers also note that England's recent performance in Euro 2016 qualifying has been positive, but the lack of opportunities for young English players remains a concern.

Demelza Poldark, played by Eleanor Tomlinson, is now the proud mother of Ross Poldark's child, with the birth occurring within minutes of the next episode. The pregnancy timeline is rushed, jumping from announcement to birth in less than a day, which has been noted by fans as unrealistic. This fast-paced development mirrors a previous instance in the show where a pregnancy progressed rapidly between episodes, prompting fan reactions on social media.

Leicester City, under manager Nigel Pearson, is in a precarious position in the Barclays Premier League, sitting just three points above the relegation zone after a recent win against West Brom. Jamie Vardy's last-minute goal against West Brom improved their slim chances of survival. Despite this, Pearson emphasizes that the team must stay focused on their own performance and not be distracted by the actions of their rivals. He warns against becoming overly optimistic and stresses the importance of maintaining control over their own run-in to secure their Premier League survival.

A North Pacific gray whale named Varvara completed the longest mammal migration ever recorded, traveling nearly 14,000 miles from Russia's Sakhalin Island to Baja, Mexico. This journey surpassed a previous record held by a humpback whale. The migration suggests Varvara may originate from a different population than previously thought, potentially indicating that some western gray whales are actually eastern grays. This finding could impact the understanding of gray whale populations, as western gray whales are considered endangered with only around 150 individuals remaining.

Residents on Hokkaido Island's Shiretoko Peninsula experienced an unexpected geological event when 1,000ft of seabed rose to the surface overnight, creating a new coastline extending 1,000-1,640ft in length and 100ft in width. This phenomenon, attributed to a nearby landslide triggered by melting ice and snow, caused land to drop and pivot underwater terrain upward. Local residents were surprised as there were no tremors or sounds, and the event is not linked to the recent earthquake in Nepal. Authorities do not expect further expansion of the landmass, and marine life remains attached to the newly emerged area.

Gregory van der Wiel has denied reports of him leaving Paris Saint-Germain in the summer, reaffirming his commitment to the club. He expressed his love for PSG, the city, and his teammates, stating everything is perfect for him and there's no reason for him to leave. Van der Wiel is ready to play whenever called upon, despite a recent falling out with manager Laurent Blanc over his omission in a Champions League match. PSG is still linked with signing Dani Alves, which may affect Van der Wiel's future at the club.

Carlos Tevez, a 31-year-old Argentine striker, has been informed by Juventus that he must terminate his contract to return to his former club Boca Juniors. Although his contract with Juventus expires in 2016, Tevez has expressed his desire to leave this summer. Boca Juniors, where Tevez began his career and scored 26 league goals in 76 appearances, is close to finalizing a deal with the player. Juventus, while reluctant to lose their top scorer, has accepted Tevez's wish to leave and is already seeking a replacement. Tevez, who has won a second Serie A title with Juventus, aims to finish his career at Boca Juniors. His international manager, Tata Martino, supports Tevez's decision, emphasizing that his future should be determined by the player himself.

In a thrilling Champions League match, Bayern Munich defeated Porto 6-1, advancing to the semi-finals with goals from Thiago Alcantara, Jerome Boateng, Thomas Muller, Xabi Alonso, and a brace from Robert Lewandowski. The match at the Allianz Arena saw Bayern's manager Pep Guardiola tear a hole in his trousers, which he humorously noted would require new ones for the next game. Guardiola also removed his suit blazer during the match. Porto, who had a 3-1 lead from the first leg, were overwhelmed by Bayern's dominant performance.

A multi-vehicle crash involving ten people, including four children, occurred on the Brisbane Valley Highway near Fernvale. Three vehicles collided, resulting in several injuries. A 40-year-old man and a five-year-old boy were the first patients airlifted to Princess Alexandra Hospital, followed by a 27-year-old woman and a six-year-old girl. Six others, including an infant and two young girls, were taken to Ipswich Hospital with minor injuries or for further assessment. A man sustained hand lacerations, while two females escaped injuries. The highway was closed with diversions in place, and emergency crews rescued a trapped individual using hydraulic cutting gear. The Rescue 500 helicopter assisted in airlifting patients.

The passage discusses the upcoming Premier League match between second-placed Arsenal and top-of-the-table Chelsea, highlighting Mesut Ozil's excitement about his new Apple Watch, which he compared to Michael Knight's gadget from the TV show Knight Rider. Ozil is expected to start for Arsenal, who trail Chelsea by 10 points with six games left. The team has been boosted by the return of Jack Wilshere, who was on the bench in a recent FA Cup semi-final win. Club legend Ray Parlour believes Wilshere has great potential but is concerned about his injury record, comparing him to Abou Diaby, who has faced similar issues.

Referee Mark Clattenburg will officiate the Manchester derby between Manchester United and Manchester City at Old Trafford. Despite having sent off three players from United and City this season, Clattenburg has only shown two red cards in the Premier League this season, both to United players: Tyler Blackcett and Luke Shaw. City captain Vincent Kompany was sent off during Belgium's Euro 2016 qualifier, resulting in his suspension for the upcoming match against Wales. The derby could determine which team finishes second behind Chelsea, with United on a five-game winning streak and City struggling after a poor start to the season. Clattenburg will be assisted by Simon Beck and Jake Collin, with Jonathan Moss as the fourth official.

Bob Katter, an outspoken federal MP of Lebanese descent, accused the Queensland Government of treating embattled MP Billy Gordon as a 'little black puppet on a string,' suggesting the Government assumed Gordon would resign after he was accused of domestic violence and concealed his criminal past. Gordon was forced to resign from the Queensland Labor Party but remains in parliament as an independent, causing political chaos. Katter defended his use of the term 'black puppet,' citing his personal experiences with racism and his background from Cloncurry. His statement sparked criticism on social media, with some questioning the racial implications of his remarks. Katter also referenced other independent MPs as examples of those who lost their independence to the government.

Dayna Dobias, a 19-year-old from Illinois with cerebral palsy, is using her passion for dancing to inspire others and challenge stereotypes about people with disabilities. Despite facing bullying and stares due to her condition, she creates videos that entertain and encourage others to think before judging. Dayna aims to show that people with disabilities are similar to everyone else and deserve to be treated equally. She has produced several dance videos, including one to Taylor Swift's "Shake It Off," and has started motivational speaking at local schools.

Orlando City, an MLS team with a large Latin-American fanbase, has shown interest in signing Javier Hernandez, a Mexican international who is currently on loan at Real Madrid and has faced difficulties there. Hernandez is also sought after by eight European clubs, including Southampton, Stoke, West Ham, Everton, Wolfsburg, AC Milan, Lazio, and Inter Milan. Manchester United is willing to sell Hernandez for around £8 million. Meanwhile, Manchester United has made a revised contract offer to 19-year-old midfielder Andreas Pereira, who is also attracting interest from clubs like Paris St Germain, Juventus, PSV Eindhoven, and Feyenoord.

A gang of at least three individuals poured gasoline on a white Dodge Charger at a gas station in South Los Angeles early on Saturday morning and set it on fire. The driver, who was arguing with the suspects while pumping gas, was not injured, but the car was completely destroyed. The suspects reportedly attempted to carjack the driver, leading to the incident. The Los Angeles County Fire Department is investigating the arson, and surveillance footage is being used in the case. No one was injured during the incident.

A chiropractor in southern Iowa, Charles Manuel, has surrendered his state license after admitting to accepting sex as payment for his services and performing exorcisms on patients. He signed an agreement admitting his misconduct and pledging not to seek reinstatement for at least 10 years. Despite the allegations, Manuel received high patient satisfaction ratings on HealthGrades.com. His practice, listed on a residential address in Lamoni, Iowa, is now associated with questionable practices.

The passage describes a recent incident where a Russian SU-27 Flanker intercepted a U.S. RC-135U reconnaissance plane in international airspace north of Poland. The U.S. called the Russian pilot's actions "unsafe and unprofessional" due to aggressive maneuvers and high speed. Russia claimed the U.S. plane had its transponder off and attempted to identify it. The U.S. denied the transponder claim and plans to file a formal complaint through diplomatic channels. This is not the first time such incidents have occurred, with a similar event in the Sea of Okhotsk a year ago. Both nations frequently encounter each other in various regions.

An FBI agent's sniper rifle was stolen from his car's window at a Salt Lake City hotel parking lot just days before President Obama's visit to Utah. The rifle, secured in a hard case with padlocks and chains, was taken by breaking the rear passenger-side window and using a rope or cable lock to free the case. The thief also stole the agent's gear bag, backpack, and personal items. The theft occurred overnight on March 27, and while some items were found nearby, the rifle remains missing. The hotel lacks surveillance cameras, and the rifle's serial number has been reported to the National Crime Information Computer. The Secret Service was informed of the theft before Obama's visit but did not comment on security changes. The incident occurred near the FBI office, and police are unsure if the car was specifically targeted.

Luigi Costa, 71, is accused of murdering his elderly neighbor Terrence Freebody in July 2012 in Canberra. Forensic psychiatrist Professor Paul Mullen testified that Costa's mental state was compromised by dementia and alcohol abuse, leading to a confused and unstable mindset during the attack. Evidence such as triple 0 calls and a trail of faeces from the crime scene suggested mood fluctuations. The prosecution claims Costa feigned memory issues, but the psychiatrist denied these claims. Costa's mental state is crucial to the case, as the jury could return a not guilty verdict if his unstable mindset at the time of the attack is proven.

Everton manager Roberto Martinez defended Ross Barkley's decision to take a penalty against Burnley, despite Leighton Baines' better record. Barkley's penalty was saved by Burnley's Tom Heaton, but Everton still won 1-0 thanks to Mirallas' goal. Martinez supported Barkley's choice, emphasizing the importance of players taking control in big moments.

Two passengers found dead in their stateroom on the Holland America Line cruise ship ms Ryndam in Puerto Rico are suspected victims of a murder-suicide. The cruise line stated that the cabin was secured and authorities, including the FBI, were notified. The ship, which departed from Tampa, Florida, on March 29, is currently in San Juan, Puerto Rico. Cleaning staff discovered the deceased after knocking on the cabin door. The official determination of the incident is pending.

Patrick Kluivert, former Holland forward and assistant coach, has successfully led Curacao to the second round of 2018 World Cup qualification in CONCACAF. Curacao advanced after a 2-2 draw in the second-leg match against Montserrat, winning 4-3 on aggregate. They won the first-leg 2-1 in Willemstad. Kluivert's team reached extra time in the first-round encounter before winning with a late goal from Charlton Vicento. Curacao will face Cuba in the next round on June 8 and 16. Kluivert, who has a connection to Curacao through his mother, previously played in the 1998 World Cup semi-finals and worked with Louis van Gaal at the 2014 World Cup.

Esteban Cambiasso, a highly decorated player who has won all major European competitions, expressed that helping Leicester City avoid relegation from the Premier League would be as significant to him as winning a trophy. Despite Leicester's struggles, Cambiasso remains optimistic, believing the team still has a chance to stay in the league. He joined Leicester in the summer, having left Inter Milan after a successful ten-year stint, and has become a key player for the club. Cambiasso is happy in England and may extend his contract beyond the current one-year deal.

A 23-year-old woman named Gemma, who has two children under five, is at risk of being banned from seeing her children by her mother Debbie. Gemma's behavior, including drinking, partying, and alleged theft, has led Debbie to take custody of the children. Debbie claims Gemma is unfit to care for them and has been unable to trust her with the children's possessions. Gemma admits to past thefts but denies stealing an iPad. Debbie, who has raised the children alone, is preparing to ban Gemma from her home and from seeing the children.

The passage describes a football match between Chelsea and Manchester United where Eden Hazard scored the opening goal for Chelsea. The goal was set up after a challenge by Chelsea's John Terry on Manchester United's Radamel Falcao, which the Sky Sports pundits believed was a foul. Terry's strong challenge from behind led to a loose ball, which was collected by Cesc Fabregas and eventually resulted in Hazard's goal. The pundits, including Graeme Souness, Thierry Henry, and Jamie Redknapp, agreed that Terry's tackle was a foul, with Souness specifically mentioning the elbow contact. While some sympathy was shown for Falcao's position as a striker, the consensus was that the challenge should have been penalized.

A tour bus belonging to Lady Antebellum's singer Hillary Scott caught fire on a Texas freeway, but everyone on board was safely evacuated. The fire, captured on video by Michael Barnett, occurred after a rear tire blew out. Hillary Scott posted about the incident on Instagram, thanking God for their safety and noting that the Bible was the only item not destroyed in the back lounge. The band's other members were not on the bus, and Lady Antebellum is scheduled to perform at the 50th Academy of Country Music Awards.

Dr Adrian Quarterman from Dundee University is developing space-based lasers to convert sunlight into energy, which can be transmitted to Earth to power homes and provide instant electricity in disaster areas. The system involves satellites equipped with mirrors and semiconductors to harvest solar energy and emit laser beams. Initial trials in Scotland were successful, with plans to test in Portugal. Unlike science fiction portrayals, these lasers are not powerful enough to be used as weapons. They are also different from a separate proposal to use lasers on the International Space Station to remove space debris, which targets small pieces of junk rather than being weaponizable. Dr Quarterman acknowledges concerns about control of the satellite system.

Stephen Munden, a 54-year-old predatory convicted paedophile with a 'fanatical obsession' with young girls, has gone on the run after escaping from a psychiatric unit near Hook, Hampshire. He was last seen leaving the hospital around 6.15pm on Tuesday. Munden, who has learning difficulties and is autistic, was detained under the Mental Health Act following a conviction for sexually touching a three-year-old girl on a bus. He was also found to have possession of indecent images of children. Officers are conducting a manhunt for Munden, who may have shaved off his beard before fleeing, and are urging the public for any information regarding his whereabouts.

V. Stiviano, a former companion of Donald Sterling, has been ordered to repay over $2.6 million in gifts she received from Sterling. This decision came after a lawsuit by Sterling's wife, Rochelle "Shelly" Sterling, who accused Stiviano of exploiting their relationship and using Sterling's money for luxury items and a $1.8 million duplex. Stiviano denied wrongdoing, claiming the gifts were a result of Sterling's own choice. The court's decision was seen as a victory for the Sterling family and set a precedent for recovering ill-gotten gifts. Sterling's downfall began with an audio recording of him making racist remarks to Stiviano, leading to his NBA ban and financial penalties.

Thierry Henry, speaking as a Sky Sports pundit, criticized Arsenal's recent transfer activities and urged the club to sign four key players: a goalkeeper, centre back, defensive midfielder, and a top striker. He argued that without these signings, Arsenal will struggle to win the Barclays Premier League title. Henry specifically questioned Olivier Giroud's ability to lead the team to victory, despite his 14 league goals this season, and compared Arsenal's situation to Chelsea's successful transfer strategy last season. He emphasized the need for competitive players of a similar caliber to those signed by Chelsea, such as Thibaut Courtois, Nemanja Matic, Cesc Fabregas, and Diego Costa.

A young woman who was abused by Maurice Van Ryn, the boss of Bega Cheese, has testified in court about the severe impact of the abuse on her life. Van Ryn has pleaded guilty to 12 sex offences, including persistent sexual abuse of a child. The victim, who cannot be named, expressed fear for her future relationships and confusion about why she was targeted. She did not understand the abuse was wrong or illegal and only came forward after learning Van Ryn had been caught. She has struggled with depression, self-harm, and attempted suicide, and remains fearful of how the abuse will affect her relationships with men.

Serge Gnabry, a 19-year-old Arsenal midfielder, is recovering from a serious knee injury that has kept him out of first-team action since March 2014. He recently played 90 minutes for Arsenal's Under 21 team against Reading, marking his return to competitive football. Gnabry expressed that he is feeling "better and better" and is looking forward to future games, having overcome his injury concerns.

Jacob Phillips, a 23-year-old accountant, fell to his death from a 70ft cliff after running away from a taxi driver in Penarth, South Wales. He had caught a taxi with friends after a night out in Cardiff but lacked enough money to pay the fare. The trio decided to run away from the driver, with Phillips choosing a different direction than his friends. Phillips, who worked for the clothing label Pretty Green, was found the next day on a rocky beach by a dog walker. The inquest concluded his death was accidental, noting he likely became disoriented and unaware of the danger posed by the cliff. The taxi driver stated he would not have pursued Phillips if he had known the location.

Thousands of holidaymakers affected by a summer passport delay crisis did not receive compensation, while passport agency managers received bonuses despite the chaos. The HM Passport Office made a £42 million profit during the period, and only 2,191 compensation claims were approved, totaling £203,066. Keith Vaz, chairman of the Home Affairs Committee, expressed astonishment at the low number of compensations, as many holidaymakers had paid extra for expedited services and missed trips. Ministers refused to offer a blanket refund, citing the creation of a precedent.

This passage describes a 1930s timewarp home in Horfield, Bristol, for sale at a guide price of £200,000 to £250,000. The property, untouched for over 80 years, retains original features such as stained-glass windows, oil-fired central heating, vintage cupboards, and an original kitchen with a mint green and black color scheme. It includes a wood-panelled hallway, a brick open-face fire, and a dated bathroom with original tiles and yellow wallpaper. The house also features original tins of historical food products on a hallway shelf. Although some upgrades like double glazing have been made, auctioneers believe the potential renovation costs may deter developers, and the house could appeal to those with an interest in antiques. The property will be auctioned on April 30 at the County Ground in Bristol.

Colin Kaepernick started as a backup quarterback for the 49ers but became the starter in 2012 after Alex Smith's injury. He led the team to their first Super Bowl appearance since 1994, where they lost to the Baltimore Ravens.
"Soul Food" is a 1997 American comedy-drama film produced by Kenneth "Babyface" Edmonds, Tracey Edmonds, and Robert Teitel, and released by Fox 2000 Pictures.

The passage provides two separate pieces of information. First, it mentions Anne Rice, born in New Orleans, who lived in Texas and later San Francisco. Second, it describes Route 495, a 3.45-mile freeway in Hudson County, New Jersey, connecting the New Jersey Turnpike (I-95) to New York State Route 495 inside the Lincoln Tunnel, providing access to Midtown Manhattan.
Telemundo is an American Spanish-language television network owned by Comcast through its NBCUniversal division, specifically NBCUniversal Telemundo Enterprises.

Damon Albarn, raised in Leytonstone and Colchester, formed the band Blur with Graham Coxon, releasing their debut album Leisure in 1991. Blur achieved worldwide success with their self-titled album in 2001. Albarn's debut solo album, Everyday Robots, released in 2014, featured collaborations with notable artists and included samples from Lord Buckley.
Mogadishu, known locally as Hamar, is the capital and most populous city of Somalia. It is home to many important national institutions.
"Happy in Slavery" is a song by the American industrial rock band Nine Inch Nails, featured on their debut extended play (EP) titled *Broken* from 1992.
Andrew Kevin Walker is an American screenwriter who has been nominated for a BAFTA award. He was born on August 14, 1964.

The passage describes two media adaptations of the Bob Lee Swagger story. The 2007 film follows Swagger, a veteran, who is framed for murder by a secret military unit. The TV series features Ryan Phillippe as Swagger, an exiled marksman drawn back into action to prevent an assassination plot against the president.
"House" is an American medical drama that aired on the Fox network for eight seasons, from November 16, 2004, to May 21, 2012.

In 1971, Charles Manson was convicted of first-degree murder and conspiracy to commit murder for the deaths of seven people, including actress Sharon Tate, all carried out by his group. He also received convictions for the murders of Gary Hinman and Donald "Shorty" Shea. Following his charges, commercial recordings of his songs were released.

Sean Justin Penn is an American actor, filmmaker, and political activist born on August 17, 1960. He began his acting career with a television appearance in 1974 and made his film debut in 1981. Penn gained critical acclaim for roles in films like At Close Range (1986), State of Grace (1990), and Carlito's Way (1993). He received his first Academy Award nomination for Dead Man Walking (1995) and won his first Oscar for Best Actor in 2003 for Mystic River. He also won a second Academy Award in 2008 for Milk.

Sir Donald George "Don" Bradman was an Australian cricketer regarded as the greatest batsman of all time. After retiring, he remained influential in the sport by serving as an administrator, selector, and writer for three decades.

L.A. Reid has held executive positions at several major music record companies, including chairman and CEO of Epic Records, president and CEO of Arista Records, and chairman and CEO of the Island Def Jam Music Group.

Brad Wilk is best known as the drummer for the rock bands Rage Against the Machine (1991-2000; 2007-11) and Audioslave (2001-07). He began his career as a drummer for Greta in 1990 and co-founded Rage Against the Machine with Tom Morello and Zack de la Rocha in August 1991. As of 2016, he is part of the band Prophets of Rage, which includes Commerford, Morello, Chuck D, B-Real, and DJ Lord. Rage Against the Machine is a German heavy metal band formed in 1984 by Peter "Peavy" Wagner.

"The Millers is a multi-camera series that aired on CBS from October 3, 2013, to July 18, 2015, spanning two seasons with 34 episodes. CBS canceled the show on November 14, 2014, four episodes into its second season."

Dorothy Ann Willis Richards (September 1, 1933 – September 13, 2006) was an American politician and the 45th Governor of Texas from 1991 to 1995. A Democrat, she gained national attention as the state treasurer of Texas and delivered the keynote address at the 1988 Democratic National Convention. She was the second female governor of Texas and known for her outspoken feminism and wit. She was defeated for re-election in 1994 by George W. Bush. Ann Richards (October 1, 1935 – April 1, 1982) was an American jazz singer and the wife of pianist Stan Kenton.
Drake Bell released an independently produced EP titled "A Reminder" in 2011.

"Boardwalk" is a 1979 American drama film written by Stephen Verona and Leigh Chapman, directed by Verona. Janet Leigh, an American actress, singer, dancer, and author, was born as Jeanette Helen Morrison on July 6, 1927, and passed away on October 3, 2004. She authored four books between 1984 and 2002, including two novels.

Simón Bolívar was a Venezuelan military and political leader known as "El Libertador." He played a key role in achieving independence for Venezuela, Bolivia, Colombia, Ecuador, Peru, and Panama from Spanish rule. He was born on 24 July 1783 and died on 17 December 1830.

The Bermuda Triangle, also known as the Devil's Triangle, is a loosely-defined area in the western North Atlantic Ocean where many aircraft and ships have reportedly disappeared under mysterious circumstances.

Colin Kaepernick started as a backup quarterback for the 49ers but became the starter in 2012 after Alex Smith's injury. He led the team to their first Super Bowl appearance since 1994, where they lost to the Baltimore Ravens. In his first full season as a starter in 2013, Kaepernick guided the 49ers to the NFC Championship, where they lost to the Seattle Seahawks.
"Marnie is a 1964 American psychological thriller film directed by Alfred Hitchcock."

Advertising is a form of marketing communication that uses nonpersonal messages to promote products, services, or ideas. It differs from personal selling by not targeting specific individuals. Advertising is delivered through both traditional media like newspapers, television, and radio, as well as new media such as websites and text messages.
"Private Lives" is a 1930 comedy of manners written by Noël Coward and a 1931 American Pre-Code comedy film directed by Sidney Franklin.

Maurice Harold Macmillan, 1st Earl of Stockton, was a British Conservative politician and statesman who served as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom from January 10, 1957, to October 19, 1963. He was born on February 10, 1894, and died on December 29, 1986.

Aristotle was an ancient Greek philosopher and scientist born in Stagira, Chalkidice. He joined Plato's Academy in Athens at age 17 or 18 and stayed until around 347 BC. After Plato's death, Aristotle tutored Alexander the Great starting in 343 BC at the request of Philip II of Macedon.

David Mordechai Packouz, born on February 16, 1982, is an American former arms dealer, musician, inventor, and entrepreneur. He invented the guitar pedal drum machine called the BeatBuddy and currently serves as the CEO of the music technology company Singular Sound.

Magic Johnson played point guard for the Lakers for 13 seasons. He won championships in high school and college, was selected first overall in the 1979 NBA draft, and won a championship and NBA Finals MVP in his rookie season. He added four more championships in the 1980s. After retiring and returning in 1996 at age 36, he played 32 games before retiring for good. Johnson is also a businessman, named by Ebony magazine as one of America's most influential black businessmen in 2009, and was a part-owner of the Lakers.

Tenacious D is an American comedy rock duo formed in 1994 in Los Angeles, California, consisting of Jack Black and Kyle Gass. They have released three albums: Tenacious D (2001), The Pick of Destiny (2006), and Rize of the Fenix (2012). The band gained popularity in 1997 through their television series and by supporting major rock acts.

James VI and I was King of Scotland from 1567 and King of England and Ireland from 1603 until his death in 1625. He ruled both kingdoms in personal union, though they remained separate sovereign states. He advocated for a unified parliament for England and Scotland, achieving success in Scotland but facing challenges in England, including the Gunpowder Plot of 1605 and conflicts with the English Parliament.

Big Brother 2017, also known as Big Brother 18, is the eighteenth series of the British reality TV show, hosted by Emma Willis and narrated by Marcus Bentley. Bentley, born on 4 October 1967, is a British actor, broadcaster, and voice-over artist. He has been narrating the UK version of Big Brother since its start in 2000 and is known for his Geordie accent and recognition as one of Britain's most identifiable voices.

The Free State of Saxony is a landlocked federal state of Germany, bordered by Brandenburg, Saxony-Anhalt, Thuringia, Bavaria, Poland, and the Czech Republic. It is the tenth largest and sixth most populous state in Germany, covering 18,413 km² and home to 4 million people. Saxony is a significant region for quality wine in Germany, part of the northernmost wine regions in Europe, and one of only two German wine regions located in former East Germany.
East End Park was a former major league baseball park in Cincinnati's East End neighborhood. "In the End" is a song by the American rock band Linkin Park.
Mel B. Brown started her solo career by releasing the song "I Want You Back" with Missy Elliott on Virgin Records.
Noah Cyrus is the youngest daughter of Billy Ray Cyrus and the younger sister of Miley Cyrus and Trace Cyrus.

"Mohra (Pawn)" is a 1994 Indian action thriller directed by Rajiv Rai, featuring Akshay Kumar, Sunil Shetty, Raveena Tandon, and Naseeruddin Shah. It was released on 1 July 1994 and became the second highest-grossing Indian film of that year. The film received nine Filmfare nominations in 1995. Originally, Divya Bharti was cast as the female lead and had filmed some scenes, but after her death, Raveena Tandon was brought in as a replacement. The movie is also noted for its chartbuster songs.
"Hourglass" is a song by the British electronic duo Disclosure, and it is also the title of singer-songwriter James Taylor's fourteenth studio album.

After the death of King George V in 1936, Mary of Teck became queen mother when her son Edward VIII ascended the throne. However, Edward abdicated later that year to marry Wallis Simpson. Mary supported her second son, Albert, who became King George VI until his death in 1952. Mary herself died the following year, during the reign of her granddaughter Queen Elizabeth II, who had not yet been crowned.
"Poseidon is a film that grossed $181,674,817 worldwide at the box office, despite having a production budget of $160 million."
The NAACP Image Award for Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Drama Series was first given in 1996. Omar Epps and Joe Morton each hold the record for the most wins with three each.

Human trafficking involves the trade of humans, primarily for forced labor, sexual slavery, or commercial sexual exploitation. The International Labour Organization estimates that forced labor, a component of human trafficking, generates $150 billion annually. Of those involved, 68% are exploited for labor, 22% for sexual exploitation, and 10% in state-imposed forced labor.
The passage states that "Rio," a 2011 film, was followed by a sequel titled "Rio 2," which was released on April 11, 2014.

The passage discusses two different historical figures named Francis I. The first, Francis I (Franz Stefan, François Étienne), was Holy Roman Emperor and Grand Duke of Tuscany, though his wife held actual power. The second, Francis I (François Ier), was the first King of France from the Angoulême branch of the House of Valois, reigning from 1515 until his death. He was known for his military involvement against Charles V and formed a controversial Franco-Ottoman alliance with Sultan Suleiman the Magnificent. The Italian War of 1536-1538 was a conflict between Francis I of France and Charles V.

Peking University, abbreviated as PKU, is a major research university in Beijing and a member of the C9 League. Founded in 1898 as the Imperial University of Peking, it replaced the ancient Taixue or Guozijian and initially served as China's highest education administration. It is consistently ranked as the top higher learning institution in mainland China.
The passage describes Lemmy, highlighting his recognizable features such as his friendly mutton chops, his gravelly voice, and his unique bass playing style.
The passage states that global warming poses significant threats to humans, including reduced crop yields affecting food security and the abandonment of populated areas caused by rising sea levels.
" Australia is a 2008 epic historical romantic drama film directed by Baz Luhrmann, starring Nicole Kidman and Hugh Jackman."

Michael Dwayne Vick, born on June 26, 1980, is a former American football quarterback who played 13 seasons in the National Football League, mainly with the Atlanta Falcons and the Philadelphia Eagles.

The passage describes Canadian folklore, which encompasses a variety of oral traditions and cultural practices. It includes songs, legends, jokes, rhymes, proverbs, weather lore, superstitions, and traditional activities like food-making and craft-making.
The First Motion Picture Unit produced over 400 propaganda and training films that were both informative and entertaining. It also created training films and trained combat cameramen.

The passage provides information about two individuals named James Jones. The first, James Jones (author), won the 1952 National Book Award for his novel *From Here to Eternity*, which was adapted into a film and a television series. The second, James Jones (basketball player), had a successful college career, earning honors as a senior, and played professionally in the NBA, winning three championships and achieving notable accolades in three-point shooting.
The passage states that Humphrey Bogart was ranked as the greatest male star of Classic American cinema by the American Film Institute in 1999.

Computer animation is the process of generating animated images. Trollhunters is an American computer-animated fantasy television series created for Netflix by Guillermo del Toro, and it is produced by DreamWorks Animation and Double Dare You.
Shane McMahon resigned from WWE in 2009, with his resignation taking effect on January 1, 2010.

Tom Baker is an English actor best known for playing the fourth Doctor in the science fiction series Doctor Who from 1974 to 1981, a record for the longest tenure by any actor in the role. He is also recognized for narrating the comedy series Little Britain. Beyond acting, Baker has provided narration for commercials, video games, audiobooks, and television series.
Angelsberg is a small town located in the commune of Fischbach in central Luxembourg.

The Hanford Site hosts a commercial nuclear power plant called the Columbia Generating Station, as well as research and development centers like the Pacific Northwest National Laboratory and the LIGO Hanford Observatory, in addition to its cleanup project.

The White House Press Secretary is a senior official who serves as the spokesperson for the U.S. executive branch, representing the President, senior executives, and policies. Appointed by the President and holding the position at their pleasure, the role does not require Senate confirmation. Despite this, the position is prominent due to its role in communicating with the media and informing the public.

Kentucky, known as the "Bluegrass State" due to its fertile soil, has the Bluegrass Region in central Kentucky, home to cities like Louisville and Lexington. The state is recognized for horse racing, bourbon distilleries, coal, the historic site My Old Kentucky Home, automobile manufacturing, tobacco, bluegrass music, college basketball, and Kentucky Fried Chicken.
"Broken Bridges" is a 2006 film featuring Toby Keith, Lindsey Haun, Burt Reynolds, and Kelly Preston. Kelly Preston also appeared in "The Cat in the Hat" and "Old Dogs."
Kesha Rose Sebert, born on March 1, 1987, is an American singer, songwriter, and rapper, formerly stylized as Ke $ ha.
The passage states that on May 5, 2017, two versions of the song "Despacito" were released: an electronic version by Major Lazer and MOSKA, and an urban version by Sky.

Starrcade was an annual professional wrestling event held from 1983 to 2000 by the NWA and later WCW. Initially broadcast via closed-circuit television, it transitioned to pay-per-view starting in 1987, making it the first NWA event to do so. In 2014, the WWE Network included Starrcades from 1983 to 1986, which were originally closed-circuit, alongside later Starrcades in the pay-per-view section, rating them TV-MA due to violent content. Starrcade (1997) was the fifteenth annual Starrcade PPV event.
Veeru Devgan is an Indian stunt and action choreographer and film director in Bollywood.
"Star Trek: Discovery is the first series developed specifically for a streaming service and marks the first Star Trek series since Star Trek: Enterprise ended in 2005."
Terry Crews played as a defensive end and linebacker in the NFL for the Los Angeles Rams, San Diego Chargers, Washington Redskins, and the World League of American Football with Rhein Fire.
