The sites, which include an unused campus owned by Newcastle College, are being considered for a new railway station. The council, in partnership with Merseytravel and West Lancashire Borough Council, plans to provide two direct trains to Liverpool per hour. The chosen location offers good highway access and potential for future expansion. Skelmersdale, designated a new town in 1961, is one of the largest towns in northwest England without its own railway station.
During a search of a warehouse near Ashbourne on Saturday morning, police discovered plants in an elaborate grow house. A man in his late 40s was arrested at the scene.

A 28-year-old woman was found seriously injured on a pavement in Hamelin, Germany, after being dragged by the neck through several streets. She was hospitalized and flown to a specialist clinic. Her 38-year-old ex-partner, from nearby Bad Muender, surrendered to authorities. Both are German citizens of Kurdish origin. The motive for the attack remains unclear, and police have asked for witnesses.

The study, conducted by Cass Business School and universities of Warwick and Wisconsin, analyzed 4,600 workers and found that women are as likely as men to ask for a pay rise, but are less likely to receive one. The research, which focused on full-time and part-time workers separately, found no evidence supporting the "reticent female" theory, which suggests women avoid asking for more money. It also concluded that women are not more reluctant to ask for a raise due to concerns about upsetting their boss or deviating from stereotypes. The study considered factors such as employer size, industry, parental status, and qualifications. The findings suggest there may be discrimination against women in pay raises. The study also noted that younger women are more successful in negotiating pay compared to older women, indicating a potential shift in negotiating behavior.

The passage discusses Oxford City Council's efforts to find a new burial site, which have been unsuccessful due to unsuitable land conditions. Two existing cemeteries, Wolvercote and Botley, are expected to fill by 2018 and 2021, respectively. The council continues to explore options but has run out of suitable land. Future burial options will be limited to reopening family plots, using reserved plots, and interring ashes. The last expansion of burial space in Oxford occurred in 1932.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival (HebCelt) in Stornoway, Isle of Lewis, from 19 to 22 July, will offer an augmented reality app allowing visitors to access online information, videos, and interviews from signs, posters, and performers such as The Waterboys, Imelda May, and others. The app will also enable global interaction with the festival, providing real-time updates, ticket purchases, and a taste of the festival's atmosphere.

A 10-year-old Irish-bred horse named Many Clouds collapsed and died after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day. The British Horseracing Authority confirmed the cause of death was a severe pulmonary haemorrhage. Despite having no significant underlying health issues, Many Clouds had a history of post-race ataxia and overheating, which led to questions about a possible link to his death. However, the report concluded that the haemorrhage was the cause. The incident highlights the rarity of such occurrences and the ongoing efforts to understand and prevent them in sport horses.

A 15-year-old girl was raped by David Ayrton in a Portsmouth garage in 2004. The defendant, now 34 and named Davina, denied the charge. She will be sentenced on 4 March. Judge Ian Pearson remanded her into custody, likely at a male prison, due to concerns about her risk to herself and failing to attend court. Ayrton, who has learning difficulties, attempted suicide last summer. During the trial, Ayrton spoke about her sexuality and stated she had not made any physical changes or taken medication. She changed her name in 2012. The victim, who had only consumed a can and a half of Foster's, clearly recalled the attack. In 2014, Ayrton told a care home worker about the incident. Protocols have been established for her detention at the prison.

The passage describes a loss by the Serbs to Brazilian doubles pair Marcelo Melo and Bruno Soares in Rio. This occurred a day after Novak Djokovic, the world number one, was defeated by Juan Martin del Potro in singles. Djokovic had previously been surprised by Sam Querrey in the third round of Wimbledon. Despite this, he won his 30th Masters title in Toronto before the Olympics.

Over 20 competitors will participate in Saturday's event in Carrbridge, Cairngorms, featuring carvers from Scotland, England, Ireland, continental Europe, Canada, and the US. Participants can only use chainsaws to carve logs into animal and human shapes. Last year's winner, Pete Bowsher, will return to defend his title and retain the Claymore Trophy.

Webb, a 27-year-old Welsh rugby player, is recovering from a serious foot injury sustained during a World Cup warm-up match with Italy in September. He is close to returning to play, aiming to be fit for the Six Nations tournament in February. Webb has renewed his dual contract with Ospreys and the Welsh Rugby Union, choosing to stay with Ospreys, where he made his debut in 2007. Wales' Six Nations campaign begins with a match against Ireland on 7 February.

A border incident occurred near Sumas, Washington, where two men, Jeffrey Laviolette and Nathan Hall, were caught attempting to smuggle 58lb of ecstasy from Canada to San Francisco. Laviolette was arrested immediately after firing at agents, while Hall was later apprehended in British Columbia. A woman, Kali Henifin, and her boyfriend, Ryan Lambert, were also arrested for planning to transport the drugs. The group faces charges of conspiracy, drug possession, and distribution. The area is known for drug and firearm smuggling, and authorities emphasize that smuggling prosecutions are a significant part of their work.

The NSPCC's Childline service reported counseling over 4,500 children in the past year, a significant increase from 2,400 in 2011-12. The charity estimates that the actual number of children suffering online abuse is much higher. Children as young as seven have shared experiences of being tormented, abused, and scared to attend school. Online trolls are said to cause misery and humiliation for thousands of children. Dame Esther Rantzen, president of Childline, emphasized the need for adults, parents, and teachers to intervene, as bullying does not resolve on its own and often worsens. Schools are urged to take the issue seriously, and children are encouraged to seek help. The report was released during Anti-Bullying Week, coordinated by the Anti Bullying Alliance, which collaborates with parents, schools, and other organizations to address the problem. A young person who contacted Childline described being targeted by online peers, leading to emotional distress, and expressed difficulty in seeking support from parents.

The passage describes the political tensions between Israel and the United States following a UN Security Council resolution that condemned Israeli settlement construction in the West Bank and East Jerusalem. The resolution, which the US chose not to veto, angered Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, who accused the White House of helping draft the resolution. In response, Netanyahu took diplomatic actions against the US and several Security Council members. The resolution is seen as a significant step towards a two-state solution, with Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas hoping it will lead to a peace conference in France. The planned vote on new settlement homes in Jerusalem was postponed at Netanyahu's request to avoid further straining relations with the US ahead of a speech by US Secretary of State John Kerry.

In a BBC interview, Prince William praised Queen Elizabeth II as a "guiding example" of a good monarch on the eve of her 90th birthday. A stamp featuring the Queen, Prince Charles, Prince William, and Prince George was released to mark her birthday. The Queen celebrated her birthday with various events, including a visit to Windsor's Royal Mail delivery office, a ceremony in Alexandra Gardens, and the unveiling of a plaque for The Queen's Walkway. Prime Minister David Cameron and Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn wished her a happy birthday, highlighting her service to the nation. Prince William addressed criticisms of his work ethic, emphasizing his commitment to duty while seeking a balance between personal life and royal responsibilities. The Queen's birthday celebrations also included lighting beacons across the UK and a lunch with US President Barack Obama. Meanwhile, the republican group Republic criticized the extensive media coverage of the Queen's birthday, arguing it was disproportionate.

West Ham United defeated Cheltenham Town 2-0 in a match. Two quick goals from Diafra Sakho and Andre Ayew gave West Ham control before half-time. Sakho scored his first goal since November, and Ayew followed with a goal into the same corner. Cheltenham had chances but failed to test West Ham's goalkeeper, Adrian. Cheltenham's exit ended League Two's representation in the EFL Cup. The match ended with West Ham winning 2-0.

Aidan McNicholl, a 36-year-old hospital radiographer, died in a collision on the A5 at Cerrigydrudion. Andreas Werner, 46, of Leipzig, caused the crash by failing to see McNicholl as he turned his VW Transporter right. Werner pleaded guilty to causing death by careless driving and was fined £1,000 and banned from driving in the UK for two years. The victim's family did not seek jail time for Werner, acknowledging it was a momentary lapse. Werner expressed remorse but provided no explanation for the crash.

Imran Khawaja, a 27-year-old from Southall, London, attempted to return to the UK secretly after being a prominent British jihadist in Syria. He joined the group Rayat al Tawheed, associated with the Islamic State, and was involved in creating propaganda materials to recruit others. Khawaja was known for his online presence and masked appearances, including videos showing his activities in Syria. He was involved in fundraising and producing content that portrayed jihad as noble and adventurous. Khawaja was also part of a video showing a gruesome scene involving a head in a bag. After returning to the UK, he tried to fake his death and evade detection, but was caught at Dover. He is now facing potential life imprisonment for his actions. His cousin, Tahir Bhatti, admitted to helping him return. Khawaja has admitted to four offenses and was held in a high-risk prison unit while on remand.

Kayden Jackson, 22, has joined Barnsley for the next season after rejecting a contract offer from Wrexham. He scored four goals in 36 appearances last season as Wrexham finished eighth. Jackson is Barnsley's third signing ahead of their League One play-off final at Wembley. Paul Heckingbottom, the caretaker manager, praised Jackson's pace and his fit with the team's playing style.

A large number of sealed bottles containing the detergent "Vanish" have washed up on the beaches of Poldhu Cove and other nearby coves in Cornwall. National Trust volunteers are clearing them due to concerns about the risk to wildlife, as the bottles could leak and harm marine life. The Maritime and Coastguard Agency stated that while a container ship, the MV Blue Ocean, lost a container of Vanish bottles near Land's End in May, there is currently no evidence linking the bottles found on the coast to this incident. The company Vanish has not commented, and authorities are monitoring the situation, advising the public to keep children and dogs away from the bottles and not to attempt recovery. Conservationists are worried about the potential impact on sensitive marine ecosystems.

The incident happened on the A9 north of Berriedale in Caithness around 14:00, resulting in several minor injuries. The road was closed, and diversions were set up using the A897 Helmsdale to Melvich road. Police Scotland is continuing their investigation into the crash.

Dervite, a 28-year-old French centre-back, made 14 appearances last season to help Bolton Wanderers finish second in League One and secure promotion. He joined Bolton from Charlton in 2014 and has made 83 appearances overall. Manager Phil Parkinson praised Dervite's contribution, especially towards the end of the season. Dervite has signed a new contract with Bolton, following other players like David Wheater, Gary Madine, and Jem Karacan.

The passage describes a disagreement between the Liberal Democrats and Labour Party in the UK House of Lords. Initially, they collaborated to challenge the government on Brexit and other issues, but their cooperation ended when MPs rejected their amendments. The Lib Dems wanted to push for these amendments, while Labour was willing to defer to the Commons. Labour accused the Lib Dems of creating "false hope" among voters, while the Lib Dems criticized Labour for supporting the government's Brexit plans. Both parties have a history of working together to oppose government policies on various issues, but there are now tensions between them, with Labour suggesting there may not be much future collaboration.

The passage discusses the low priority given to defence in the current UK election, with political parties focusing more on issues like the economy, NHS, and immigration. Public and political fatigue from military interventions has contributed to this neglect. Despite the increasing global instability and threats, the UK has been cutting its military capabilities and defence spending, falling behind in global rankings. The 2% defence spending target, once a key commitment, is not being met, and further cuts are likely. While some parties, like UKIP and the Democratic Unionist Party, support the 2% target, others are not. The future of the UK's nuclear deterrent, Trident, is uncertain, with different parties proposing various approaches. Additionally, the Royal Navy's new aircraft carriers, while symbolizing power, may not be effectively crewed or equipped due to staffing and budget constraints, highlighting the challenge of maintaining a strong military presence without adequate resources.

FC Barcelona denied any wrongdoing in the Neymar transfer saga, stating they had not committed an offense. The club paid £48.6m for Neymar, with his parents receiving £34m of the fee. Including signing-on fees, wages, agent fees, and additional tax payments, Neymar's total cost to the club reached £106.8m. Barcelona's former president, Sandro Rosell, resigned amid allegations of financial misconduct and is under investigation. A Spanish judge ruled there was enough evidence to continue the investigation. Barcelona made a complimentary tax declaration of €13,550,830.56 to address potential tax interpretations, while maintaining that their original tax payment was in line with their obligations. The case's outcome remains uncertain. Neymar has performed well for the club, scoring seven league goals and three in the Champions League in his first season.

Michael Luciw, a 27-year-old delivery driver from Nottingham, died in a crash caused by Albert Kenneth Newman, a 70-year-old man who was driving the wrong way on the motorway. The accident occurred on 12 October near Kegworth, Leicestershire, when Newman's Mazda Premacy collided with the van Luciw was a passenger in. Luciw's family and colleagues called for stricter measures to ensure road safety, including regular driving tests and medical examinations for older drivers. Currently, drivers over 70 in the UK must renew their licenses every three years with a self-assessment form, but no medical or driving test is required. The Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA) stated it has no plans to restrict licenses based on age, citing no evidence that older drivers are more likely to cause serious accidents. Age UK emphasized the importance of older people maintaining their independence through driving.

The passage discusses concerns over the safety of transvaginal mesh implants used to treat incontinence and pelvic organ prolapse, with many women reporting severe side effects. An independent review was conducted, but it faced criticism for being biased and lacking consensus, leading to the resignation of several members. The final report recommended that procedures not be offered routinely and that patients be given informed choices, with mandatory reporting of adverse events. Despite calls for a ban, the government cannot enforce one, as it is under the jurisdiction of the UK regulatory body. Over 20,000 women in Scotland have undergone the procedure, with over 400 currently taking legal action against health boards and manufacturers.

Laura Muir, a 23-year-old Scottish athlete, broke Jenny McColgan's 25-year-old British 5K record at the Emirates Arena in Glasgow with a time of 14:49.12. McColgan expressed excitement about the record being broken but had initially questioned whether Muir's race met UK Athletics' criteria for record-breaking, as Muir was the only competitor. However, British Athletics confirmed the time would be classified as official. McColgan praised Muir's potential, believing she could improve further and compete with the world's best. Muir also holds the British 1500m record and competed in the 1500m Olympic final in 2016.

In the event, Jung won aboard Sam, who replaced Fischertakinou due to an infection. France's Astier Nicolas took silver, and American Phillip Dutton won bronze. GB's William Fox-Pitt finished 12th, despite a faultless show-jumping performance. Fox-Pitt, who had previously been in an induced coma, had his medal bid ruined by a poor cross-country performance. He led after dressage but dropped to 21st due to time penalties. Ireland's Jonty Evans finished ninth. The passage also promotes meeting Henry the mechanical horse at Team GB fan parks and subscribing to the BBC Sport newsletter.

Andy Murray, a British tennis player, won his match against Fabio Fognini in four sets with the score 6-2, 4-6, 6-1, 7-5 after two hours and 39 minutes. The match concluded at 20:57 BST, with Murray clinching the final point. Fognini, the 29th seed, had five set points but Murray managed to win five consecutive games to secure his place in the last 16 for the 11th time. Murray will next face Benoit Paire in the fourth round. Meanwhile, fellow Briton Johanna Konta advanced to the second week of the tournament. Murray described the match as tense and challenging, especially towards the end when the light was fading and there was a possibility of changing conditions. Despite some struggles, Murray managed to win the match and expressed satisfaction with his performance.

Paramedics were called to a sudden death at Joe's Bar in Dungiven on 6 October 2014. Police found people still at the bar, with till receipts showing alcohol was served as late as 04:49 BST. The bar was ordered to close for three months. Colleen O'Neill and James Thomas, both from Kevin Lynch Park, were charged with allowing liquor consumption outside licensing hours. The court heard that the premises had been operating well into the morning and that the license holder had an "appalling record." O'Neill was fined £3,000, and Thomas was fined £1,000. The judge expressed concern about the lack of power to impose a custodial sentence.

Mike Nesbitt, leader of the Ulster Unionists, launched the party's manifesto with a speech emphasizing "partnership" over "domination." His comments have drawn attention, particularly after a senior colleague, Danny Kennedy, publicly distanced himself from the remarks. Nesbitt defended his stance, stating he had no regrets and would not withdraw his words. He expressed a preference for forming a government with the SDLP over Sinn Féin, highlighting the need for a "Real Partnership" approach to address issues such as waiting lists, PSNI numbers, and Brexit impacts. The election is framed as a referendum on the handling of the Renewable Heat Incentive scandal and the political culture at Stormont, with Nesbitt acknowledging ongoing controversy around his remarks.

The passage outlines a motion to be considered by the Northern Ireland Assembly, which aims to align with England and Wales by providing pardons for men convicted of now-abolished sexual offences. The proposals, referred to as 'Turing's Law', include both posthumous and living pardons for gay and bisexual men. Justice Minister Claire Sugden has secured executive agreement to pass a legislative consent motion, ensuring equal treatment for these individuals and addressing past injustices. The motion is expected to be approved "as soon as possible."

Laura Muir, a 23-year-old Scottish athlete from Kinross, set a new Scottish record in the 1500m with a time of 4:19.12, finishing second behind Kenyan Faith Kipyegon. This surpassed Yvonne Murray's 1994 record of 4:22.60 and placed Muir second on the British all-time list behind Zola Budd. Muir, who finished fifth at the World Championships last year, now holds both the Scottish 1500m and mile records. She aims to qualify for the Rio Olympics at the British trials in June. Muir, who balances her training with veterinary studies, recently won an 800m race in France and will compete in a 1500m event in Stockholm next. Her husband, Tom Mooney, praised her achievement on Facebook.
The passage mentions a list of 26 beaches in Scotland that have been ranked as "most excellent" for water quality, and it refers to the inclusion of some of the user's pictures from these beaches.

In 2006, Alexander Litvinenko, a former Russian spy, was poisoned with polonium-210 during a meeting with suspects Dmitry Kovtun and Andrei Lugovoi in London, leading to his death three weeks later. Met Police barrister Richard Horwell QC stated that the Russian state likely sponsored the plot due to Litvinenko's accusations against the FSB and his personal attacks on Putin. The suspects deny wrongdoing, and attempts to extradite them have failed, leaving them in Russia. Horwell noted the suspects left a "trail of polonium" and had no credible response to the scientific evidence. The inquiry into the case was adjourned, and while the public risk from polonium remains unknown, the suspects were unlikely to face trial.

Steve Smith, 26, has been appointed as the new captain of Australia's one-day and Twenty20 teams, succeeding Michael Clarke, who has retired after the Ashes series. Smith will captain the team in the absence of the injured Aaron Finch. David Warner, 28, has been named as Smith's vice-captain. Smith has already captained Australia in three Tests against India and has played 32 Tests, scoring 2,952 runs at an average of 54.66. National selector Rod Marsh praised Smith's talent and leadership qualities, while acknowledging Warner's maturity and development despite past disciplinary issues. Smith and Warner will lead Australia in the upcoming limited-overs matches following the final Ashes Test.

The passage describes a political figure, Mr. Farron, who, when asked if he believes homosexual sex is a sin, refuses to give a direct answer, instead stating "my firm belief is we are all sinners." He expresses strong support for LGBT-plus rights and emphasizes that defending equal marriage will be a priority. He also advocates for extending marital rights to transgender individuals, highlighting the spousal veto as a barrier. Although he voted against the Equality Bill in 2007 due to concerns about individual liberties, he maintains his support for equal access under the law for all people regardless of sexuality.

Sanofi closed its drug manufacturing site in Fawdon, France, in 2015, resulting in the loss of 450 jobs. Accord Healthcare plans to use the site for pharmaceutical production, aiming to reemploy many former Sanofi employees. The move is expected to have a positive impact on the local economy and strengthen Newcastle's reputation in the healthcare sector. Accord Healthcare operates globally, developing, manufacturing, and distributing over 130 pharmaceutical products to 60 countries.

Richard Ellis is leaving his position at the end of his contract, while Ciaran Monaghan and Ewan Sutherland are resigning under a voluntary redundancy and early retirement scheme. Stephen Flynn from the SNP criticized the council for losing senior staff and expects more departures. Ellis was the interim director of corporate governance and acting deputy chief executive, Monaghan was head of the chief executive's office, and Sutherland was head of human resources and customer services. Council chief executive Angela Scott thanked them for their service.

The English rider crashed at this year's TT on a Fireblade bike that had mechanical issues. He initially said he was quitting road racing but later clarified he still wants to race but not on Hondas this year. He did not race at the North West 200 after his teammate crashed and will not compete in the Ulster Grand Prix. He described the TT as a disaster and mentioned the bike was not competitive for the Ulster Grand Prix, leading to his withdrawal from the event. He expressed interest in racing classics and oddball events instead.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 out of 28 governorships in Nigeria's elections, marking a significant defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP), which lost key northern states and failed to gain national support. The PDP retained control of Rivers State but lost Adamawa, a state affected by Boko Haram. APC leader Muhammadu Buhari will be inaugurated as president on 29 May, following his victory over President Goodluck Jonathan. The PDP's decline is attributed to corruption allegations, failed policies, and defections to APC. The APC's success in the north and Lagos state highlights its growing influence, while the PDP faces challenges in rebuilding. Elections were generally peaceful, with some violence reported in southern states. The APC's inability to win oil-producing states may pose challenges for Buhari's administration.

The passage discusses allegations by the environmental group Mighty against Olam, an agricultural commodities trader, and its main stakeholder, Temasek, for potentially enabling unsustainable palm oil practices that contribute to haze in Southeast Asia. These practices are linked to slash-and-burn techniques used by farmers and traders in Indonesia. Olam claims it has a strict sourcing policy with zero tolerance for burning and has only recently disclosed its suppliers. Temasek, as a major stakeholder, denies the allegations and emphasizes its support for no-burn policies. The report also raises concerns about Olam's activities in Gabon, where it is accused of clearing rainforests for palm oil plantations. Olam defends its operations in Gabon as responsible and transparent. The palm oil industry is criticized for environmental and labor issues, with ongoing disputes between environmental groups and industry executives.
A restaurant started offering puppy platters after a new law allowed dogs to eat at restaurants, provided they were outdoors.

The passage outlines the latest injury updates and potential returns for Derby County players. Forward Fernando Forestieri is doubtful due to a knee injury, having only played from the bench in the last two games. Striker David Nugent may return after missing the game against Huddersfield. Midfielder Jacob Butterfield is hopeful for a recall following his late goal in the match against the Terriers.

In 2012, Pakistan banned YouTube after an offensive film sparked protests. The ban was lifted as Google launched a Pakistan-specific version of YouTube. The Pakistan Telecommunication Authority (PTA) allowed internet service providers to resume access to YouTube. While the government claims it can request content removal, Google stated it follows community guidelines and may restrict access to illegal content after review. Activists call for transparency in the agreement with Google. The ban was imposed by the Supreme Court due to the controversial film "Innocence of Muslims," which led to protests and deaths in Pakistan. Google has now launched local versions of YouTube in Nepal, Pakistan, and Sri Lanka.

Domenico Scala, head of Fifa's Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee, is Swiss-Italian, sharing nationality with presidential candidate Gianni Infantino. Scala previously stepped down from the 2015 elections due to potential conflict of interest with Swiss candidate Sepp Blatter. Musa Bility, LFA boss, threatens to take the case to the Court of Arbitration for Sport if Scala does not withdraw by Thursday. The election to replace Blatter is set for February 26, with five candidates including Infantino, Prince Ali, Jerome Champagne, Sheikh Salman, and Tokyo Sexwale. Bility argues that Scala's dual nationality creates a conflict of interest, while Scala's representative denies this, stating there is no such regulation. The election will be held in Zurich, with votes from Fifa's 209 members.

Daniel Timbers, 29, and Barry Joy, 56, were killed in a flashover explosion at Harford Attachments in Spar Road, shortly after 09:00 BST on Monday. They were working in a paint-spraying area. Their bodies were removed on Tuesday afternoon. A forensic search has been conducted, and Det Ch Insp Paul Durham mentioned significant progress in inquiries, suggesting the fire started from a build-up of toxic fumes and an ignition source. The Health and Safety Executive is gathering evidence with inspectors and electrical safety experts.

Tunisia was initially expelled from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations (Nations Cup) due to complaints against Caf but reconciled after apologizing. Morocco was banned from the 2017 Nations Cup qualifying draw but had their ban overturned by the Court of Arbitration for Sport (Cas). Both nations faced past controversies: Morocco was replaced as 2015 hosts due to Ebola fears and later fined, while Tunisia disputed a controversial penalty in the 2015 Nations Cup, leading to a dispute with Caf. Tunisia's 2017 participation was secured after a meeting with Caf president Issa Hayatou. Tunisia will face Togo, Liberia, and Djibouti in Group A, while Morocco will face Cape Verde, Libya, and Sao Tome in Group F. If Tunisia reaches the 2017 finals, it would achieve a record 13 consecutive Nations Cup participations.

In the 95th minute of a game at Etihad Stadium, a mass fracas occurred, resulting in Manchester City's Sergio Aguero and Fernandinho being sent off. Chelsea's Cesc Fabregas was not further penalized. Aguero received a four-match ban for violent conduct, while Fernandinho will serve a three-match ban. City manager Pep Guardiola apologized for the incident. Both clubs have until 8 December to respond to the charge.

The passage discusses a pilot scheme in Cwm Cynon and Castell-nedd aimed at early cancer diagnosis for asymptomatic patients. Inspired by Denmark's successful cancer diagnosis system, the initiative seeks to address delays in diagnosis for patients with unclear symptoms. Doctors in Wales believe early detection could improve outcomes. The pilot involves referring patients to diagnostic clinics at Ysbyty Brenhinol Morgannwg and may lead to the establishment of similar services across Wales if successful. The goal is to diagnose cancer earlier, potentially saving lives and improving patient care.

England secured a decisive victory against Pakistan in the second Test at Old Trafford, leveling the series with a comprehensive margin. England's score of 589-8 declared in the first innings and 173-1 declared in the second set up their second-largest win over Pakistan in terms of runs. Joe Root was named man of the match for his outstanding performances, scoring 254 in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 in the second, along with taking four catches and a wicket. Captain Alastair Cook praised Root's performance, calling it one of the best he had seen. Pakistan's batting was criticized, with only two players scoring over 50 in the series, and their captain Misbah-ul-Haq acknowledged the team's lack of confidence and poor shot selection. The third Test is scheduled for August 3 at Edgbaston.

Head coach Warren Gatland is leading the British and Irish Lions in New Zealand, with interim coach Rob Howley as part of his backroom team. Forwards coach McBryde will take on head coach responsibilities for the third time, following his previous roles with Wales. McBryde expressed his honor and excitement about the opportunity. The Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) is appointing assistant coaches for the summer tour and is in advanced discussions with other individuals to finalize the management team. WRU chief executive Martyn Phillips and union chairman Gareth Davies believe the involvement of Welsh coaches will benefit the national team and provide valuable development opportunities. They also highlighted the potential mental and inspirational benefits of the New Zealand tour for both coaches and players.

In a dramatic match, Hull City secured a 2-1 victory over Southampton, ending a six-game league losing streak. The game saw Southampton take an early lead through a penalty by Charlie Austin, but Hull turned the tide in the second half. Robert Snodgrass, coming on as a substitute, played a crucial role, scoring a goal and setting up Michael Dawson's equalizer. Despite Southampton's efforts to equalize, David Marshall made several important saves. The win was significant for Hull, lifting their spirits and providing a morale boost. Both managers reflected on the performance, with Hull's manager Mike Phelan praising his team's resilience and Southampton's Claude Puel acknowledging the need for improved concentration. The match concluded with Hull City 2, Southampton 1.

A motorcycle crash occurred at 14:15 BST on the B1191 near Woodhall Spa, Lincolnshire. The motorcyclist, who lived locally, was killed, while the tractor driver was unharmed. Lincolnshire Police are seeking witnesses and have closed the B1191 in both directions between specific junctions.

In June, President Ivanov of Macedonia canceled an investigation into abuse of power claims revealed by covert recordings, aiming to "put an end to the agony" before early elections. This decision was criticized by the opposition and EU officials, including EU Enlargement Commissioner Johannes Hahn, who called it incompatible with the rule of law and potentially jeopardizing Macedonia's EU membership. The crisis began in 2015 with the release of recordings showing ministers plotting vote-rigging and covering up a murder. Opposition leader Zoran Zaev has been releasing these recordings, accusing the government of widespread corruption, while the government denies the allegations and claims Zaev is trying to destabilize the country.

Swansea is preparing for their match against Bournemouth with Curtis and assistant manager Paul Williams temporarily in charge following Bob Bradley's sacking. The club aims to appoint a new manager quickly, with Paul Clement as their top choice. Curtis expresses concerns about the team's current direction, noting a decline since Michael Laudrup's departure in 2014 and frequent changes in management. He believes the squad is capable of staying in the Premier League and emphasizes the importance of the club's history and the need to maintain the 'Swansea Way.' Swansea, promoted in 2011, has a strong history of successful management and a remarkable rise from near bankruptcy. Curtis reminds new signings of the club's journey and its significance to the local area.

In a crucial match, Dagenham & Redbridge (The Daggers) lost to Leyton Orient, resulting in their relegation and ending their promotion hopes. The match saw goals from Jamie Cureton and Clevid Dikamona for Dagenham, but Armand Gnanduillet's winning goal for Orient secured their play-off chances. This loss marks Dagenham's return to the National League under manager John Still, who previously led them to League One in 2007. The club faces challenges, including a poor goal difference and a struggling attack, with Jamie Cureton scoring only nine goals this season compared to 20 in the previous campaign. Still expressed commitment to helping the club gain promotion next season. Meanwhile, Leyton Orient's interim manager, Andy Hessenthaler, emphasized the importance of professionalism and the fans' support, following the recent dismissal of player-manager Kevin Nolan.

Steven Gerrard, a former Liverpool captain, will return to his former club as a youth coach in February after retiring as a player. Gerrard, who had a 19-year career at Liverpool, won multiple trophies, including the Champions League, and later played for LA Galaxy. He is currently working towards a Uefa A coaching licence to manage in the Premier League. Gerrard expressed interest in becoming a manager in the future and was previously linked with the manager's job at MK Dons, but felt the opportunity came too soon. Liverpool manager Jurgen Klopp praised Gerrard's qualities and described his appointment as "wonderful news."

In this match, McManus scored first and then again to help his team take the lead. Ross Forbes also scored, and despite a goal from Kyle McAusland, the hosts secured a comfortable win with additional goals from McManus and Denny Johnstone.

Ofsted has found evidence of children being taught in squalid conditions in three closed schools in Birmingham, with owners under investigation. Illegal schools could face up to 51 weeks in jail. Ministers are consulting on stricter regulations for schools operating more than 6-8 hours weekly. Sir Michael Wilshaw noted inspectors were shocked by conditions and warned that these cases may be the "tip of the iceberg," with concerns about child abuse and radicalization. 18 unregulated schools, mainly in Muslim communities in the Midlands, have been investigated. While some "flexi schools" are legal, Ofsted and ministers suspect others are illegal.  Six inspectors have been funded to investigate illegal schools, with inspections potentially expanding beyond Muslim communities. The education secretary plans to pursue prosecutions, and a government consultation on further regulations is ongoing until mid-January.

Lilliard Gin is based at the Born in the Borders visitor centre in Jedburgh and aims to capture the local flavour of the Scottish Borders using regional botanicals. It is part of plans to establish the region's first whisky distillery since 1837. The gin is produced on a small scale, fitting into a cowshed, and is named after Lilliard, a legendary Borders heroine. The distillery is seen as a natural complement to the Scottish Borders Brewery on-site.

Harry Whitlam died in August 2013 when Gary Green, who was over twice the legal alcohol limit, reversed a vehicle into him on private land at Swithens Farm. Green, who had consumed the equivalent of 13 pints of beer, was jailed for 16 months and two weeks and was prosecuted under health and safety legislation. Harry's mother, Pam Whitlam, expressed the family's grief and emphasized the importance of not driving under the influence. The Health and Safety Executive described Green's actions as reckless.

Luis Suarez, a 27-year-old Uruguay striker, has been allowed to train and participate in friendly matches with his new club Barcelona after an appeal against his suspension. He will join Barcelona's training session on Friday and will be publicly presented as a new player on Monday at the Camp Nou. While he cannot play in competitive matches, he can now engage in all football-related activities. His ban from competitive international games remains, with eight games left of a nine-match suspension. Suarez's competitive debut for Barcelona is expected to be against Real Madrid on 26 October. He will be available for Uruguay's friendlies in September and Saudi Arabia in October. The Court of Arbitration for Sport (Cas) upheld Fifa's decision but deemed the complete ban excessive. Suarez's lawyers argued the punishment was disproportionate, and while the appeal was unsuccessful, the ruling allows him to train and participate in promotional activities. Suarez has a history of disciplinary issues, including previous suspensions for biting and racial abuse.

On 18 March 2014, Richard Blake-Smith and his partner Anna won a race by carrying Anna's wife, Neringa Kirliauskiene, defeating Vytautas Kirkliauskas of Lithuania. The race involved a 380-metre course with obstacles like haystacks, a steep slope, and water pistols. The event included various competitor combinations, such as men carrying women or men. The winners will compete at the World Championships in Finland in July.

In October 2014, the UK government planned to replace the paper tax disc system with an electronic system, allowing monthly direct debits. This change raised concerns about job losses at the DVLA, which employs around 5,000 workers. Stephen Hammond, a minister, addressed these concerns in a letter to Mike Hedges, assuring that job role changes would occur, but any reductions in staff would be managed through redeployment to other areas of the DVLA. Hedges welcomed the assurances, acknowledging the benefits of the new system while expressing disappointment over reduced job opportunities.

The passage discusses Hungary's resistance to EU pressure over three controversial laws: strict asylum controls, a higher education law that could close the Central European University (founded by George Soros), and legislation targeting NGOs. Hungary's Foreign Minister, Szijjarto, asserts that these issues are domestic and urges the EU to refrain from interference. Poland has pledged to veto any EU sanctions against Hungary. The EU has expressed concerns over the laws' compatibility with EU values and rules, with warnings of potential action if Hungary does not change course. Human rights groups criticize the proposed NGO law for labeling them as "foreign-backed."

The passage describes the casting and details of the live-action film adaptation of "Beauty and the Beast." Emma Watson is cast as Belle, Dan Stevens as the Beast, and Luke Evans as Gaston. Josh Gad plays LeFou, and Kevin Kline plays Maurice. The film, directed by Bill Condon, is set for release on 17 March 2017 and begins filming in May at Shepperton Studios.

Adrian Gill, a renowned journalist and writer for the Sunday Times, passed away suddenly after being diagnosed with multiple cancers. Despite his illness, Gill remained stoical and expressed gratitude for his life. He was celebrated for his wit, writing, and intelligence, and was deeply respected by colleagues and peers. Gill's career, which began in the 1980s, included controversial remarks that sparked debate, but he was also admired for his unique style and contributions to journalism. He overcame dyslexia to become a successful writer, and his personal life included two marriages and a long-term relationship. His final column, reflecting on his diagnosis, was published in the Sunday Times.

Amarmandakh Sukhbaatar, a Mongolian rapper known as Amraa, was attacked in Ulan Bator, Mongolia, during a performance. He was hit with a bottle and kicked in the face, leading to a coma for about 10 days. His father reported the injuries, and the rapper emphasized that the swastika, which he wore on stage, is a traditional Mongolian symbol, not a hate symbol. The Russian embassy called local reports "distorted" and stated they were investigating the incident. The suspect, a Russian diplomatic officer, has not been identified or arrested, though the police said he was not detained due to the injury's severity, not diplomatic immunity. The rapper's lawyer and band member denied claims he shouted "Heil Hitler" during the show. The swastika has historical significance in Mongolia, predating Nazi use, but is also associated with far-right groups in the country.

Campaigners from Plane Stupid protested against an airport's expansion plans by staging a demonstration on the northern runway at 03:30 BST. They were charged with aggravated trespass and entering a security restricted area and will appear in court on 19 August. The Metropolitan Police stated they will review airport security following the incident.

Glamorgan's innings was dominated by Nick Selman's second first-class century, scoring 101 off 144 balls, after being dropped on eight. Seamers Matt Taylor and Craig Miles took regular wickets in cloudy conditions. Gloucestershire struggled as the bowlers remained dominant, with Aneurin Donald scoring 36 off 30 balls. Glamorgan's batsmen Graham Wagg and Timm van der Gugten earned a consolation bonus point. The day ended evenly balanced, with Glamorgan led by Michael Hogan due to Jacques Rudolph's absence. Selman expressed relief at scoring runs after a string of low scores and acknowledged the difficulty of opening in county cricket. Gloucestershire's Matt Taylor praised the bowlers' performance and the opportunity to bowl with the red ball.

Craig Hughes, 33, was arrested by North Wales Police in August after communicating online with the Hope Line Crisis Centre in Tennessee. He admitted to planning to make false police reports to ambush officers on the Dee Estuary, a plan he made while drunk on two separate occasions. Hughes has a prior conviction for firearm possession in 2009. He was remanded in custody pending sentencing after admitting two charges. The court was informed that Hughes had not intended to harm himself or carry out threats against police, although North Wales Police was concerned due to his bail status and pending firearms trial, which he was later cleared of. The Hope Line Crisis Centre provides confidential support and counseling.

In this cricket match, Yorkshire, after being reduced to 8-2, posted a score of 255-7 with a notable partnership of 130 between Davies and Ben Foakes. However, their run-chase was disrupted by a three-wicket burst in nine balls from Stuart Meaker, leading to their eventual defeat for 236. Despite a strong start and contributions from Tim Bresnan (68), Yorkshire fell short. The team was hoping to reach Lord's for the first time since 2002 but were disappointed after losing to Durham in the T20 Blast semi-finals. Surrey's captain, Gareth Batty, praised the team's performance, while Yorkshire's captain, Alex Lees, expressed disappointment, acknowledging the bowlers' effectiveness and the team's failure to perform when it mattered most.

A 56ft converted trawler, located 6 miles west of South Stack, was in distress when the crew contacted coastguards at 07:00 BST. The boat's pump could not handle the incoming water, so an RNLI lifeboat crew provided assistance by placing a pump and towing the vessel to Holyhead.

Muir will not compete in the Commonwealth Games due to her veterinary medicine studies, which conflict with the event schedule. She will return to university and complete her final year, prioritizing her degree. Despite missing the Commonwealth Games, she remains committed to representing Scotland and believes the team will perform well. Muir is targeting the World Indoor Championships and is in good shape, having set a new outdoor personal best in the 5,000m. She also expressed optimism about her future in athletics, including potential participation in future Olympics.

This passage discusses Robbie Savage's analysis of Liverpool's current situation in the Premier League, focusing on their distance from repeating last season's title challenge, their potential lineup against Chelsea, and Steven Gerrard's struggle to secure a long-term future with the club. Savage highlights Liverpool's struggles in attack, particularly the lack of quality strikers and the decline in their high-intensity pressing and set-piece effectiveness. He also criticizes the defensive instability despite spending significant money on defenders. While acknowledging the challenges, Savage believes Gerrard still has a role in the team, especially as a defensive midfielder, and emphasizes the mental and physical battle he faces to extend his career. Overall, Savage predicts a tough match against Chelsea, with Liverpool having a difficult time competing against the dominant Blues.

A new £45m facility in Kilmarnock will house primary and secondary schools, a Gaelic school, and a childcare centre. East Ayrshire Council plans to name the campus after William McIlvanney, a renowned Scottish writer and educator, with permission from his family. McIlvanney, who was born and educated in Kilmarnock, transitioned from teaching to writing in 1975 and became known as the "Godfather of Tartan Noir." He authored notable works such as the Laidlaw trilogy and contributed to Scottish culture through poetry, journalism, and broadcasting. He passed away on 5 December.

A section of the town near the swimming pool was evacuated for most of the morning and early afternoon due to a sea mine spotted on Monday, believed to be a British mine from the 1940s or 1950s. Residents within 500 meters of the mine were advised to stay indoors, open windows, and avoid going outside. An exclusion zone remained in place on the river, and a half-mile exclusion zone was established at sea, affecting small boat owners. Ferry services experienced some disruption. Experts from the Royal Navy's Northern Diving Unit were working to safely move the mine due to its deteriorated condition, as the amount of explosive material could not be determined. The evacuation was precautionary, and there was no immediate danger to the community. Inverclyde Council thanked residents for their cooperation during the operation.

The passage discusses UK Sport's decision to reduce funding for several sports, including archery, fencing, weightlifting, wheelchair rugby, badminton, and basketball, while increasing support for others like judo. The total investment for Olympic and Paralympic sports is £345m, a £2m decrease from the Rio 2016 funding. This decision aims to prioritize sports with higher medal potential for the Tokyo 2020 Games, targeting 51-85 Olympic and 115-162 Paralympic medals. Badminton, which won a bronze in Rio, is the only sport that achieved a podium finish to lose funding, prompting criticism from its leaders. UK Sport emphasizes the need for prioritization to maintain medal success, while some sports argue the decision undermines future performance. Additional sports like baseball/softball, karate, and others will be considered for inclusion, with final funding decisions pending.

Three Victorian hotels in Bournemouth's East Cliff area will be demolished to make way for a six-storey, four-star hotel and two assisted-living apartment blocks. English Heritage opposed the development, citing potential harm to the conservation area. However, councillors voted in favour, arguing the project would boost tourism and improve living conditions for older people. The buildings to be demolished are considered no longer functional. The development includes a 90-room hotel and 122 assisted-living apartments. While 246 residents supported the plans, 49 residents and the Ancient Monuments Society objected, emphasizing the historic character of the area.

Pte Matthew Boyd, a 20-year-old soldier from Carrickfergus, was attacked and killed by Jake Vallely during a night out in Brecon. The attack occurred outside a bar called The Cellar, where CCTV footage showed Boyd being punched, beaten, and left unconscious. Vallely then dragged his body away before fleeing. Aaeron Evans, Vallely's friend, was cleared of manslaughter as he was not present during the attack. The trial revealed Vallely had been drinking heavily and boasted of being the "hardest man in Brecon" before the attack. The incident shocked the community, with authorities condemning the act as despicable. A family tribute described Boyd as a loving and promising individual, expressing deep grief over his death and the impact on their lives. Vallely will be sentenced on 8 December.

Andrew Travers left his position at Barnet Council by mutual agreement following an error that caused voters to be turned away from polling stations due to missing names on the poll list. An independent investigation has been launched, and Deputy Chief Executive John Hooton will temporarily take over. The council apologized for the issues and offered emergency proxy votes. Travers blamed the electoral registration lists for the problems, and the review will conclude by the end of May, examining arrangements for the EU Referendum.

In this match, Gateshead defeated Wrexham 2-1. Josh Gillies opened the scoring with a free-kick, but Wrexham equalized through a set-piece from Sean Newton. Ryan Bowman secured the win for Gateshead with a header from a cross by Jamie Chandler. Gateshead's manager, Malcolm Crosby, praised the team's second-half performance, while Wrexham's manager, Gary Mills, expressed disappointment with their second-half display.
The Global AgeWatch Index 2014 evaluates the social and economic welfare of individuals over 60 in 96 countries. Norway is ranked first, while Afghanistan is the worst, followed by Mozambique.

The passage describes the OneWeb project, which aims to create a global broadband network using a constellation of at least 600 spacecraft, potentially expanding to over 2,000. The project focuses on high-volume, low-cost satellite production, utilizing new assembly line methods inspired by automotive and aviation industries. Airbus, in partnership with OneWeb, has established assembly lines in Toulouse, France, and plans to expand to Florida. The satellites will be launched in waves, with the first launches scheduled for early 2021. The project requires a significant rocket campaign, with over 20 Soyuz vehicles booked to launch satellites into orbit. OneWeb faces competition from other companies like SpaceX and Boeing, but believes it has a first-mover advantage. The project also emphasizes debris mitigation, with plans to de-orbit satellites within two years and include technology to retrieve any satellites that fail during descent. The UK plays a key role in the project's regulatory and economic aspects, and the success of OneWeb's manufacturing approach could influence the broader satellite industry.

The passage discusses the financial pressures on the Scottish government due to UK government spending cuts. Mr. Swinney, the Scottish government leader, highlights that real-term discretionary budget cuts will reduce by 12.5% by 2019-20 compared to 2010-11, with 4.2% of that reduction occurring between now and 2019-20. He criticizes the UK chancellor's austerity measures, stating that significant cuts of over £1bn remain to be implemented. Despite these challenges, Mr. Swinney asserts that the Scottish government will prioritize essential services like education, healthcare, and policing. The UK government counters by stating that Scotland will have an increased block grant, and the current economic stability is better than the alternative of Scottish independence. Labour criticizes the Scottish government for its anti-austerity rhetoric and calls for a long-term budget with different tax policies.

This passage discusses the challenges faced by individuals with severe disabilities and their families when accessing suitable toilet facilities. It highlights the need for Changing Places toilets, which offer enhanced facilities for those requiring assistance with toileting. Currently, these toilets are recommended but not compulsory in building regulations. Campaigners are pushing for them to be made compulsory in larger public buildings. The passage includes personal stories from families who have experienced the difficulties of lacking proper facilities and the positive impact of having access to Changing Places toilets. It also mentions the logistical and financial challenges of installing these toilets and the importance of making them available to ensure inclusivity for all.

A group of Italian consumer organizations has formally complained to the European Commission, accusing McDonald's of imposing excessive rents and fees on franchisees, which they claim limits consumer choice and raises prices. McDonald's defends its approach, stating it shares risks and rewards with franchisees. The complaint is supported by unions, including the SEIU and the Bakers Food and Allied Workers Union in the UK. The European Commission has agreed to investigate the allegations, which include claims that franchisees are bound by long contracts and lease premises at above-market rates. Franchisees operate 73% of McDonald's restaurants in Europe, and the company earned $9.27bn in franchised revenues globally in 2014.

A social media campaign supporting 13-year-old Joshua Martin, who was diagnosed with cancer, has gone viral. The campaign began with a hashtag on Facebook and Instagram by Bangor Elim Church, where Josh's father is a staff member. The hashtag #prayforjosh was shared 948 times and viewed by over 79,000 people. A mystery donor paid for a billboard with the hashtag in Holywood. The campaign has received global support, with Josh's classmates also using the hashtag on Twitter. The support has been overwhelming, with people from all over the world praying for Josh and his family.

The passage discusses the closure of Brecon Barracks in Wales as part of a UK military restructuring. MP Chris Davies criticized the decision, highlighting the barracks' long history and its importance to the local community and military tourism. He plans to fight the closure and launch a petition, expressing concerns over unemployment and the impact on the town. The Defence Secretary mentioned creating a light infantry centre at St Athan and closing other bases like Cawdor Barracks and the Sennybridge depot. Labour's Shadow Defence Secretary acknowledged the need for restructuring but warned of the uncertainty it may cause for local residents.

The passage discusses the potential impact of Brexit on the UK fishing industry. It highlights concerns that Brexit could lead to the UK allowing EU-registered boats to fish in UK waters as part of trade negotiations. Fishing communities, which heavily supported leaving the EU, are at risk of being marginalized. The EU's Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) has been criticized by the industry for limiting control over UK waters. While some argue Brexit offers opportunities to regain control and become a leading fish-exporting nation like Norway, the House of Lords report warns that the industry must not be overlooked in Brexit negotiations. The report notes that the UK's fishing industry is small in economic terms but important for coastal communities. The industry's future depends on continued market access, which may require trade-offs. The report suggests retaining elements of the CFP post-Brexit and maintaining cooperation with neighboring states. There is concern about the potential for different fisheries management regimes in the UK's four nations. Despite these concerns, some in the industry remain optimistic about Brexit's potential to bring more control and sustainable management. The EU recently announced new quotas under the CFP, which some analysts see as a positive sign for the UK fishing industry. The UK government emphasizes the opportunity to review fisheries management to ensure fair access, sustainable stocks, and a healthy marine environment.

Ed Snowden, a former CIA employee, revealed himself as the source of leaks that exposed the extent of US surveillance. The leaks showed that the NSA has massive access to personal data, including phone records, social media, and internet activity. The NSA obtained phone records from Verizon and had "backdoor" access to servers of major tech companies like Google, Facebook, and Apple through a program called Prism. These companies denied involvement, and the exact workings of Prism remain unclear. While the NSA claims these operations protect national security, experts question their true scope. Data protection laws vary by country, and many cloud services are subject to US jurisdiction, allowing US authorities to access non-American data with limited transparency. The UK and EU have expressed concerns, and Snowden criticized the surveillance practices, fearing a loss of privacy.

OpenAI is a venture backed by prominent figures and companies such as Elon Musk, Peter Thiel, Infosys, and Amazon Web Services. Its mission is to develop AI research focused on positive human impact without financial constraints. While some experts warn of AI's potential existential threats to humanity, others believe the risks are remote. OpenAI aims to advance digital intelligence for the benefit of all humanity, ensuring AI aligns with human wills and is distributed as broadly and safely as possible. Only a small portion of the $1 billion funding will be used in the near future.

L/Bdr Parkinson, who was seriously injured in a bomb attack in Afghanistan in 2006, carried the Olympic torch on 26 June. Despite losing his speech due to a brain injury, he has regained his ability to speak and remains humorous and determined. He spends 12 hours daily in the gym and rehabilitation, walks with crutches, and raises money for military charities. His Facebook page received thousands of friend requests, but Facebook limits personal pages to 5,000 friends. His mother noted the overwhelming support and increased mail and email traffic. Facebook suggested creating a public page or using subscribe for more visibility. The Olympic torch will be carried by 8,000 people over 8,000 miles in 70 days leading up to the London Olympics on 27 July.

In 2011, the US poverty rate remained at 15%, with 46.2 million Americans in poverty, after three years of increases. The real median household income decreased by 1.5%, and the average poverty threshold for a family of four was $23,021. Income inequality, as measured by the Gini index, increased by 1.6% for the first time since 1993. The percentage of Americans without health insurance dropped to 15.7% from 16.3%. Poverty reached a record high in 2010 at 15.1%.

Jos Buttler, a 25-year-old cricketer, has signed a new contract with Lancashire until 2019. He moved to the club from Somerset in 2013 and is known as a short-format specialist, having scored England's three fastest ODI centuries. Buttler plays for Mumbai Indians in the Indian Premier League and will return to Lancashire for their T20 Blast game against Durham. Cricket director Ashley Giles praised Buttler's talent, his contribution to the team's T20 Blast victory, and his positive influence on the squad.

The decommissioned Type 22 frigates HMS Cumberland, HMS Campbeltown, HMS Chatham, and HMS Cornwall are currently moored in Portsmouth Harbour. Bidders had until 23 January to register interest in the ships, but no preservation proposals have been submitted. Those who registered are finalizing bids, with viewings scheduled for late February and March, and a final decision expected in the spring. The government aims to award at least one frigate to a UK ship recycler to assess industry capacity. Penny Mordaunt supports UK recyclers but also hopes for at least one ship to be preserved, ideally as a reef or diving attraction, for tourism and value. The Ministry of Defence seeks the best financial return for taxpayers. The ships, originally designed for anti-submarine warfare, were versatile combatants with advanced systems. Last year, HMS Ark Royal was sold for £3m.

Since 1987, Fiji has experienced ongoing racial and political tensions leading to instability and international isolation. A series of coups, including the 1987 indigenous Fijian coup, the 2000 coup led by George Speight, and the 2006 military takeover, have caused economic harm, particularly to tourism, and damaged Fiji's international reputation. These tensions led to Fiji's suspension from the Commonwealth in 2009. In 2012, the government agreed to hold free elections, leading to the restoration of diplomatic ties with Australia and New Zealand and Fiji's re-admission to the Commonwealth. Fiji's population is divided between indigenous Fijians and Indo-Fijians, with the latter fleeing due to political unrest. The society remains segregated, with small minority communities. Economically, Fiji relies on sugar and tourism but also has mining and services sectors, though it faces trade and budget deficits, making it a major aid recipient.

Syria claims it is doing its best to comply with the timetable to destroy its chemical weapons, but missed a deadline to hand over its entire stockpile. Two shipments were attacked on the way to the port of Latakia, with the second intercepted by fire from terrorist groups. Syria denies using barrel bombs on civilians and accuses the US of supporting terrorists. The conflict in Aleppo has resulted in numerous casualties from barrel bomb attacks. There are conflicting reports about the control of Aleppo's central prison. Syria has about 1,300 tonnes of declared chemical weapons, with only 30 tonnes having left the country so far. The US and Russia have set deadlines for the destruction of Syria's chemical weapons, while the OPCW acknowledges delays due to security concerns. Syria insists it is committed to fulfilling its obligations under the agreements with the OPCW and the UN Security Council.

The passage discusses the 46th year of the Booker Prize, which is open to all English-language authors regardless of nationality. Mukherjee's *The Lives Of Others* is the favorite to win, while Howard Jacobson's *J* is considered the strongest book on the shortlist. The shortlist includes notable authors such as Ali Smith, Joshua Ferris, Karen Joy Fowler, and Richard Flanagan. The winner will be announced at London's Guildhall, with the shortlisted authors receiving £2,500 and a special edition of their book. The shortlist has sparked debate about the prize's criteria, with some questioning whether it should prioritize literary merit over readability. The ceremony will be broadcast on the BBC News Channel and BBC Arts.

A celebrity, referred to as PJS, is appealing against an appeal court ruling that lifted a ban on his name being published in the media in England and Wales. The UK Supreme Court will consider whether to grant an appeal and decide if the ban should be allowed or dismissed. An interim injunction remains in place until the conclusion of the hearing. The Sun on Sunday seeks to publish an account of alleged extra-marital activities by PJS, who claims privacy rights. Court of Appeal judges ruled that PJS had "occasional sexual encounters" with another person, AB, starting in 2009, including a "three-way" encounter. Despite a High Court judge initially refusing an injunction, the appeal court initially ruled in PJS's favor. However, the Court of Appeal later lifted the ban, citing the widespread nature of the story and the difficulty in maintaining confidentiality. PJS opposes this, arguing the ban should remain.

Fosse Park, near junction 21 of the M1, opened in 1989 and was purchased for £345.5m in August. Plans are underway to improve parking, traffic congestion, and the appearance of the park. The new owners have engaged with Blaby District Council to address potential planning issues. Council leader Ernie White emphasized the park's importance as a gateway to the city and its potential for improvement. Paul Clarke from Crown Estates highlighted the need to address parking, congestion, and the quality of common areas and facilities to enhance the park's appeal.

The film "Beauty and the Beast" faced controversy in Malaysia due to a "gay moment" in its storyline. Although the Malaysian Censorship Board approved the film with a minor edit, Disney delayed its release for a content review. Homosexual activity is illegal in Malaysia, but the country's tourism minister criticized the potential ban. The film was given a "P13" rating, and the LPF stated it only approves content, not release dates. Some cinema chains offered refunds, and the film's director mentioned the "exclusively gay moment" involving a sidekick's complex feelings. The decision sparked criticism from netizens, who called it hypocritical.

Landlords in Southampton who rent properties to more than three unrelated people must apply for a House of Multiple Occupation (HMO) licence. Despite the potential fine of up to £20,000, many landlords are deterred by the £1,000 application fee, leading to an estimated 1,500 unlicensed HMOs. Concerns among tenants include fear of eviction and poor property maintenance. Mandatory licensing applies to properties with three or more storeys and five or more unrelated occupants. In Southampton, the licensing applies to specific areas, with some areas having different designations and introduction dates. The council has prosecuted one firm and 13 individuals for non-compliance.

Enda Kenny of Fine Gael and Micheál Martin of Fianna Fáil aim to avoid a second election. Fianna Fáil is willing to support a minority government but will not back a government program. Water charges are a major issue, with Fianna Fáil wanting their immediate removal and Fine Gael supporting their continuation. A commission to review Irish Water is under consideration. After the election, Fine Gael had 50 seats, Fianna Fáil 44, Sinn Féin 23, and Labour 7, but no party could form a majority government, and a taoiseach has not been elected.

The Sorrento, an Italian ferry, caught fire while en route to Valencia, approximately 27km from Mallorca. Passengers and crew were evacuated to lifeboats and later rescued by the ferry Puglia. At least three people were injured, with one in serious condition. The cause of the fire is unknown. Spanish officials noted the risk of the ship sinking and arranged for psychologists to provide support. The ferry sent distress signals, and the captain initially did not plan an evacuation, but the fire forced a full evacuation. The rescued passengers were heading to Palma de Mallorca.

The Electoral Commission reported that 38 MPs identified individuals, including students, who claimed to have voted twice, which is a criminal offense. There was a record number of 46.8 million voters registered for the June 8 election, with a turnout of 68.7%, the highest since 1997. A surge in registration applications occurred after the snap election was called, but concerns about duplicate entries persist. The electoral registers and online registration systems are not integrated, leading to a significant number of duplicate applications. The watchdog suggested improving registration sites with verification functions and allowing voters registered in two places to choose one constituency for future elections. Labour warned against measures that might hinder young people's ability to register to vote.

Lawrence Phillips, a former University of Nebraska star and NFL player, is believed to have taken his own life. Despite his athletic success, he faced numerous legal troubles, including assault convictions and a prison sentence. While incarcerated, he was accused of killing his cellmate, leading to a trial for the death of Damion Soward. His former coach noted his intelligence and positive traits but also his unresolved anger issues and personal struggles. The exact method of his suicide remains unclear.

Private Derby XXX was promoted to the rank of lance corporal during an event in Chester, marking eight years of the Mercian Regiment. The promotion was awarded by Brigadier Andrew Williams for "good behaviour." As the 30th in a line of mascot rams dating back to the Indian Mutiny War, Private Derby XXX has been part of the regiment since 2014. He has his own army number, is paid to buy his rations, and takes holidays during the mating season on the Chatsworth Estate. He has also participated in notable events, including switching on Christmas lights in Ashbourne and meeting Prince William at a memorial event.

Liverpool secured a dramatic 4-3 victory over Borussia Dortmund in a thrilling Europa League match, marking a significant step towards qualifying for the Champions League. The game, filled with emotion and excitement, showcased Liverpool's resilience as they overcame a 2-0 deficit in the second half. Manager Jurgen Klopp's motivational tactics and the team's determination played crucial roles in the comeback, with key goals from Philippe Coutinho, Mamadou Sakho, and the late strike by Dejan Lovren. The match was highlighted by a powerful atmosphere at Anfield, including a memorable rendition of "You'll Never Walk Alone" and a minute's silence for the Hillsborough disaster. Despite the victory, Liverpool's defensive vulnerabilities were noted, and Klopp's influence on the team and fans was evident. The win has boosted Liverpool's confidence and positioned them as strong contenders for further success in the competition.

The passage describes a meeting of the EU Negotiation Joint Ministerial Committee in London, where UK ministers discussed preparations for Brexit negotiations. Mr. Davis emphasized maintaining regular communication with Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland through monthly meetings to ensure a "two-way information flow." Mr. Russell called for greater transparency from the UK government regarding its strategic intentions, particularly regarding EU market access and membership in the single market, which he considers essential for Scotland's economy. The UK government aims to have the High Court's decision on triggering Article 50 overturned by the Supreme Court, while the Scottish government plans to oppose this in court.

The passage describes a study on cloned sheep, including Daisy, one of 13 cloned sheep at the University of Nottingham. These sheep, including four clones of Dolly, are being closely monitored to determine if cloning affects their aging process and health. Researchers are examining signs of aging-related conditions such as osteoarthritis, cardiovascular disease, and diabetes. The study aims to address concerns about whether cloned animals age prematurely or develop age-related diseases earlier than naturally born sheep. The results could have significant implications for cloning technology.

The passage discusses recent horse racing events, highlighting key performances and future plans. Shutter Speed, trained by John Gosden, won her race despite soft ground conditions and will compete in the Chantilly Oaks. Gosden's other horses, Enable and Coronet, are top contenders for the Epsom Oaks. Tasleet won the Duke of York Stakes for William Haggas. Gosden is cautious about the ground conditions for Cracksman in the Dante Stakes and may not run him in the Derby trial due to the short time frame. The trainer expressed confidence in Shutter Speed's abilities and plans to prepare her for the Chantilly Oaks.

The passage describes the fluctuating value of the British pound against the dollar, euro, and yen, influenced by the Brexit referendum. The pound initially dropped but recovered slightly before falling again. The "volatility index" reached crisis-levels, reflecting investor uncertainty. Polls show the Leave campaign is ahead, with the probability of a Remain vote decreasing. Markets are reacting to the economic implications of Brexit, with hedge funds short-selling sterling. Asian stock markets also fell due to Brexit concerns. The FTSE 100 ended the day down, with Lloyds Banking Group significantly affected. Leave campaigner Nigel Farage argued that the pound has strengthened since Brexit became a possibility and that a weaker pound benefits UK exporters.

The Iron are currently sixth in the National League, just one point and one position away from the play-off spots. After a tough loss to Barrow, who extended their unbeaten league run to nine games, manager Cowley remained optimistic. He acknowledged the challenges of their long journey and the difficulty of conceding early, but praised his team's performance so far. Cowley emphasized that this is their toughest challenge yet, but they are determined to embrace it and see where it leads.

The passage discusses a change in planning responsibilities in Northern Ireland, where local councils will now make planning decisions instead of the Planning Service. This shift is seen as a potential democratization of the planning system, with some, like Michael Corr, viewing it as an opportunity for local development. However, concerns exist about the skills of politicians in handling planning issues and the risk of favoritism or corruption, reminiscent of past issues in the 1960s. Environmental groups like Friends of the Earth emphasize the need for transparency and strict codes to prevent unfair practices. There are also concerns about political donations and their influence on planning decisions.

A one-year-old cat named Teenie was injured by three airgun shots, resulting in the amputation of her left back leg. She was found by her owner, Sarah Nisbett, and is now learning to walk again. The incident has sparked concern about the safety of airguns, with the Scottish SPCA calling for urgent licensing of air weapons. Despite a previous consultation where most respondents opposed airgun licensing, the charity emphasizes the need for stricter controls to prevent such incidents. The owner expressed fear that children in the area could be at risk, and the Scottish SPCA is urging anyone with information to come forward.

Liverpool signed Christian Benteke as their second most expensive player on a long-term contract, following the sale of Raheem Sterling. Benteke, who scored 49 goals in 101 games for Aston Villa, joined after triggering a release clause. His arrival aims to strengthen Liverpool's attack, which struggled for goals last season due to the sale of Luis Suarez and injuries to Daniel Sturridge. Benteke's signing is part of a broader summer recruitment drive, which also includes Danny Ings, Roberto Firmino, and the return of Divock Origi. Benteke missed the 2014 World Cup with an injury but had a strong season with Villa, scoring 15 goals. Former managers and players, including Paul Lambert and John Aldridge, expressed confidence in Benteke's ability to succeed at Anfield.

The passage discusses a study on the use of tablet computers in schools, revealing that while there is no clear evidence of academic improvement, tablet use is widespread, with 68% of primary and 69% of secondary schools using them. Some schools have one tablet per student, and the number of tablets is expected to double between 2014 and 2016. Researchers note that tablets help motivate disengaged students and involve families, but they cannot isolate their impact on academic results. Tablets are seen as a growing part of education, reflecting students' technology use at home and in the workforce. A separate study suggests touch-screen computers benefit boys and poorer pupils in reading. Schools like Honywood Community School advocate for tablets, emphasizing their portability, ease of use, and alignment with modern life.

The exhibition "Growing Up in the City" at the Museum of Liverpool features 25 photographs capturing children's lives from the 1880s to the 1990s. These images highlight both the joys and challenges of childhood, including special occasions and the reality of child labor. The exhibition was curated by Kay Jones, who selected the photos to reflect a comprehensive view of childhood experiences. It runs until 25 September.

Anderson, a 27-year-old centre-back, has mutually cancelled his contract with Barrow to join their National League rivals. He previously played for Aldershot, Exeter, and in Italy.
