He may play against his former club on 18 February. Keating, a 21-year-old striker, is set to join after being recommended by Micky Adams. He has played for Sligo Rovers, Galway United, and Finn Harps, with his transfer pending international clearance. Gulls manager Kevin Nicholson praised Anderson's leadership qualities and Keating's potential. The Gulls are four points above the relegation zone but have only won one of their last six games.

The passage discusses Bolivia's new law allowing 12-year-olds to work with parental authorization, reflecting the country's economic realities. The law includes harsher penalties for child violence, such as 30 years in prison for child homicide. It was approved by Congress and signed by Vice-President Alvaro Garcia Linera while President Evo Morales was away. The law aims to address extreme poverty, as over 500,000 children work in Bolivia, often in dangerous conditions. While the International Labour Organisation (ILO) allows a minimum working age of 14 in developing countries, it is reviewing the legislation to check if it complies with international child labor regulations.

A 50-year-old woman, O'Donnell, experienced a heart attack known as the "widow maker" after falling ill at home. She researched her symptoms online, took aspirin, and visited a cardiologist the next day, who inserted a stent into a 99% blocked artery. She did not call emergency services but warned others to recognize heart attack symptoms and seek help immediately. O'Donnell, known for her acting roles, recently hosted a canceled talk show.

A 16-year-old boy named Che Labastide-Wellington was stabbed to death during a party in Belvedere Way, Kenton, on Saturday evening. The incident occurred in an alleyway around 00:30 GMT after he was invited to the well-organized event. Police believe he was not involved in an earlier altercation but was targeted later. A 21-year-old man and two boys aged 15 and 16 have been arrested on suspicion of murder, while a 14-year-old is held on suspicion of possession of an offensive weapon. Another 16-year-old boy was also stabbed and is in stable condition. Authorities are seeking witnesses near the alleyway between Belvedere Way and Tylers Gate.

The passage discusses Denmark's initiative to improve cancer diagnosis by reorganizing the healthcare system. This reform was prompted by poor cancer survival rates over 15 years ago, particularly for cases with non-obvious symptoms. The new system includes three routes: fast-track diagnosis for alarm symptoms, diagnosis centres for undiagnosed symptoms, and "yes-no" centres for minor symptoms. The changes have improved diagnosis efficiency, reduced waiting times, and enhanced survival rates. The Danish model is seen as a potential example for Wales to adopt, emphasizing better collaboration between GPs and specialists.

The passage discusses a new role in Powys that will issue warning and banning orders against dishonest estate agents or those breaching estate agent laws. This service was introduced after the UK government disbanded the OFT, with Powys winning a competitive bid to take over the service and receiving £170,000 annually. Complaints about estate agents will still be handled by local authority trading standards, which will refer cases to Powys if they believe the Estate Agents Act has been breached. James Munro, who leads the new team, hopes this role will demonstrate Powys' capability to take on more contracts and external work in the future.

The NHS Employers has approved a plan to expand the roles of healthcare workers, such as nurses and pharmacists, to address staffing shortages and changing care needs. A Nuffield Trust review highlighted examples of such role expansion, noting that nurses have filled in for doctors and pharmacists for GPs. While the plan aims to improve patient care and provide more rewarding roles, unions and medical professionals have raised concerns. They warn against using this as a quick fix, emphasizing the need for proper training and funding. The report suggests that with more support, non-doctor staff could play a greater role in managing long-term conditions, but this requires investment in training and resources.

Avon and Somerset Police closed the Lower Bristol Road in Bath at Rackfield Place after a crash at 03:00 GMT, causing disruption to commuters and bus services during rush hour. The road closure was lifted at 14:00 GMT. Investigations are ongoing into the collision. First stated that some services had resumed normal schedules, with full service expected for the evening commute. Managing director James Freeman thanked the public and staff for their support and efforts during the incident.

The passage discusses a disagreement between Tidal Lagoon Power (TLP) and Natural Resources Wales (NRW) regarding the environmental impact of the Swansea tidal lagoon project. NRW estimated that the lagoon could lead to 21% of salmon and 25% of sea trout deaths annually, based on "best available evidence." TLP disputes these figures, claiming they lack a "clear scientific basis" and are based on unrealistic "what if" scenarios. TLP's own computer modeling suggests a "worst case scenario" of 2% fish mortality. The project is seen as a test bed for larger lagoons, with the UK government reviewing its viability. Wales' Environment Secretary supports the project but calls for clarity on the UK government's stance. NRW defends its methodology, stating it has shared extensive evidence and is confident in its assessment.

The passage discusses the announcement by Northern Ireland's Enterprise, Trade and Investment Minister Arlene Foster of a new industry-led agri-food marketing body, similar to Scotland Food and Drink. The body, to be developed by the Agri-Food Strategy Board (AFSB), aims to provide strategic leadership and coordination for marketing activities in the agri-food sector, which is vital for Northern Ireland's economy, employing nearly 100,000 people. Agriculture Minister Michelle O'Neill supports the initiative, noting its potential for export-led growth, but also highlights possible implications for existing organizations and the need for further discussion.

The passage describes a tree-planting event organized by the Woodland Trust at Brackfield Wood in the Faughan Valley, aimed at commemorating the millions of people who died in WW1. The project, part of a four-year initiative across the UK, involves planting 40,000 native trees to honor the estimated 40,000 people from Ireland who lost their lives in the conflict. The Woodland Trust invites the public to participate, offering saplings and encouraging volunteers to wear appropriate footwear. The resulting woodland will feature wildflowers like poppies and serve as a place for reflection and wildlife. The event is located seven miles outside Derry, with limited parking available.

Hilary won the Theakstons Old Peculier Crime Novel of the Year Award for her book "Someone Else's Skin," which is the first in a series featuring Det Insp Marnie Rome. The book was praised for its powerful storytelling and strong writing. Sara Paretsky received an outstanding contribution honor for her 23-year career creating the character VI Warshawski, a female detective. Paretsky's work, including the Deadlock novel, inspired the 1991 movie and a BBC Radio 4 adaptation. She also founded Sisters In Crime to support female crime writers. Ann Cleeves, the festival programming chair, highlighted the strength of the shortlisted books and praised Hilary's work for its atmosphere and plot.

Mitch Santner, a 24-year-old left-arm batsman and spinner, broke his finger in his second game for Worcestershire in 2016, which prevented him from contributing to the team's hopes of qualifying. Director of cricket Steve Rhodes expressed regret over losing Santner, who had made his Test debut in 2015. Santner is set to rejoin the Worcestershire Rapids after the ICC Trophy in June 2017, aiming to make up for lost time. In August 2016, Worcestershire signed Australian pace bowler John Hastings as their main overseas player for the 2017 season.

Barry Pring, a 47-year-old man, was killed in 2008 by a speeding car while attempting to hail a taxi on a dual carriageway in Kiev. His wife, Ganna Ziuzina, was 19 years younger and was involved in the case, as she tried to claim his assets shortly after his death. The coroner, Dr. Elizabeth Earland, concluded that Barry's death was an unlawful killing, citing circumstantial evidence and the fact that the car did not brake or stop. The case highlighted the challenges of investigating deaths abroad. His family believed the death was a staged hit-and-run accident, and they suspected his wife had some involvement to inherit his money and property. Ziuzina was not present at the inquest, and Ukrainian police closed the inquiry but later relaunched it as a murder inquiry, which remains active but not actively pursued.

Sophie Fearns, Charlie's mother, stated that her son, who has been ill since the age of three, needs to fly to Seattle, America for experimental T-Cell Therapy at Seattle Children's Hospital, as it is unavailable in the UK. After a third relapse in April, there were no treatment options left in the UK. The first T-Cell transplant did not work, leaving the family heartbroken. However, they were overwhelmed by an anonymous donation that covered the treatment costs. The family received confirmation via email from the hospital that someone had offered to pay for the treatment. Financial clearance has been granted, and Charlie's treatment will begin as soon as possible, with the exact date expected to be confirmed next week.

The passage discusses Apple's implementation of a two-step verification system for iCloud, aimed at preventing unauthorized access following reports of celebrities' intimate photos being stolen via third-party software like Elcomsoft's Phone Password Breaker. The new security measure requires users to enter a four-digit code via a trusted device or app when logging in from an unfamiliar device, with the option to use a recovery key if needed. While Apple's change blocks Elcomsoft's method, experts suggest making two-factor authentication the default setting rather than an opt-in choice. Concerns remain about the recovery key's security and potential for loss or theft. Some experts argue that stronger default security measures are necessary across tech companies to protect user data.

Dan Groves mentioned that details about a potential deal allowing Wright to buy 20% of Billericay are not yet finalized. Wright, a former I'm A Celebrity Get Me Out Of Here contestant, is set to become a club director. Billericay, currently eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, are three points away from a play-off spot. The club, recently purchased by Glenn Tamplin, has invested £10,000 weekly and signed former England international Paul Konchesky. Wright has a background in non-league football with clubs like Lewes and Crawley Town.

Mr Ashley has been invited by the Business, Innovation and Skills select committee, chaired by Hartlepool MP Iain Wright, to provide evidence regarding the treatment of his workers at Sports Direct's Derbyshire warehouse. The committee plans to review issues related to low-paid workers and the enforcement of the national minimum wage. Mr Ashley has until 21 March to respond, as the committee has offered alternative dates for a public meeting at Westminster, which he has not accepted. If he fails to agree to attend, the committee may take further action, including seeking support from the House of Commons. Sports Direct has not commented on the BBC's request, and the company previously pledged to review worker rights under Mr Ashley's oversight.

The passage discusses a report, "Putin. War," which was initially started by murdered opposition politician Boris Nemtsov but was never completed. His colleagues, led by Ilya Yashin, finished the report, which argues that President Vladimir Putin is waging war in Ukraine. The report is based on facts from media coverage since 2014 and claims that Russian soldiers and equipment were decisive in pro-Russian rebel victories in eastern Ukraine. Russian authorities deny sending regular troops, calling them "volunteers," but the report presents evidence suggesting otherwise, including testimonies from soldiers. The report also highlights the economic cost of the conflict and the lack of compensation for families of fallen soldiers. Despite its completion, distributing the report is challenging, and the opposition faces difficulties in gaining public support. The report's fate may mirror that of earlier works by Nemtsov, who was known for exposing corruption and the costs of the Sochi Olympics but failed to spark significant protests against Putin.

Craig Nelson, also known as Craig Preston, was found dead at the Woodhead Tunnels off the A628 in Derbyshire at 11:00 BST on Monday. The post-mortem revealed he died from head injuries. A 41-year-old man and a 23-year-old woman were arrested in Sheffield by South Yorkshire Police and are currently in custody.

The passage discusses the disagreement between the UK government and the Welsh government regarding the Article 50 letter, which outlines the UK's withdrawal from the EU. Carwyn Jones, the First Minister of Wales, criticized the UK government for not involving the Welsh administration in the drafting of the letter and for treating them with a lack of respect. Welsh Secretary Alun Cairns defended the UK government, stating that discussions about the letter had taken place over many months and that the government aims to consult on the devolution of powers to Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland. However, the specific powers to be devolved and whether funding will accompany them remain unclear. The passage also mentions the potential for a white paper to provide more details on the process.

Two cars were damaged in an incident on Nursery Drive and Parkhead in Newry on Friday night. Assistant Chief Constable Stephen Martin expressed his dismay at the attacks on PSNI officers and the community. The PSNI Newry & Mourne Facebook page stated that police were performing their duties when attacked and appealed to parents to be aware of their children's whereabouts.

Mr Charney, the founder of American Apparel, was removed as CEO last year due to employee complaints and accusations of misusing company funds. The company's court filing states it does not expect him to return, citing evidence of illicit emails and racially derogatory comments. His lawyer claims the company invaded his privacy to extort him. Mr Charney has filed a defamation lawsuit against the company and its chair. The board argues that his past conduct violates the company's policies, making it unlikely any company would hire him again. A restraining order has been granted to prevent him from making negative public statements about the company.

The passage describes a basketball game between Great Britain (GB) and Greece, which will be broadcast on BBC iPlayer and the BBC Sport website and app. The game takes place at the Copper Box in London and is GB's only home game before the FIBA EuroBasket 2017. Greece won their previous match against GB 92-64, but three of their players will be absent, giving GB a chance for revenge. GB guard Teddy Okereafor expressed excitement about playing at the Copper Box and the importance of the game for their preparation for EuroBasket. The game will be followed by a tournament in Poland before EuroBasket begins in September.

The passage describes the transformative impact of the iPhone's introduction in 2007, highlighting how it changed the way people interact with technology. Initially, phones were primarily for making calls, but the iPhone introduced a new era of mobile computing. The author recounts their experience of obtaining an iPhone for a news report, which sparked controversy but also demonstrated the device's potential. The iPhone revolutionized photography and various other activities by making powerful tools accessible on mobile devices. Although there were earlier mobile devices with basic functionalities, the iPhone's success lay in its user-friendly interface, which made it appealing to a broader audience. The author reflects on the significance of the iPhone's launch as a pivotal moment in technology history, paving the way for future innovations by companies like Amazon and Google.

In Melton Mowbray, Leicestershire, several cats have died after ingesting a toxic substance, with antifreeze identified as the cause. Meereen, a seven-month-old cat, died after consuming antifreeze and was found foaming from the mouth and trying to vomit. Her owner expressed devastation. The RSPCA is investigating whether the poisonings were accidental or deliberate and is urging residents to store pesticides and chemicals safely, especially as antifreeze is commonly used in vehicles during this time of year. Three other cats have died in the past week, with another dying two weeks ago.

The passage discusses the lack of public protests in Greece despite the Syriza government's agreement to implement austerity and liberalization measures mandated by creditors. It notes the increase in tourist arrivals to Greece, suggesting that holidaymakers may be more interested in tourism than in the political situation. The text explores the reasons behind the lack of resistance from Greeks, including the possibility that the government's concessions to secure a new bailout may have led to a sense of inevitability. It highlights the economic challenges Greece faces, including fiscal and monetary austerity, and suggests that for the new bailout to be successful, creditors must consider debt forgiveness to enable genuine recovery.

In 2012, actor Ross Kemp, who previously played Grant Mitchell in EastEnders from 1990-1999 and again in 2005-2006, returned for Barbara's final episodes. His character, Grant Mitchell, reunited with his brother Phil and mother Peggy for the last time. Peggy, who had left in 2010, returned to inform Phil of her cancer's return, leading to her eventual death in emotional scenes. The storyline brought together the Mitchell family for a heartfelt farewell, highlighting Grant Mitchell's significance as one of EastEnders' most memorable characters.

Lance Corporal Trimaan "Harry" Dhillon stalked and fatally attacked Alice Ruggles in October. Her parents, Sue Hills and Clive Ruggles, recognized Dhillon as the perpetrator immediately upon learning of her death. The trial revealed Dhillon's obsession with Alice and his stalking behavior. Dr. Hills expressed guilt for reassuring Alice on the phone and dismissing her daughter's warnings. The family established the Alice Ruggles Trust to raise awareness about stalking dangers, hoping to honor Alice's memory as a vibrant, smiling person. Dhillon was found guilty of murder and received a minimum sentence of 22 years.

The passage discusses the Hinkley Point C nuclear power plant project in Somerset, which is being financed by French firm EDF with most of the £18bn cost. EDF's board approved the funding, but the UK government has delayed its decision, raising concerns about environmental impact, costs, and foreign involvement, particularly from Chinese investors who contribute one-third of the funding. The government's decision to review the project has caused uncertainty and affected EDF's executives. Critics argue that the project is too costly and risky, while supporters emphasize its importance for energy supply and economic benefits. The project has faced delays and internal challenges within EDF, including resignations of board members. The UK government's hesitation reflects broader concerns about post-Brexit investment and the project's significance in the UK's energy strategy.

The new divorce application form in England and Wales asks for the name of the person a spouse committed adultery with, though there is no legal obligation to provide this information. Family lawyers express concerns that naming the third party can increase conflict and complexity in divorce proceedings. While the form aims to make the process more user-friendly, especially for those without legal advice, some legal professionals believe the inclusion of the question may encourage people to name the third party, even though it is not necessary. Naming the person can lead to delays and additional costs, and judges generally view such actions negatively. Adultery was a reason for 12,148 divorces in 2015, while "unreasonable behaviour" accounted for 46,815. The Ministry of Justice emphasizes that naming a third party is not required and is just one part of the divorce proceedings.

The passage discusses the debate in Wales over the focus of forestry policies. Ministers are criticized for prioritizing environmental concerns over commercial timber production, as Britain is the third-largest wood importer. Confor, a forestry industry representative, warns that 16,000 hectares of commercial forest have been lost since 2001 and need replanting. Half of Wales' woodland is managed by Natural Resources Wales, while the other half is privately owned, contributing over £450m annually to the Welsh economy. There is a conflict between environmental goals, such as promoting native broadleaf trees and public access, and the economic needs of the timber industry. The Welsh government aims for a balance between environmental, economic, and social aspects through initiatives like the Glastir scheme and the Woodlands for Wales strategy. Confor's Martin Bishop argues that the current system is too bureaucratic and that more timber planting is needed to meet industry demands.

A boy was badly injured after being struck in Coatbridge on Bank Street near Langloan Primary School at approximately 16:40. Emergency crews responded to the scene, and the boy was taken to Queen Elizabeth University Hospital in Glasgow, where his condition is considered serious.

The passage describes a ceremony where Russian Defence Attaché Capt Oleg Kornienko presented Ushakov medals to veterans of the Arctic Convoys. The medals were awarded to honor the veterans' service during World War II, when Allied ships transported supplies to the Soviet Union under extreme conditions. The Foreign Office initially blocked the recognition due to rules on foreign medals, but an exception was made in 2013. The Russian Embassy emphasized the importance of the alliance and the role of the convoys in helping defeat Nazi Germany. The Arctic convoys were perilous, with many lives lost, and the Ushakov medal is given to sailors who showed courage in defending Russia.

The HM Inspectorate of Probation found significant delays in starting unpaid work for offenders and noted that many were let off if they did not attend. One offender completed only 16 hours of work in 17 months. The Ministry of Justice acknowledged the report and is acting on its recommendations. Unpaid work, or "community payback," can range from 40 to 300 hours and is given for various offenses. In 2014, 70,000 offenders were ordered to do such work. Inspectors examined 100 cases and interviewed 86 offenders, identifying 15 recommendations for improvement. Issues included poor organization and difficulty in enforcing sentences, as offenders with chaotic lives and substance abuse issues often failed to attend. The report praised some high-quality work and positive offender attitudes but criticized the general lack of focus on enforcing sentences. Recommendations included reducing rejections of offenders who report on time and tailoring work objectives to offenders' circumstances. The chief inspector emphasized the need for urgent action, while the Ministry of Justice expressed commitment to improving rehabilitation and ensuring offenders attend work.

The passage discusses a newspaper headline criticizing a comedian, Brand, as a hypocrite for advocating for economic and political change for the poor while living in a luxurious home. This accusation is not new, and Brand has addressed it before, explaining that he acknowledges his wealth and the criticism but believes in personal and systemic change. He argues that his wealth does not negate the need for addressing inequality and ecological issues, and he has not taken legal action against the newspaper despite the allegations.

Dr. Craig Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur, transformed the mapping of the human genome into a competitive race, which led to criticism from the scientific community. Despite being seen as arrogant and not modest about his achievements, his efforts significantly accelerated the genome sequencing process. After completing the human genome, he focused on creating synthetic life, leading to the development of "Synthia," an organism published in the journal Science. Venter's early life included a lack of academic success, military service in Vietnam, and a shift towards medicine. His innovative approaches in molecular biology, including using RNA to decode genes, led to significant scientific advancements. He left the NIH in 1992 to establish a private research institute and later formed Celera Genomics to sequence the human genome in three years. His work, though controversial, allowed him to fund his research independently. In 2006, he founded the J Craig Venter Institute to create synthetic life and also conducted oceanic research to study marine microbes. He envisions synthetic microbes contributing to environmental solutions and industrial advancements.

Researchers found that most children in England who ate school lunches tried new foods at school that they hadn't tried at home. Half of the parents surveyed wanted these foods to be available at home. The survey of 1,000 parents showed that carrots, sweetcorn, and peas were the most popular vegetables, while aubergine, chickpeas, and spinach were least popular. School meals in England now follow strict nutritional guidelines, and about 40% of primary school children eat school lunches, slightly more than in secondary schools. More children in Scotland eat school lunches, with about 46%. The study was conducted online and was commissioned by England's School Food Trust following concerns about children's eating habits.

Morata, a 23-year-old Spanish striker, joined Juventus in 2014 after four seasons with Real Madrid. His transfer included an option for Real to buy him back for up to 30 million euros. Morata, who has previously been linked with Arsenal and Chelsea, scored three goals for Spain at Euro 2016. At Juventus, he scored 27 goals in two years, winning two Serie A titles and two Coppa Italias. He participated in back-to-back Champions League finals, scoring in Juventus' 2015 defeat to Barcelona. Morata, who made his Real Madrid debut at 18, scored 10 goals for the club.

Wilson rejoined Forest from Celtic for £2.5m in August 2013 but has since been without a team after being released in May. At 30, he made 51 appearances in his second spell at Forest, following a four-season stint there before moving to Celtic. He has also played for Preston North End and Notts County.

Tesco, the world's third largest retailer, is exiting its loss-making US food chain, Fresh & Easy, by transferring 4,000 of its 5,000 employees to a new business led by Yucaipa, a private equity firm. The deal involves a £80m loan from Tesco to the new business, with 50 stores set to close. Tesco will spend £150m to dispose of the brand, with potential for repayment and a future stake if Yucaipa's business becomes profitable. This move comes after Tesco reported its first annual profit decline in 20 years.

The passage describes an athlete who faced racial abuse but overcame it, considered representing France, and is now aiming for a medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics. It also mentions a guide for getting into martial arts.

In the late 1960s/early 1970s, the ice fields in the French Alps covered about 375 sq km, but by the late 2000s, this had decreased to 275 sq km, representing a 26% loss over 40 years. The new glacier inventory, conducted by Marie Gardent and colleagues, assessed around 600 glaciers in the French Alps, using map archives, satellite imagery, and aerial photographs, with manual checks to improve accuracy. The retreat is not uniform, with greater losses in the southern sectors, such as the Belledonne and Ecrins massifs, compared to the northern areas like the Mont Blanc Massif. The northern region has more precipitation and cloud cover, which may contribute to slower glacier retreat. The largest French glacier, La Mer de Glace, has slightly decreased in area since the 1970s. These findings align with similar observations of glacier retreat in other Alpine regions.

The Scottish women's football team is in a strong position to qualify for the upcoming finals, having won all five qualifiers so far. They face Iceland in a crucial match, with a win likely securing their place. The team, including players like Kim Little, who plays in the US, and others in top leagues in Germany, England, and Sweden, aims to reach the finals for the first time. The outcome of the matches against Iceland will determine the group winner, with the top six teams qualifying automatically. The team is focused on reaching the finals, which is a long-standing goal for many players, and they believe playing in top leagues abroad enhances their performance and competitiveness.

Stuart Campbell, a Scottish independence blogger, was arrested in the west of England on a harassment complaint from a woman in south London, alleging online harassment over two years. Campbell, who was released on bail until mid-September, denied the allegations, claiming the media was using "innuendo" to provoke speculation. He stated the allegations concerned some tweets, which he insists are not threatening and remain publicly visible. A police spokesman confirmed an investigation is underway.

The passage discusses a proposal by People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals (Peta) to replace the Jolly Fisherman mascot, associated with Skegness, with a modern, animal-friendly image of a fish and the slogan "Skegness - A Happy Plaice." Peta argues that the Jolly Fisherman symbolizes animal cruelty, referencing traditional fishing practices. The original Jolly Fisherman poster, commissioned in 1908 by the Great Northern Railway, is a beloved symbol of Skegness. The mayor of Skegness, Carl Macey, expressed that while animal cruelty is not something the town wants to associate with, he believes the Jolly Fisherman is loved and does not represent cruelty. He mentioned that Peta's suggestion would be considered by the council, but if the current mascot is not broken, there is no need to change it.

The passage describes a rugby match between Scotland and Georgia. Scotland took an early lead with tries from Tommy Seymour, a penalty try, Sean Maitland, and Stuart Hogg, with Greig Laidlaw converting all of them. Hamish Watson extended the lead after half-time, and Hogg scored again with a counter-attack. Georgia scored a try through Vasil Lobzhanidze, but Scotland continued to dominate with more tries, including one from Watson. Georgia managed a second try through Lobzhanidze after a scrum error. Scotland's coach, Vern Cotter, praised the team's performance, highlighting their possession and counter-attacks. The match ended with Scotland winning decisively.

In this rugby match, Widnes secured a 38-26 victory over Castleford. Widnes took a 14-6 half-time lead with tries from Macgraff Leuluai, Ah Van, and Chris Bridge. Despite a late surge from Castleford, including three tries in four minutes from Larne Patrick, Luke Gale, and Paddy Flynn (on loan from Widnes), Widnes held on to win. The victory moved Widnes above Wakefield into seventh place, while Castleford remained in sixth. Key players for Widnes included Ah Van, Lloyd White (2 tries), and Joe Mellor, while Castleford's players included Paddy Flynn, Larne Patrick, and Luke Gale. The match was refereed by J Smith.

Fawzi al-Odah, a 37-year-old detainee at Guantanamo Bay, was released after a US review panel determined he was not a "continuing significant threat." He had been held since 2002 following his arrest in Pakistan on suspicion of ties to al-Qaeda and the Taliban, which he denies. His release came after a July decision by Guantanamo's Periodic Review Board. Although he is now free, he must spend at least a year at a militant rehabilitation center in Kuwait. This marks the first release since May, when five Taliban detainees were exchanged for US soldier Bowe Bergdahl. His release reduces the total number of detainees at Guantanamo to 148. The facility, opened in January 2002, remains a subject of controversy, with President Barack Obama having pledged to close it.

Anzac Day commemorates the first major battle involving Australian and New Zealand forces during World War One, specifically the Gallipoli landings. On this day, thousands attended a dawn service at Hyde Park Corner, with up to 400 people participating in a parade before a wreath-laying ceremony at the Cenotaph. Services were also held at Westminster Abbey, where the national anthems of New Zealand and Australia were sung. The day marks an important moment for expatriate and visiting Australians and New Zealanders to honor the sacrifices of their countrymen and women in all wars. Alexander Downer, the Australian high commissioner to the UK, addressed the crowds, reflecting on the bravery and heroism of the Anzac troops. The ceremony included prayers read by schoolchildren and participation from members of veterans' associations, service personnel, and their families. The Gallipoli campaign, which lasted eight months, was one of the bloodiest of the war and aimed to force the Ottoman Empire out of the war.

Clarkson, 30, has joined Premiership Well for a second spell and may debut for St Mirren in the Championship against Alloa. He scored nine goals at Dundee last season and has mainly played as a substitute this term. Clarkson is fit and ready for the game, having maintained his match fitness through training and playing for the U20s. He has made nearly 400 senior club appearances and has represented Scotland twice with one goal. St Mirren are currently eighth in the Championship, seven points above Alloa. Clarkson expressed his eagerness to contribute to the team's success and help push the club up the table.

The turkey firm Bernard Matthews was sold to food tycoon Ranjit Boparan. Concerns were raised about the impact on existing workers' pension schemes, but Unite, the union representing the workers, confirmed that all current agreements would be honored. The Bernard Matthews final salary pension scheme, which was closed in 2004, is no longer in effect, and members are under an alternative scheme unaffected by the takeover. Boparan Private Office confirmed that current pension arrangements would continue under new ownership. Unite's Steve Harley met with Boparan's representatives and was assured that the new owner aims to restore Bernard Matthews to its former profitable status through increased investment, cost savings, and utilizing existing spare capacity to process chicken and not just turkeys.

The passage discusses issues with a new chain ferry service in Cowes. The council leader, Dave Stewart, announced that the ferry crossing would be free until 2 July to address problems and gather feedback. The ferry, which launched on 14 May, has faced multiple issues including breakdowns, running aground, and suspension due to training problems. Cars have also been damaged. Local businesses, like Valu-4-U, are suffering from lost trade. Compensation for damaged cars and businesses is under discussion. The council has ordered an audit and authorized ramp extensions to fix vehicle scraping issues. The councillor noted that the ferry is a prototype with expected teething problems, which are being addressed.

The passage discusses the implications of Brexit on the UK fishing industry. It highlights concerns that Brexit could lead to EU-registered boats fishing in UK waters as part of trade deals, and that fishing communities may be marginalised in Brexit negotiations. The EU's Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) has been unpopular in the UK due to its quotas and equal access rules, which many in the industry believe have harmed British interests. Despite these concerns, some argue Brexit offers the chance for the UK to regain control over its waters and become a leading fish-exporting nation, similar to Norway. The House of Lords report warns that while the fishing industry is small in economic terms, it must not be overlooked in Brexit negotiations. The report also notes the complexity of managing shared fish stocks and the importance of maintaining market access, which may require trade-offs. The report suggests retaining elements of the CFP post-Brexit and continuing cooperation with neighboring states. Although there are concerns about potential fragmentation of fisheries management across the UK, some in the industry remain optimistic about Brexit's opportunities. Recent EU quota announcements have been seen as positive developments for the UK fishing sector.

Timothy Geaney admitted to downloading or allowing the taking of images of young boys in erotic poses between 2004 and 2014. He received a community payback order, was placed on the sex offenders register, and was removed from the teaching register after a hearing by the General Teaching Council Scotland. The panel found his actions to be incompatible with being a teacher, noting a pattern of behavior over a long period with no remedial action. They concluded there was a strong likelihood of recurrence and deemed him unfit to teach, prohibiting him from re-registering for two years.

A fire occurred on 2 March at a site on Duncan Street, leading to several days of firefighter efforts and disruptions to train services. The Environment Agency (EA) revoked the environmental permit of Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited, which operates the site, due to fire safety concerns. The company, managed by Asset and Land Group, was deemed "broadly compliant" with fire safety laws but faced enforcement action after the fire. The EA's decision to revoke the permit is subject to an appeal, with the revocation taking effect on 7 August. The cause of the fire remains undetermined.

Syria claims it is doing its best to comply with the timetable to destroy its chemical weapons, but missed a deadline to hand over its entire stockpile. Two shipments of weapons were attacked on the way to the port of Latakia, with the second shipment intercepted by terrorist groups. Syria denies using barrel bombs on civilians and accuses the US of supporting terrorists. Reports indicate civilian casualties from barrel bomb attacks in Aleppo. There are conflicting accounts regarding the control of Aleppo's central prison. Syria has about 1,300 tonnes of declared chemical weapons, with only 30 tonnes having left the country. The US expresses concern over the slow progress, while Russia urges Syria to complete the transfer by 1 March. The OPCW acknowledges security concerns have slowed the process. Syria asserts its commitment to fulfilling its obligations under the UN and OPCW.

In this passage, England secured a significant victory over Pakistan in a Test match at Old Trafford, leveling the series. England's score of 589-8 declared and 173-1 declared set up their second-largest win over Pakistan in terms of runs. Joe Root was named man of the match for his outstanding performances, scoring 254 in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 in the second, along with four catches and a wicket. Captain Alastair Cook praised Root's performance, calling it one of the best he had seen. The England team displayed strong batting, discipline, and bowling, according to former England batsman Geoffrey Boycott. Pakistan's performance was criticized, with their captain Misbah-ul-Haq acknowledging a lack of confidence and poor shot selection as key issues. The series is expected to remain tight, with the third Test scheduled for August 3. Pakistan will play a two-day tour game against Worcestershire before the next Test.

Sarah Rochira, the Older People's Commissioner for Wales, is conducting a review to assess the quality of life and care for older people in residential care. She is seeking input from pensioners, their families, and friends to gather experiences, which will inform recommendations for care providers and public bodies. Rochira aims to highlight both positive and negative aspects of care, emphasizing the importance of older people's voices in shaping care standards. The review will examine factors such as health, social relationships, and the care home environment, and will involve consultations with care providers, staff, and public bodies. Mario Kreft from Care Forum Wales supports the review's goals but expresses concern that the advisory panel lacks representation from care home providers, which he believes limits full sector engagement.

Paul Sheerin, a former Aberdeen midfielder, has been appointed as the new manager of Arbroath, replacing Neil Cooper. Sheerin, 39, has been the player-manager at Arbroath since 2010. He previously played for several Scottish clubs and Östersunds in Sweden, and earned a Scotland Under-21 cap in the mid-1990s. Sheerin led Arbroath to their first national trophy by winning the Scottish Third Division title and securing promotion in 2011. Arbroath was relegated to Scottish League Two after finishing bottom of League One in the 2013-14 season. Aberdeen's chief executive, Duncan Fraser, stated that Derek McInnes chose Sheerin after a comprehensive process, and Arbroath chairman John Christison was appreciative of Sheerin's desire to return to Aberdeen.

Curtis and assistant manager Paul Williams will manage Swansea's match against Bournemouth following Bob Bradley's dismissal. Swansea aims to appoint a new manager quickly, with Paul Clement as their top choice. Curtis believes the club has lost its identity since Michael Laudrup left in 2014, citing frequent managerial changes and player losses. Despite these challenges, Curtis is confident the current squad can avoid relegation, emphasizing the importance of staying up for the club and the local area. Swansea was promoted to the Premier League in 2011 after a remarkable rise from near bankruptcy and almost being relegated in 2003. Curtis also reminds new signings of the club's history through the documentary "Jack to a King."

Dr. Craig Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur, transformed the mapping of the human genome into a competitive race, which led to criticism from the scientific community. Despite being criticized for his methods and lack of modesty, his work significantly accelerated the genome sequencing process. After publishing the human genome, he focused on creating synthetic life, leading to the development of "Synthia," a synthetic organism. Venter's early life included military service in Vietnam, which inspired his determination to become a doctor and his sense of urgency. His innovations in genetic research, including the use of RNA to decode genes, led to significant scientific achievements and the establishment of private research institutes. His work in synthetic biology aims to create new industrial and environmental applications, such as using synthetic microbes to reduce reliance on oil and capture carbon dioxide.

The passage discusses concerns about the quality and quantity of apprenticeships in England compared to other European countries like Germany. The Sutton Trust reports that many apprenticeships are low quality and too short, with fewer than 200,000 rated at level three (equivalent to A-levels) annually. It highlights that only 20% of employers in England offer apprenticeships, compared to 51% in Germany. The report calls for expanding apprenticeships to 300,000 new starts annually, with a focus on level three and higher qualifications. It also warns that over half of apprenticeships since 2010 have been below level three, and many are aimed at older workers. The report emphasizes the need for a clear, respected vocational system to improve social mobility and economic competitiveness. The Department for Education states that apprenticeships are being reformed to improve standards, and a spokeswoman notes that over a million people have become apprentices since 2010.

The passage describes British Paralympian Sarah Storey winning a race in Nottwil, Switzerland, finishing over two minutes ahead of Anna Harkowska. Storey, who is targeting further Paralympic success in Rio, is Britain's most decorated female Paralympian with 22 medals. She has achieved 11 gold, eight silver, and three bronze medals across cycling and swimming in six Paralympics. Storey, who began her career in swimming at the 1992 Paralympics, switched to cycling in 2005 and has won 21 world titles. She aims to win her 17th title in the upcoming road race.

The passage discusses the financial and administrative issues that led to Hereford United's expulsion from the Conference Premier. Despite a dramatic final-day escape, the club failed to meet financial obligations, including debts to creditors and unpaid wages. The Conference extended payment deadlines multiple times, but Hereford could not meet the final deadline. As a result, the club was expelled, and Chester City, which had been relegated earlier, was reinstated. The situation has left fans and players deeply affected, with the club's financial struggles exacerbated by declining attendances since their relegation in 2012.

The passage summarizes the career of a 30-year-old former Manchester City player who earned 61 caps for England after his senior debut in 2009. He participated in two World Cups and two European Championships but only played three minutes at Euro 2016. The player, Sam Milner, expressed support for his former manager, Sam Allardyce, and his team. Milner also holds the record for the most capped England Under-21 player with 46 caps, and he scored his only international goal in a 5-0 victory over Moldova during the 2014 FIFA World Cup qualifiers.

Christopher Hogwood, a prominent figure in the early-music movement, passed away at his home in Cambridge after an illness. His funeral will be private, with a memorial service planned later. Hogwood was a founding member of the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) in 1973, which he directed for 30 years across six continents. The AAM produced over 200 CDs, including a complete cycle of Mozart symphonies on period instruments. Notable recordings include the 1980 Handel's Messiah with Emma Kirkby and Carolyn Watkinson, which was recognized as one of the top 20 recordings of all time. Hogwood studied with several renowned musicians and held various positions, including being a keyboard player and musicologist with the Academy of Saint Martin-in-the-Fields and a founder member of the Early Music Consort of London. He was also involved in several festivals and held academic positions at universities in the UK and the US. Colleagues and friends praised his generosity, intellect, and contributions to the field of historically informed music.

A boy from Northern Ireland is unable to attend mainstream school due to difficulties coping, and his family is waiting for a place at a special school. All special schools in the South Eastern Education Board area are full, and no time frame has been given for availability. The boy's mother expressed concern about his isolation and the strain on the special needs school system. An extra classroom assistant has been hired at a local special school, with hopes that the boy will start soon. The Education Authority stated they cannot comment on individual cases but are reviewing the need for special school places in Northern Ireland to ensure availability closer to where children live, with efforts ongoing for implementation from 2016.

Newport County FC, along with Newport RFC and Newport Squash Club, are tenants at Rodney Parade stadium, which is subject to a potential takeover by the Welsh Rugby Union (WRU). The WRU aims to use the stadium as a rugby venue, but Newport County has a lease agreement that grants them priority for fixtures until 2023. The WRU's takeover bid will be decided by a shareholder vote in early May. Newport County, currently two points above relegation in League Two, hopes to secure survival with a win and a loss by their rivals. The WRU's plan to install an artificial pitch conflicts with Football League rules, and the club's chairman has emphasized that current agreements protect all tenants at Rodney Parade.

The passage describes the journey of an individual who was kidnapped by rebels during the civil war in Sierra Leone and subjected to brutal treatment. After escaping and facing challenges in the capital, he found hope through a preacher's initiative, which encouraged him to pursue education and contribute to rebuilding his nation. During the Ebola outbreak in 2014, he and others took initiative to educate communities, provide support, and establish an Ebola treatment unit, saving many lives. The individual now sees himself as a changed person, focusing on investing in young people to shape a better future. The passage also mentions the significant number of deaths caused by the virus across several countries.

A public fundraising campaign successfully raised enough money to prevent the auction of a valuable collection of art, ceramics, manuscripts, letters, and photographs, which were at risk of being sold to pay off a pension debt. The collection will remain on display at the Wedgwood Museum in Barlaston, Staffordshire, after being gifted by The Art Fund to the Victoria and Albert Museum. The collection's preservation was crucial to maintaining a significant part of Britain's cultural heritage.

Dan Groves mentioned that details about a potential deal allowing Wright to buy 20% of Billericay are not yet finalized. Wright, a 30-year-old who was a contestant on I'm A Celebrity Get Me Out Of Here in 2011, is set to become a club director. Billericay, currently eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, are three points away from a play-off spot. The club has been acquired by Glenn Tamplin, a multi-millionaire who is willing to invest £10,000 weekly. Additionally, Billericay signed former England international Paul Konchesky in March.

The passage describes a football match between Blackpool and Colchester United, which ended in a 1-1 draw. Blackpool took the lead in the 12th minute through Jamille Matt, who scored from a chip-in by Nathan Delfouneso. Colchester equalized through Kurtis Guthrie in the 17th minute following a corner. Blackpool had several chances but failed to score, including a missed header by Tom Aldred. Colchester finished the game with 10 men after substitute Sean Murray received a red card for a bad tackle in injury time. The match ended with both teams having equal points.

The disused Fawley power station chimney, which is 198 metres high, will be the tallest attraction south of London's Shard. The site, which was a 2,000 megawatt oil-fired power station commissioned in 1971, closed in 2013 after over 40 years of operation. The developers, Fawley Waterside, plan to transform the 300-acre site into a £1bn "merchant city" development featuring a marina, housing, restaurants, and fast ferry links to Southampton and Portsmouth. The development will include a petal-shaped glass structure at the centre, with the chimney serving as a signature feature. The application for outline planning permission is due later this year, with construction potentially starting in 2018. The chimney, which powered one million homes, is to be preserved as a key part of the project.

The passage reports on the results of the Hong Kong Championships for British cyclists. 23-year-old Latham won a bronze medal in the men's scratch event, earning GB's second medal of the championships.  In the men's team pursuit, GB finished fifth.  Elinor Barker, a gold medallist at the Olympics, competed in the women's team pursuit but the team failed to medal.  Several other British cyclists competed in various events, with some facing early exits.  Quotes from various athletes and coaches highlight the competitive nature of the event and the potential for future success.

In 2012, actor Ross Kemp, who previously played Grant Mitchell in EastEnders from 1990-1999 and again in 2005-2006, returned for Barbara's final episodes. His character, Grant Mitchell, reunited with his brother Phil and mother Peggy for the last time. Peggy's return was announced after her initial exit in 2010, and she revealed her cancer had returned. The storyline culminated in Peggy's death, which would be shown in spring 2012. The return of Grant Mitchell, a memorable EastEnders character, was seen as an opportunity to showcase Ross Kemp and Steve McFadden's talents.

Sadio Mane scored twice within 138 seconds as second-placed Tottenham Hotspur struggled against Liverpool at Anfield. Manager Mauricio Pochettino criticized his team's lack of desire and performance, noting their poor away record against top-six teams. He warned that a potential 12-point lead by Chelsea would be a significant challenge. Former player Danny Murphy highlighted Tottenham's inconsistency away from home, suggesting they should maintain their back-three formation against strong opposition.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 of 28 governor posts in Nigeria's elections, marking a significant defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP), which lost control of key northern states and the oil-rich Adamawa state. The PDP retained only eight governorships, mainly in the southeast and oil-rich Niger Delta. APC leader Muhammadu Buhari will be inaugurated as president on 29 May, after defeating President Goodluck Jonathan. The PDP's decline is attributed to corruption allegations, failure to address insurgency, and loss of support to the APC. The APC failed to gain control of any of Nigeria's five oil-producing states, raising concerns for Buhari regarding oil production and revenue. Elections were peaceful overall, with some violence reported in southern states. The PDP is expected to undergo a period of rebuilding under a new leader.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival (HebCelt) is taking place in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis from 19 to 22 July. Visitors can use an app to access online information, videos, and band interviews from signs and posters on-site. The festival features artists like The Waterboys, Imelda May, and Skerryvore. HebCelt director Caroline Maclennan introduced an augmented reality experience to enhance the festival experience and allow global participation, with updated messages providing access to information, interviews, and ticket purchases.

The passage discusses the termination of funding agreements for several Birmingham schools, including Park View and Nansen Primary, which were rated inadequate by Ofsted. These schools are part of a broader investigation into alleged issues of discrimination and a narrow, faith-based ideology. Education Minister Lord Nash has raised concerns about the management of these schools, particularly regarding the promotion of spiritual, moral, social, and cultural development. The schools have been criticized for failing to address issues such as segregation, curriculum balance, and the vetting of external speakers. The Park View Educational Trust has indicated they will challenge the Ofsted report and may be removed from running the schools. The Department for Education will decide the future of the schools. Parents and staff have criticized Ofsted's findings, claiming bias and that the reports are being used to push personal agendas.

Vincent Barker, known as Vinnie, died in July 2012, five months after a routine eye test at Boots in Ipswich. The prosecution claims that the conduct of eye specialist Honey Rose was so below the expected standard that it was "criminal," leading to Vinnie's death. Ms Rose denies the charge of gross negligence manslaughter. The prosecution argues that her failure to detect Vinnie's swollen optic discs and refer him for further investigation was the key issue, as it led to a build-up of fluid in his brain, increasing skull pressure and causing his death. The case is ongoing.

Clive Weatherhogg, 42, was found guilty of coercing a woman into engaging in sexual activity with a man he arranged through an adult website, and of sending explicit material to the woman's sister and father. He was placed on the sex offenders register and his case was remitted to the High Court for sentencing due to its greater powers. The woman described feeling "blackmailed" by Weatherhogg, and the judge emphasized the need for a sentence that reflects society's abhorrence of his conduct. Weatherhogg, a first-time offender, was assessed as posing a moderate risk of re-offending.

In a T20 match between Ireland and Afghanistan in Greater Noida, Ireland scored 165-5, with Stuart Thompson (56), Gary Wilson (41 no), and William Porterfield (39) contributing significantly. Afghanistan chased down the target, reaching 171-4 with two overs remaining, thanks to Samiullah Shenwari (56) and Mohammad Shahzad (47). The sides are set to play again in the second T20 at the same venue on Friday. Ireland faced early challenges with Paul Stirling's dismissal and the loss of Boyd Rankin due to a back injury, though Rankin is expected to return for the ODIs starting on 15 March. Afghanistan's Amir Hamza took 2-23, and Shahzad and Najeeb Tarakai formed a 51-run partnership. Porterfield noted Ireland's potential to score higher and acknowledged shortcomings in their bowling performance.

FC Barcelona denied any wrongdoing in relation to tax obligations connected to the signing of Neymar, stating that they had paid £48.6m for the player, with his parents receiving £34m of the fee. The club emphasized that the total cost of Neymar, including other contracts, reached £106.8m. Barcelona's former president, Sandro Rosell, resigned amid accusations of misappropriating funds and is under investigation. A Spanish judge ruled there was enough evidence to continue the investigation. Barcelona made a complimentary tax declaration of 13,550,830.56 euros to address potential interpretations of tax responsibility, while maintaining that their original payment was in line with fiscal obligations. Neymar has contributed seven goals in 18 league appearances and three in seven Champions League matches for the club.

On 15 September, the bodies of David Miller and Hannah Witheridge were found on a beach in Koh Tao. UK detectives, who had been working with Thai police, have completed their investigation and will return to the UK to compile a report and update the families. Two Burmese suspects, Zaw Lin and Win Zaw Htun, are alleged to have confessed to the murders, though Thai police denied reports of them withdrawing their confessions. They face charges of conspiracy to murder, rape, and robbery, with the possibility of the death penalty. The UK expressed concerns about the investigation, particularly regarding DNA verification and allegations of mistreatment. Post-mortem examinations indicated that Miller died from drowning and a head injury, while Witheridge died from head wounds. DNA evidence linked the suspects to Witheridge.

The passage describes Scotland's women's football team in a crucial qualifier against Iceland, with a win potentially securing their place in the finals. The team is determined to avoid missing out on major competitions after previous heartbreaks. Iceland, ranked higher, is also unbeaten, and the outcome of the two matches between the teams will determine the group winner. Scotland is in a strong position to qualify without needing a play-off, as the top six group runners-up also qualify. The team includes players who compete in top leagues abroad, such as Bayern Munich, which they believe benefits the national team. The players emphasize the importance of fans' support and the positive impact of playing in competitive leagues on their development.

The passage discusses Apple's implementation of a two-step verification system for iCloud, aimed at preventing unauthorized access following reports of celebrities' intimate photos being stolen via third-party software like Elcomsoft's Phone Password Breaker. The new security measure requires users to enter a four-digit code via a trusted device or app when logging in from an unfamiliar device, with a recovery key as a backup. While the system is an opt-in feature, experts suggest it should be the default to enhance security. Elcomsoft's owner acknowledges the new measures as secure but expresses concerns about the recovery key's vulnerability. Security experts argue that two-factor authentication should be the default setting, not just a recommendation, to better protect user accounts against cyber threats. Apple has committed to encouraging users to enable two-factor authentication and use stronger passwords.

UKIP spent the most on their campaign, £2,956,737, followed by the Conservatives with £2,980,815. The Lib Dems spent £1,580,575 and lost all but one of their MEPs, while Labour spent £1,027,339 and came second. The Green Party spent £534,249, and the SNP spent £267,372. The total spent by the six highest-spending parties was £9,347,087. Campaign spending per vote varied, with UKIP at 68p, Labour at 26p, Conservatives at 79p, and the Lib Dems at £1.45. The figures cover the period from 23 January to 22 May. All parties except Labour spent more than they did in the 2009 European election campaign.

Centre-back Anderson, 27, has mutually cancelled his contract with Barrow to join their National League rivals. He may play against his former club on 18 February. Striker Keating, 21, is set to join after being recommended by Micky Adams. Keating has previously played for several clubs and his transfer is pending international clearance. Gulls manager Kevin Nicholson praised Anderson's leadership qualities and Keating's hunger for success. The Gulls are four points above the relegation zone but have only won one of their last six games.

A 10-year-old Irish-bred horse named Many Clouds collapsed and later died after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day. Veterinary staff confirmed the cause of death was a severe pulmonary haemorrhage. Despite having no significant underlying health issues, the horse had a history of post-race ataxia and overheating, which raised questions about its connection to the haemorrhage. The British Horseracing Authority emphasized the rarity of such incidents and the need for further understanding to prevent them. Many Clouds had previously won notable races, including the Hennessy Gold Cup in 2014 and the Gold Cup trial in 2015.

The passage describes the emotional farewells of several Scottish politicians as they step down from their roles as MSPs ahead of the May 5 election. Presiding officer Tricia Marwick was moved to tears by the speeches of Duncan McNeil and Alex Salmond. Salmond, former First Minister, emphasized Scotland's unity and diversity, and highlighted the need for Holyrood to take greater responsibility for governance. He also noted the transfer of powers under the Scotland Bill, while expressing disappointment that it did not fully meet previous promises. McNeil warned that Holyrood should learn from Westminster, particularly regarding accountability and scrutiny. Annabel Goldie, a Conservative MSP, humorously reflected on her time in office.

The passage describes the casting and production details of the live-action film adaptation of Beauty and the Beast. Emma Watson is cast as Belle, Dan Stevens as the Beast, and Luke Evans as Gaston. Kevin Kline plays Maurice, and Josh Gad portrays LeFou. The film is directed by Bill Condon and is set for release on 17 March 2017, with filming beginning at Shepperton Studios in May.

The Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) will meet with victims' relatives to disclose its decisions regarding potential charges against 23 suspects linked to the 1989 Hillsborough disaster. Ninety-six fans died in the incident, and new inquests concluded the deaths were unlawful. Evidence was referred to the CPS in January, with 15 cases related to the disaster's causes and eight to police conduct investigations. Relatives, including Margaret Aspinall, are awaiting the outcomes, expressing hope for accountability and a resolution to their long struggle.

Chelmsford Prison has experienced multiple incidents of packages being thrown over its walls, according to residents and a former inmate, who noted the jail is known for receiving mobile phones and synthetic cannabis. The Ministry of Justice acknowledged the challenge, stating staff work hard to prevent contraband but more needs to be done. A local woman reported witnessing packages thrown over the wall multiple times and mentioned the prison's efforts to address the issue. While a former inmate claimed drones were used to transport contraband, the Ministry stated there is no evidence of drones entering the facility. Laws now allow for up to two years in jail for those caught smuggling packages over prison walls.

Sylvia Blackburn, a 72-year-old lollipop lady, suffered serious head injuries in a collision with Brian Wright's car outside Bedford Road Lower School in December. Wright, 55, admitted hitting Blackburn but denies causing serious injury through dangerous driving, claiming he was blinded by the setting sun. The incident occurred when Blackburn, wearing appropriate clothing, stepped out to escort a woman and her daughter across the road. Wright's VW Golf failed to stop at a red light. The court heard that the sun was 10 minutes from setting and could have been shining into Wright's eyes. Judge Michael Kay QC paused the case for five minutes as Wright composed himself. Wright expressed remorse for his actions and their impact on Blackburn and her family. The trial continues.

The passage discusses Scottish middle-distance runner Eilidh Muir's decision to prioritize her final year of veterinary medicine studies over competing in the Commonwealth Games in April. Muir, who finished fourth and sixth in the 1500m and 5,000m at the World Athletics Championships, will not be with the Scotland team at the event due to her academic commitments. She plans to return to university next week and will have a busy schedule with her studies. Despite missing the Commonwealth Games, Muir expresses her love for representing Scotland and confidence in the team's performance. She also mentions her potential for future Olympic participation and her interest in the World Indoor Championships. Muir achieved a new outdoor personal best in the 5,000m, finishing second behind Hellen Obiri.

Trevor Deely, 22, was last seen walking home from a Christmas party in December 2000. A search in Chapelizod, Dublin, began on Saturday, involving excavations expected to take weeks. CCTV footage from the night he disappeared, enhanced with technology, shows him talking to a man in black outside his workplace. Detectives released the footage in April, appealing for the man's identification. The man was later seen on Haddington Road, but has not yet been identified.

Del Potro won against Wawrinka with a score of 3-6 6-3 7-6 (7-2) 6-3. He is ranked 165th and is in the same half of the draw as Andy Murray. Del Potro will next play either Lucas Pouille or Donald Young. Del Potro has been absent from Grand Slam events for over two years due to injuries and is now playing in his first Grand Slam since the Australian Open in 2014. He reached the Wimbledon semi-finals in 2013. Del Potro expressed his happiness after winning the match and mentioned that it is his second or third career victory after his injuries. Nick Kyrgios is also in the same half of the draw as Murray and is set to meet him in the last 16. Kyrgios defeated Dustin Brown in a long and rain-affected match. Feliciano Lopez will play Kyrgios in the third round, with the winner facing Murray or John Millman in the last 16. Tomas Berdych and Jo-Wilfried Tsonga also had routine victories in their matches.

Tunisia was initially expelled from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations (AfCON) but reconciled with the Confederation of African Football (CAF) after apologizing for complaints about referee selection during the 2015 Nations Cup. Morocco, on the other hand, was banned from participating in the 2017 AfCON qualifying draw but had their ban overturned by the Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS). Both nations are now preparing for the 2017 AfCON. Tunisia faced controversy during the 2015 AfCON when they were replaced as hosts due to fears of the Ebola virus, leading to a fine and eventual replacement by Equatorial Guinea. Tunisia's dispute with CAF was resolved through discussions with CAF president Issa Hayatou. Morocco's participation was affected by a previous ban due to their withdrawal as hosts in 2015, which was later reduced in fine. Tunisia is set to compete in Group A, while Morocco will be in Group F. If Tunisia reaches the 2017 finals, they would set a record for consecutive AfCON participations.

The passage discusses McLaren's historical success in Formula 1, including 182 race wins, 12 drivers' titles, and eight constructors' titles. Despite their past achievements, the team is currently struggling, with their best result being fourth in the championship grid. The current issues stem from the Honda power-unit, although the car itself is performing well. The team's decline began in 2013, and they have faced scandals, such as the 2007 technical information breach and the "lie-gate" incident. McLaren's history is marked by cycles of success and decline, with Ron Dennis playing a key role in their rise and management. Dennis believes the team is on the path to recovery and aims to challenge Mercedes' dominance. Fernando Alonso's return in 2015 was seen as a move to revive the team's fortunes, and the team remains hopeful for future success.

On 6 October 2014, paramedics were called to Joe's Bar in Dungiven after a sudden death. Police found people still present, and till receipts showed alcohol was served until 04:49 BST. The bar was ordered to close for three months. Colleen O'Neill and James Thomas, both from Kevin Lynch Park, were charged with allowing alcohol consumption outside licensing hours. The judge noted their "appalling record" and expressed concern about the lack of custodial sentencing power. O'Neill was fined £3,000, and Thomas was fined £1,000.

stephen curry set an nba record for most three-pointers in a season with 276, helping the golden state warriors defeat the portland trail blazers 116-105. curry scored 45 points and made eight three-pointers, while klay thompson contributed 26 points. the warriors avoided a three-game losing streak. lamarcus aldridge and damian lillard led the blazers with 27 and 20 points respectively. in another game, the chicago bulls beat the miami heat 89-78, with pau gasol leading the way with 16 points and 15 rebounds. derrick rose scored 12 points as he continued his comeback from injury.

Liverpool players Mario Balotelli, Fabio Borini, Rickie Lambert, and Lazar Markovic were surprised when YouTube star Bas van Velzen arrived at Melwood. They believed van Velzen was a competition winner who had earned a meeting with the players and a dead-ball masterclass. However, van Velzen, a free-kick specialist, showcased his skills in front of the team. Balotelli also demonstrated his free-kick ability, impressing the group. Van Velzen, known for his YouTube videos of free-kick exploits, wowed the Liverpool quartet. He later surprised Balotelli by unveiling his famous slogan, which Balotelli had worn during Manchester City's 6-1 win over United in October 2011.

Carriers of the BRCA1 gene, such as Angelina Jolie, can significantly reduce their risk of dying from breast cancer by having their ovaries removed after diagnosis. A study found that women with a BRCA1 mutation who underwent oophorectomy had a 62% decrease in breast cancer death risk compared to those who did not. The protective effect lasted up to 15 years. Oophorectomy also reduced overall mortality by 65%. The procedure was most effective when performed within two years of diagnosis, with a 73% reduction in death risk. The study highlighted the benefit for women with estrogen-receptor negative breast cancer. While the study focused on BRCA1 carriers, further research is needed for BRCA2 carriers. Angelina Jolie had a double mastectomy and oophorectomy due to her BRCA1 mutation, which increases lifetime breast and ovarian cancer risks to up to 70%. Genetic testing is available for BRCA1, BRCA2, TP53, and PTEN mutations, with BRCA mutations more common in Ashkenazi Jewish populations. Ovarian cancer is a severe threat for BRCA carriers, and oophorectomy is recommended as part of treatment discussions for early-stage breast cancer in BRCA mutation carriers.

A married couple, Derek Lowe, 38, and Tina Lowe, 33, were struck and killed by an Amtrak train on Easter Sunday morning in Durham, North Carolina. The accident occurred shortly before 10 am as they lingered on the tracks. The train, Amtrak No. 80 (the Carolinian), was traveling from Charlotte to New York City and the incident took place on property owned by Norfolk-Southern. None of the 166 passengers on the train were injured, although a man who fell ill during the delay received treatment. The train was delayed for about two hours and 45 minutes before continuing on its route. A man who met the couple while collecting scrap metal mentioned they may have lived in a homeless camp and expressed compassion for their situation. Durham is located about 25 miles northwest of Raleigh, and the usual travel time from Charlotte to New York City is approximately 13 hours and 30 minutes.

Carlos Toro, a former Medellin cartel member who worked as an undercover DEA informant for 27 years, is now facing deportation after retiring. Toro was promised U.S. citizenship in exchange for his cooperation but has not received it. He claims he would be killed if sent back to Colombia and has been living illegally in the U.S. since his health forced him to retire. The DEA refused to assist him with citizenship, and despite efforts by his former handler and colleagues, Toro remains in legal limbo, unable to collect social security benefits or travel without documents. He is prepared to go into hiding if necessary and expresses frustration over not receiving the promised citizenship.

The passage discusses a Canadian company, Vox Populi Registry Ltd., which registered the domain name ".sucks" to target celebrities and companies, charging high fees to remove their names. Celebrities like Kevin Spacey and companies such as YouTube, Visa, and Bank of America have paid to have their names removed from these domains. The U.S. body regulating internet addresses, ICANN, is investigating whether Vox Populi's actions are illegal. While ICANN initially approved the domain, it is now reconsidering due to complaints from industry groups. The advisory panel has called the domain a "shakedown scheme" and "predatory," suggesting that the threat of opening ".sucks" domains to the public is part of a coercive strategy. ICANN may take action if regulators determine the company's actions are illegal.

A mother of a stillborn baby boy was arrested 27 years after his body was found in a pond in Norfolk, England. The case was reopened during a periodical review, and DNA analysis eventually led police to identify the mother. She admitted to concealing her pregnancy and giving birth to the stillborn child in secret, then placing the baby in the pond. The body was exhumed, reburied, and given the name Peter after the local church. Police ruled out foul play and are considering charges of failing to register a birth and preventing a lawful burial. The case, which remained unsolved for 27 years, was closed after using DNA technology to identify the mother and confirm the circumstances of the baby's death.

A taxi driver, Michael Young, was ordered to pay compensation to passenger Kristopher Hicks, who suffered severe brain injuries after jumping from a moving taxi. Young mistakenly believed Hicks was planning to flee and drove him back to the taxi rank, leading to Hicks' injury when he jumped out at high speed. The High Court ruled that Young unlawfully imprisoned Hicks, entitling him to damages. The compensation is expected to be around 50% of the family's requested amount, with an additional £250 for unlawful imprisonment. Hicks now requires 24-hour care from his mother and has developed long-term health issues. Both parties have been granted permission to appeal the decision.

On Wednesday night, tornado sirens sounded in Kansas as multiple storms reported twisters, including one near Goddard, which missed Wichita but posed risks to other areas. Severe weather expert Chad Myers warned of dangerous nighttime tornadoes. Tornadoes were also reported in southwestern Kansas and in the town of Potosi, Missouri, where wind damage and flooding were observed. Unusual weather phenomena, including large hail, were reported in other areas. More storms are expected in the Midwest and surrounding regions on Thursday.

Luke Rockhold aims to dominate Lyoto Machida in their upcoming middleweight matchup in New Jersey, positioning himself as the "bull" while Machida is the "matador." Rockhold, seeking to extend his winning streak and earn a title shot, plans to cut off Machida's movement, control the fight, and exploit weaknesses in his style. Machida, confident in his ability to upset Rockhold, believes his technique and strategy can lead to victory and secure a title shot. Both fighters express mutual respect but are focused on showcasing their styles and achieving victory.

A light general aviation aircraft touched down on a runway without deploying its landing gear, resulting in a belly landing. The incident was captured in Fort Pierce, Florida, and the pilot, Chris Georgaklis, managed to take off again, despite damaged propellers and a high angle of attack. He flew 100 miles to Fort Lauderdale and landed safely. The FAA is investigating the incident, which is likely due to human error or a mechanical fault. The video maker described the event as shocking, noting the sound of the propellers hitting the runway and the pilot's quick response to regain control.

Manuel Pellegrini has expressed disappointment in Yaya Toure's performance this season but has pledged to support him until the end of the season. Toure, who is under contract with Manchester City until 2017, has faced criticism for his recent form, particularly in City's collapsed Premier League defense. Despite this, Pellegrini insists Toure is an important player and will not be forced out. Manchester City, currently in a poor run of form, may consider selling Toure in the summer, while also seeking to sign West Ham's Aaron Cresswell. Pellegrini has also retained the backing of the dressing room, despite facing questions about his own future. Meanwhile, West Ham manager Sam Allardyce has warned Cresswell not to make the same mistakes as other English players who moved to City without long-term success.

Domenico Rancadore, a Sicilian mafia fugitive known as the "Godfather of Uxbridge," was set to be extradited to Italy for a seven-year sentence from 1999 for mafia association.
