However, his case expired in October 2014, as Italian law states that a sentence is extinguished after more than double the time of the penalty has passed. Consequently, his European Arrest Warrant is to be withdrawn, allowing him to remain in the UK. The Italian Supreme Court will still review the case, but Rancadore's solicitor believes the Italian government will withdraw the warrant. The extradition process faced delays and legal challenges, including a judge's concern over his health and prison conditions in Italy. The case highlighted issues with the efficiency and trust in the extradition process between the UK and Italy.

The passage discusses the Grade One Celebration Chase at Sandown, where Mr Mole, ridden by AP McCoy, is one of three 7-2 co-favorites. Mr Mole, trained by Paul Nicholls, will compete against Irish Raider Special Tiara and Sprinter Sacre, ridden by Nico de Boinville. This race will be McCoy's last in a Grade One event, and his final rides for the day will be confirmed on Friday. Notably, McCoy announced his retirement after winning with Mr Mole at Newbury in February. Other competitors include Somersby, trained by Mick Channon.

The mother of Marcia Trimble Ritter, who was raped and choked to death by Jerome Sydney Barrett in 1975, has finally viewed crime scene photos of her daughter's body after decades of reluctance. Marcia's body was found 33 days after she disappeared, and her mother was initially advised against seeing the body or photos by her then-husband. Despite Barrett's conviction in 2009 for second-degree murder, Ritter had not seen the photos until she requested them from the lead investigator in 2023. Upon viewing the photos, she expressed deep emotional distress, describing the state of her daughter's body and vowing revenge. The case was Nashville's most notorious unsolved murder for 33 years before Barrett was convicted in 2009.

Rory McIlroy believes it is unthinkable that he will not win the Masters at some point to complete the career grand slam. He considers his 2011 final-round collapse at Augusta National, which led to a significant loss, as the most important day of his career. McIlroy is aiming to win his first Green Jacket and become one of only a few players to win all four major titles. Despite having only one top-10 finish in six Masters appearances, he remains confident in his ability to succeed at Augusta. McIlroy's recent successes include major titles in the U.S. Open, U.S. PGA, and The Open. He also acknowledges the challenges he faced, including personal and legal issues, and hopes to use Augusta as a sanctuary from the pressure.

The passage highlights various trending stories from the week, including four rainbows appearing after heavy rain in New York, the use of exotic dancers at wakes in rural China, RDJ's frustration during an interview, a new trend of lip plumping by sucking on a jar, a prom-posal referencing bombs, Ewan McGregor playing Lumiere in "Beauty and the Beast," Johnny Depp's appearance in the "Black Mass" trailer, and a unique way to announce pregnancy by referencing "The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air." These stories all trended online.

A new report reveals that 272 children in England were hospitalized due to fetal alcohol syndrome (FAS) last year, with experts warning the actual number could be much higher. Research suggests that at least one in 100 babies in the UK may suffer from learning, behavioral, and physical issues due to maternal alcohol consumption, equating to about 7,500 cases annually. The condition leads to lifelong disabilities, as seen in the case of Niamh Brown, a 15-year-old who requires assistance with daily tasks and has no sense of danger. Other health complications linked to prenatal alcohol exposure include liver, kidney, and heart problems, as well as cerebral palsy and epilepsy. While the government advises pregnant women to limit alcohol intake to two units twice a week, advocates suggest a complete abstinence from alcohol during pregnancy.

A 31-year-old ex-juvenile offender, Shaun Andrew McKerry, known as "Boomerang Boy," attempted to rob a store in Shildon, County Durham, with an axe. The shopkeeper, Sab Dhillon, tackled McKerry, causing him to fall and drop the axe. His wife, Sam Dhillon, hit McKerry twice with a baseball bat, helping to disarm him. McKerry was arrested by police and previously had convictions for various crimes, including shoplifting and burglary. He was jailed for six years after pleading guilty to attempted robbery.

Four Royal Navy sailors, charged with the gang rape of a young woman during an alcohol-fuelled party at a Canadian naval barracks, have been granted bail with conditions requiring them to stay in Nova Scotia until their trial. They must live at the Stadacona naval base in Halifax, surrender their passports, and continue working for the Royal Navy while their case is ongoing. The alleged incident occurred on April 10 after a hockey game at the Shearwater naval base. The sailors are charged with sexual assault, causing bodily harm, and group sexual assault, which could result in up to 14 years in prison. The Canadian authorities are handling the investigation, and the British High Commission is assisting. The case is set for a court hearing on May 27.

A mother, Valerie Jackson, from Las Vegas, is caring for her four-year-old son, RJ Jackson, who suffers from Netherton's syndrome, an extremely rare congenital skin disease that causes his skin to appear red, inflamed, and scaly. Despite her efforts to manage his condition with regular creams and moisturizers, RJ has faced misunderstanding and accusations of abuse from strangers, leading to an incident where armed police surrounded the family while they were shopping. Valerie expressed frustration over public ignorance and the cruel comments directed at her and her son, emphasizing that RJ is a beautiful and healthy child despite his appearance. Netherton's syndrome is a severe form of ichthyosis, with no known cure, and requires constant care to manage symptoms. The condition can be misdiagnosed due to its similarity to other skin issues, and it is believed to be genetic.

The passage discusses a controversy surrounding Protein World's controversial advertising campaign featuring a bikini-clad model named Renee Somerfield, which sparked backlash from feminists, body image campaigners, and social media users. The ads, which promoted the slogan "Are you beach body ready?" were displayed on London Underground trains and were criticized for promoting an unrealistic and sexist body image. A Change.org petition calling for the removal of the ads gained over 50,000 signatures. Transport for London (TFL) confirmed that the posters were being removed as they had reached the end of their three-week advertising period. The advertising standards authority received over 200 complaints about the ads. Protein World defended the campaign, claiming the image was unphotoshopped and that their goal was to encourage a healthier lifestyle. The controversy also led to threats against the company, including a bomb threat under investigation. Despite the backlash, Protein World stated they would not change their advertising methods. Meanwhile, sales of protein powder in the UK have been increasing.

Rail firms faced criticism for planning significant fare hikes, including up to 87% increases, just ten days after the general election, despite party leaders' pledges to freeze prices. Prime Minister David Cameron personally intervened, requesting First Great Western to urgently review its decision to nearly double fares on the London-Cotswolds route, which passes through his constituency. The proposed changes have angered constituents, with passengers facing a substantial increase from £33.30 to £62.40 for an off-peak return. Train companies can increase unregulated fares three times a year, and First Great Western cited the need to align the North Cotswolds route with other services. Other notable hikes include a 24.5% increase on an anytime return between Stafford and Liverpool and a 22% rise on a first-class day return from Manchester to Stoke. Virgin Rail defended its fare increases, stating that most affected fares are cheaper than rival options and that overall increases on the west coast are below the industry average.

Former soldier John Young, 66, was blinded in one eye after being hit by a brick thrown through his front door by thugs who had previously been throwing stones at his property in Oldham. The attack occurred three weeks after his marriage to Elaine, 54, and while they were writing thank you cards for wedding gifts. Despite emergency surgery, doctors could not save his eyesight. Police are investigating the incident, which they believe may have been a case of "yobs messing around" with no known motive. The couple, who have no children and met just 14 months ago, are now considering moving out of the area due to their fear for safety.

Tom Poynton, a 25-year-old Derbyshire wicketkeeper, has signed a one-year contract extension following a successful return from injury. He missed the entire 2014 season after sustaining leg injuries in a road accident that also claimed his father's life. After undergoing ankle surgery, Poynton made a comeback during Derbyshire's pre-season tour in Abu Dhabi. He will be available for the start of the season and is committed until the end of 2016. Derbyshire's elite performance director, Graeme Welch, praised Poynton's resilience and dedication, expressing confidence in his performance this summer.

A five-year-old boy named Harley Renshaw, from Stretford, was diagnosed with neuroblastoma, an aggressive form of cancer affecting nerve cells. He underwent 80 days of chemotherapy, an operation to remove his kidney tumor, a stem cell transplant, and radiotherapy at the Christie Clinic in Manchester. During his treatment, Harley created a Ninja Turtle mask to help him feel brave and strong. His story gained worldwide attention, and Nickelodeon sent him a box of Ninja Turtle presents for Christmas. After a year of battling cancer, Harley was declared cancer-free by doctors. His bravery earned him the Cancer Research UK's Little Star Award and made him the face of their Kids and Teens campaign. Harley's parents expressed their joy and hope for his future, including returning to school full-time. Regular check-ups will continue to monitor his health. Neuroblastoma is a rare cancer, affecting fewer than 100 children in the UK each year, and can spread to various parts of the body. Symptoms vary depending on the tumor's location.

Jack Grealish, a 19-year-old Aston Villa player, is currently at the center of a competition between the Republic of Ireland and England for his international future. Tim Sherwood, Villa's manager, emphasizes that Grealish should focus on his club career and continue to establish himself in the first team. Sherwood believes Grealish's confidence and skills have earned him international options, but the decision on which country to represent should be up to Grealish. His father, Kevin, supports this approach, urging Grealish to prioritize club football. Grealish is expected to make his choice by the end of the season, with a potential friendly match offering him the chance to play for both nations.

The passage discusses the high landing fees at airports for private jet travelers, highlighting that these fees can be extremely costly, with some airports in Japan, such as Haneda, charging up to £4,559 per landing. It notes that private jet travel is a growing trend, with significant numbers of flights recorded in the US and Europe, and that the market is worth trillions of dollars. The passage also mentions that popular events like the Super Bowl and the Monaco Grand Prix lead to increased demand and higher costs for private jet travel. Additionally, it lists several airports with the highest landing fees, noting that Japan has the three most expensive airports, followed by other international locations.

The passage describes a video of Cooper, a Labrador, eating an ice cream cone quickly at a McDonald's drive-thru, while his friend Daisy takes only a few licks. Katie Gallegos, who runs a dog resort, explains that Cooper always eats quickly, and Daisy gets only a few licks due to her smaller size. The video has been viewed over seven million times, with mixed reactions from viewers. Gallegos defends feeding the dogs ice cream, noting that Cooper is healthy and that she feeds Sammy, her late large breed dog, ice cream weekly. Another video shows the duo visiting Starbucks for a "pup-uccino," which is just whipped cream in a cup, with Cooper again taking the whole cup in one bite.

Gary Locke, the interim manager of Kilmarnock, has been appointed to the role permanently after signing a three-year deal. He previously served as an assistant manager under Allan Johnston and took charge of the team when his former teammate left in February. Since assuming control, Locke has lost only once in seven games. He will speak at a press conference on Friday, and the appointment was confirmed following his handshake with chairman Jim Mann.

A Florida mother, Jessica Kemp, has accused a school of threatening to suspend her five-year-old autistic son, Logan, due to the use of essential oils he wears to help manage his condition. The oils, manufactured by Doterra, have scents like lavender, chamomile, and sandalwood. Teachers at Seminole County Elementary claimed the oils were a distraction because of their smell. Kemp insists the oils help Logan stay calm and focused, and she continues to fight the school's decision despite the threat of punishment. The school later stated it would not suspend Logan, calling it a "health issue." Doterra has not yet commented on the situation.

A beach-side apartment complex in the Hamptons, known as the Sandpiper Complex, was completely destroyed by a fire on Wednesday afternoon. The fire, which started near a car parked by the complex, spread through 90 condos before the building collapsed. The blaze was so intense that it melted paint off nearby buildings and produced smoke visible from three miles away. Twelve fire crews attempted to control the fire but could not enter the building. Residents and the building manager lost everything, and the cause of the fire is under investigation. The complex is used as a holiday home between May and November.

The passage describes Queen Elizabeth II's continued passion for horseback riding despite her age and a knee injury. At 88, she enjoys riding her black fell pony, Carltonlima Emma, in the spring sunshine, preferring a silk scarf over a helmet. She has never worn a riding helmet, a habit that has persisted despite safety recommendations. The Queen has been an equestrian since childhood, starting with a Shetland pony named Peggy at age four. She breeds various horses and ponies, including fell ponies at Hampton Court. The fell pony, a breed with a long history in the UK, has been used for various purposes throughout history, including transportation and riding, and remains popular today.

A dispute between two Brisbane neighbors over noise levels turned fatal when 28-year-old Phillip Pama allegedly killed 55-year-old Leon Yeaman with a single punch during an argument. Yeaman was making noise in his yard at around 9 pm on Thursday night. Pama, who was asleep due to a 3 am shift, confronted Yeaman and hit him, leading to Yeaman's death at the scene. Pama was charged with manslaughter and granted conditional bail, with conditions including surrendering his passport, a curfew, and regular police check-ins. The case is set for a court hearing on May 18. Pama, described as a non-violent, married father of three, shielded his face from reporters and expressed grief over the incident. Neighbors and friends described Yeaman as generous but known for loud music and erratic behavior.

Yulia Simonova, a 52-year-old music teacher, planned to hire a hitman to torture and murder her 15-year-old ex-pupil, Damian Vanya, after he ended their relationship. She offered 100,000 rubles (£1,400) for the crime. Police conducted a sting operation, with an undercover officer posing as a hitman, and secretly filmed the exchange. Simonova ordered the hitman to inflict severe pain on Vanya, including breaking his arms and legs, causing him to bleed out, and then "finish" him. She was arrested after handing over some of the payment and faces 15 years in prison for attempted murder. Vanya expressed relief at the outcome, hoping Simonova would be imprisoned.

jose mourinho, chelsea's football manager, discusses his personal beliefs and family life. he prays daily but does not discuss football with his wife or pray about the game. he emphasizes separating his professional and family life, and he has a strong faith in god, though he does not attend church regularly. mourinho and his family have been involved with the word food programme to combat hunger. he acknowledges making mistakes in his professional life but considers himself a good person and family man. currently, chelsea is leading the league, and mourinho has faced fines for controversial comments. he also highlights his family's support and involvement in various events.

In this passage, it is mentioned that for the first time in eight years, TV legend Bob Barker returned to host "The Price Is Right." On the April 1 edition of the show, Barker, who had hosted the game show for 35 years before stepping down in 2007, took over the hosting duties for the first game, "Lucky Seven," before handing over to Drew Carey. Despite being away from the show for most of the past eight years, Barker did not seem to miss a beat.

An off-duty Secret Service agent, Arthur Baldwin, was arrested in Washington D.C. on Friday after attempting to break into a house. He was charged with attempted burglary and destruction of property. Baldwin, who was assigned to the foreign missions branch, was placed on leave and had his security clearance revoked. His arrest follows another incident involving a high-ranking supervisor accused of misconduct, and both cases are under investigation. The Secret Service faces ongoing scrutiny following a previous incident involving two officials driving into a secure White House area.

A freelance photographer, Atif Saeed, risked his life to capture images of a hungry lion from just 10 feet away at Lahore's safari park. Using only a camera, he approached the lion, lying on the ground and taking photos before the lion detected him through the camera's shutter sound. The encounter was intense, with the lion treating him like prey, and Saeed barely escaping to safety. He described the experience as a close and frightening encounter.

The passage describes the discovery of an unidentified woman's body in Brooklyn, New York, on March 22. She was found unconscious near Shore Parkway and 26th Avenue in the Gravesend section and later pronounced dead. Police have released images of a distinctive tattoo on her right leg, believed to be the name "Monique" within a heart and rose design. The woman, aged 25 to 45, had no identification, and authorities are seeking information to identify her. The cause of death is pending a medical examiner's report, and the public is urged to contact NYPD Crime Stoppers with any information.

A New Zealand couple, Hannah and Alex, built a self-sufficient two-bedroom home on the bed of a 1986 flatbed truck after returning from the UK in 2009. They constructed the solar-powered, wood and steel home over a year and a half, using a steel frame and gradually completing the project. The home, which includes stained glass windows, a wood-fired stove, and a gas-powered hot water system, is located on a lot in Nelson, surrounded by nature. The couple lives there with their cat, and the home costs approximately $25,000. They are nearly self-sufficient, with most electricity from solar panels and water from a nearby spring. They also plan to build another similar home in the future.

A study found that kindergarten children who shared iPads in class performed significantly better in early literacy tests compared to those who didn't use iPads or used them individually. Courtney Blackwell's research, involving 352 students, suggests that collaborative learning around the technology, rather than just collaboration itself, contributed to the improved performance. Shared iPad users scored about 30 points higher than other groups. The findings indicate that schools might reconsider how tablets are used, especially in early grades, to maximize their effectiveness. Blackwell plans to present her results at an international conference.

This passage describes a two-legged piglet, nicknamed "Super Pig," who has become an internet sensation due to a video showing it learning to walk on its front trotters. Born without back legs, the piglet demonstrates remarkable balance and has captured the hearts of many. It lives with its siblings, all of whom have four legs, and interacts happily with them. The piglet belongs to farmer Ms. Duan in Qionglai City, Sichuan Province, China, and has attracted many visitors. The piglet's story is similar to that of a two-legged rabbit in Liuzhou Zoo, which also became a popular attraction.

During the inaugural Indycar Grand Prix of Louisiana, Todd Phillips, a front-outside tire changer for Dayle Coyne Racing, was injured when struck by Francesco Dracone's car as Dracone exited his pit box. Dracone spun while exiting, clipping Phillips' leg. Phillips received stitches for a leg cut and was released from the infield care center. The race faced traction issues due to prior rain, and Dracone finished 23rd.

A husband, Milton Vieira Severiano, murdered his wife, Cicera Alves de Sena, by repeatedly slamming her head into concrete and shooting her in the face. He confessed to the crime, stating his jealousy over men looking at her. The incident occurred in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, and was captured on CCTV. Severiano stole a neighbor's car during his escape but was later arrested. Police found weapons, including four handguns, a shotgun, and a bulletproof vest, in his car. He faces life in jail.

Sarah Wilson, author of "I Quit Sugar," shared her personal struggle with mental illness, including anxiety and depression, which led her to contemplate ending her life. She attributed her feelings of hopelessness to a combination of stress, anxiety, thyroid disease, and feelings of isolation. Wilson now views depression and anxiety as closely linked and emphasizes the need to recognize this connection, especially given the rising rates of anxiety among Australian women. She has found peace with her anxiety and acknowledges it as part of her identity, while also highlighting the importance of seeking help and support.

An Oregon woman, Elena Curtin, who was seven months pregnant, was charged with second-degree assault after she used a crowbar to attack her boyfriend's ex-girlfriend, who was using heroin in her bathroom. Prosecutors dropped the charge, citing Curtin's justification for her actions. Curtin gave birth in January and is now living with her parents. The ex-girlfriend, who had a history of drug use and conflict with Curtin, was described as jealous and bitter. The boyfriend, who is the father of Curtin's child, has not been involved in his new child's life. Curtin's defense attorney noted the ex's harmful behavior and stated that the incident allowed Curtin to reassess her relationship and move forward. If convicted, Curtin would have faced a mandatory prison sentence of almost six years.

The passage describes Gemma, a pit bull in California, who is filmed being fed treats. Her owner tries to trick her by adding a broccoli spear, which Gemma reacts to with disgust, eating it and then spitting it out. The text hopes the two children living with her don't imitate her behavior. It also mentions that Gemma enjoys sleeping and spending time with her human family.

HSBC apologized after a link on its official website directed users to a pornographic page. The link, which was meant to lead to the Young Entrepreneur Awards page, was taken over by a porn site after the awards were canceled in 2011. HSBC removed the link and denied any association with the external site, assuring the public that its website remains secure.

A 13-year-old Maryland boy, Marcus, called 911 after a fire broke out in his family's home in Clinton on Sunday morning. He stayed calm during the 11-minute call, providing firefighters with directions to rescue him and his 9-year-old sister, Aaliyah, who were trapped on the second floor. Marcus also comforted his sister and gave her instructions to stay low and breathe. Firefighters entered the room through a broken window and rescued the siblings. Both were taken to the hospital with non-life threatening injuries, while their other family members escaped on their own.

Amazing pictures of blue fluorescent algae lighting up Australia's east coast have emerged, specifically in Jervis Bay, New South Wales. Photographer Andy Hutchinson captured the neon glow illuminating a popular beach, describing it as a "beautiful supernatural scene" caused by millions of plankton emitting light. A similar display was seen in Sydney's Manly Beach in August 2014. Oceanography expert Iain Suthers explained that the glow is caused by noctiluca scintillans, a single-celled phytoplankton that blooms in spring and autumn, usually due to natural causes. The algae emits light as a defense mechanism against diatoms.

New tests, such as Endopredict, can identify genetic markers in breast cancer tumors to determine their aggressiveness, potentially sparing some patients from chemotherapy. After surgery, cancer cells are analyzed to assess the risk of recurrence, with some women having a very low risk (as low as 5%). This information allows patients to make informed decisions about chemotherapy, which is often avoided if the risk is low. While these tests are currently available privately at a cost of around £2,500, there is hope they may become accessible through the NHS. Patients like Becca Cornford have benefited from these tests, avoiding chemotherapy due to a low recurrence risk, while still maintaining regular monitoring for early detection.

Over the past nine years, more than 25 women have been airlifted from Royal Navy ships due to pregnancy, including at least one from HMS Illustrious, nicknamed "HMS Lusty." Emergency evacuations occurred on 18 other ships, such as HMS Dragon, HMS Enterprise, and HMS Richmond. The Ministry of Defence confirmed a strict "no touching" rule at sea, suggesting pregnancies occurred before or during leave. This comes nine months after Commander Sarah West, the first woman to captain a Royal Navy warship, was flown back to the UK following claims of a sexual relationship with a crew member, leading to an investigation. Women have served in the Royal Navy since 1990, with 9% of personnel being female in 2014. Strict military rules prohibit pregnant women from serving in war zones, resulting in the evacuation of nearly 100 female soldiers from Afghanistan and 102 from Iraq between 2006 and 2013. Troops are advised to check for pregnancy before deployment but are not required to take tests. Most pregnancies were conceived before deployment, but some occurred while on operations.

A drone carrying traces of radioactive cesium was found on the roof of Japan's prime minister's residence, raising concerns about potential terrorism involving drones. The discovery occurred as Japan's government approved restarting two reactors at the Sendai nuclear plant, a move that is controversial due to the country's lingering fears from the Fukushima disaster. The drone, equipped with a camera and smoke flares, was 50 centimeters wide and had four propellers. Authorities suspect the cesium was intentionally placed in the drone, though the amount is not immediately harmful. The incident has prompted officials to review drone regulations and enhance security measures ahead of upcoming events like the Olympics and G7 summit. Current Japanese law restricts drone flights near airports but not around government buildings, including the prime minister's residence.

This passage describes Lu Xincuai, a security guard from Zhejiang Province, China, who takes his 84-year-old Alzheimer's-suffering mother to work on the back of his motorbike every day. He ensures her safety by tying a sash around their waists and rides slowly to allow them to chat. After his father's death, he took on the responsibility of caring for his mother, as no one else could. At work, his employer provided his mother with a room, and he regularly checks on her to prevent her from wandering. Lu feels a sense of duty to care for his mother, as she once cared for him, and he expresses deep concern for her well-being.

A major study reveals that heavy drinking and binge drinking among Americans increased significantly between 2005 and 2012, with a notable rise in women's drinking habits. Heavy drinking is defined as more than one drink per day for women and two for men, while binge drinking involves consuming four or more drinks for women and five or more for men in a single occasion. The study highlights that women's binge drinking rates increased more than seven times the rate among men over the decade. The rise is attributed to changing social norms, making it more acceptable for women to drink like men. The study also notes that alcohol-related deaths and costs are substantial, with about 88,600 U.S. deaths attributed to alcohol in 2010 and annual costs exceeding $220 billion. Factors contributing to increased drinking include lower alcohol prices, increased advertising, and weakened alcohol control policies.

The passage discusses concerns raised by UN officials about the increasing rate of caesarean sections, warning that they are being performed too readily, putting the health of women and their babies at risk. It notes that over a quarter of women giving birth in England now have a caesarean, a rate that has more than doubled since the early 1990s. The World Health Organization (WHO) recommends that caesareans should only be performed when medically necessary, as they can lead to infections, complications, disability, or death. The procedure is also costly, with a planned caesarean costing the NHS an average of £2,369 compared to £1,665 for a natural birth. WHO's stance contradicts current NHS guidelines, which allow caesareans for non-medical reasons such as anxiety (tokophobia) or certain medical conditions. The WHO emphasizes the need to reduce unnecessary caesareans to allocate resources more effectively and minimize health risks.

A woman named Michelle Filkins, 44, was arrested after breaking into a home on Martha's Vineyard, living there for at least a week, and selling or giving away items from the property. She was discovered by the homeowner, Mark Conklin, on April 17. Filkins was charged with breaking and entering, larceny over $250, and malicious destruction of property. She fled when confronted, and police later found her attempting to re-enter the home. Items missing include various furniture, electronics, and personal belongings. Police are urging anyone who received items from the home to return them for restitution. Filkins is next scheduled to appear in court on May 14.

A lost iPhone belonging to Bella Crooke from Melbourne was reunited with its owner after Albury police officers used the unlocked phone to post humorous selfies and messages on Bella's Facebook page to track her down. The phone was handed in at the police station on Sunday morning, and officers posted photos of the phone in a "holding cell" and jokes about its "charge" and "cell" status. Bella, who had lost the phone at a friend's birthday party the previous night, reclaimed it without needing to provide her name, as the officers recognized her from Facebook. The police's humorous approach was well-received, and Bella later added a password to her phone.

A five-day-old baby hippo was tragically killed when it got caught in a fight between two adult male hippos at Isimangaliso Wetland Park in eastern South Africa. The calf's mother, who had stayed with her herd to avoid harm, was unable to save her baby. One of the fighting hippos grabbed the calf, and despite her efforts, the baby was thrown into the air and dragged along the water's surface before dying from its injuries hours later. A tour operator, Stacey Farrell, witnessed the event and described the mother's desperate attempts to protect her calf. The exact reason for the attack remains unclear.

A three-bedroom apartment in Knightsbridge, London, is being sold for £575,000, which is significantly cheaper than neighboring properties. However, the property has only three years left on its lease and requires renovation. If the lease is extended, the property could be worth up to £6 million. The apartment is part of a rare sale of two maisonettes in Egerton Place, both with short leases and needing modernization. The current freeholder is the Welcome Trust, and extending the lease would likely cost between £3.35 and £4.5 million. The properties are historically significant, with an architectural style from the late 19th century. Experts warn potential buyers about the high cost of lease extensions, even though the property appears to be a bargain at first glance.

Starbucks experienced a computer outage affecting 8,000 stores in the U.S. and Canada, causing sales disruptions and prompting baristas to give away free drinks. The issue, caused by a system refresh failure, was resolved by Saturday, with stores resuming normal operations. While customers celebrated the free coffee and baked goods, some locations closed early to avoid giving away free products. The incident occurred just after Starbucks reported record quarterly earnings, leading to a stock price increase.

Terrorists are being trained and radicalized in rural areas of West Wales, including Ceredigion, Powys, and Pembrokeshire. Detective Constable Gareth Jones from the Wales Extremism and Counter Terrorism Unit emphasized that terrorism is not limited to large cities. Radicalization efforts in these areas involve individuals participating in ordinary community activities with ulterior motives. Historical incidents include extremist training in the Brecon Beacons in 1998 and the 2005 sighting of 7/7 bombers in North Wales. Recent cases include arrests of individuals plotting terror attacks and links to a terrorist attack involving someone who studied at an institute connected to Iraqi clerics. Community intelligence is highlighted as crucial for counter-terrorism efforts.

A species of whale, the Omura's whale, feared to be extinct, was found washed up on a remote Exmouth beach in Western Australia, marking the first sighting in the state and only the second in Australia. Identified through DNA profiling, the 5.68-meter juvenile female provided significant scientific value as the species was only described in 2003 and is typically found in Indonesian waters, the Philippines, and the Sea of Japan. The whale has a sleek body and unique skeletal features, including 53 vertebrae. The carcass will be buried, with the skeleton to be recovered for further study and potential public display.

This passage discusses the controversial views of Cheryl Rios, a Texas businesswoman, who argues that women, due to their hormones, are unsuitable for leadership roles like the presidency. She claims that female leaders might make irrational decisions, such as starting unnecessary wars, and expresses support for male candidates over women. The article also highlights the broader issue of gender bias in the workplace and its impact on women's potential. It notes that while some argue about the biological differences between men and women in leadership, the real issue is the entrenched gender bias that hinders women's advancement. The passage emphasizes the importance of addressing this bias to achieve equality, which benefits individuals, families, and the economy. It also points out that despite the challenges, women like Hillary Clinton are making strides in politics, and the article concludes by highlighting the need to challenge stereotypes and support women's leadership.

Veteran actor Robert Hardy, 89, is selling his extensive collection of antiques, including over 200 items, in a £100,000 auction due to downsizing his home. The auction, held by Dominic Winter Auctioneers in Gloucestershire, features items such as a hand-painted limewood diorama of the Battle of Agincourt, a longbow, a portrait of Hardy holding the bow, and various other antiques like furniture, paintings, swords, and books. Hardy, known for his roles in "All Creatures Great and Small" and as Winston Churchill in multiple TV dramas, has a deep interest in military history and medieval longbows. He studied English with J.R.R. Tolkien and C.S. Lewis and has authored books on the longbow. Despite retiring from stage acting, he plans to continue with television work.

Michael Scott Shemansky is on the run as a suspect in the murder of his mother, Sandra Shemansky, found dead in their shared home in Winter Garden, Florida. Shemansky failed to appear for a supervised visit with his son on the same day the body was discovered, prompting police involvement. An initial investigation suggests foul play. Shemansky has a history of mental illness, including bipolar disorder, and was on parole for battery on law enforcement. His estranged wife had previously filed a domestic violence injunction against him. Neighbors believe the stress of divorce proceedings and his mother's intervention may have contributed to his actions. Authorities have the murder weapon but have not confirmed the method of death. Shemansky was last seen fleeing on foot without provisions or medication. Anyone with information about his whereabouts is urged to contact authorities.

The city of Eugene, United States, was awarded the rights to host the 2021 IAfF World Championships, bypassing the usual bidding process due to a strategic opportunity to host the event in the USA for the first time. Eugene previously lost its bid for the 2019 event to Doha, Qatar. The IAfF Council emphasized the unique collaboration between public authorities, the private sector, and other stakeholders in Eugene. This decision followed a similar approach used for the 2007 World Championships in Osaka, Japan. Additionally, Mo Farah won gold in the men's 10,000 metres at the 2013 IAfF World Athletics Championships in Moscow.

Leonie Granger, a 25-year-old care assistant from Gillingham, Kent, was jailed for 16 years for manslaughter after luring professional gambler Mehmet Hassan, 56, to his death in a honey trap scheme. Granger befriended Hassan at a London casino, using her appearance to gain his trust and showered with gifts, cash, and trips. She later conspired with her boyfriend Kyrron Jackson and friend Nicholas Chandler to kill Hassan, who was described as a "soft target" due to his lavish lifestyle and tendency to keep winnings at home. The trio tied up and kicked Hassan to death in his flat, stealing £3,000 and other items. Granger was found guilty of manslaughter, while Jackson and Chandler were convicted of murder and received life sentences. The court described the attack as "pitiless and wicked," highlighting the brutality of the crime.

Cesc Fabregas, the Chelsea midfielder, has been experiencing a decline in form, particularly in the second half of the season. Despite a strong start, his performance has dropped, leading to concerns about his durability. Fabregas, who captained Spain in a 2-0 defeat by Holland, struggled to make an impact in midfield. His form has been affected by the demanding campaign, and his assist numbers have significantly decreased. Although he is on track to fall short of Thierry Henry's Premier League assist record, Chelsea still has nine games left in the season, and Fabregas's revival could be crucial for their title hopes. Mourinho is hopeful that Fabregas can regain his form and contribute to the team's success.

West Ham are close to signing Jamaican starlet Deshane Beckford, a 17-year-old forward who impressed during a two-week trial with the club's academy. Beckford, who has offers from Belgian clubs and has been linked with several European teams, is considered one of the top Caribbean prospects. Additionally, West Ham announced that season tickets for the Olympic Stadium will cost as little as £289, making it the cheapest in the Premier League for the 2016-17 season.

Police have discontinued an investigation into the assault of Mike Lane, a huntsman, despite having substantial evidence, including video footage and names of suspects. Lane, who was severely injured during the attack by masked protesters, criticized the decision as "pathetic" and expressed loss of trust in the police. The attack occurred during a hunt with an artificial scent, and Lane suffered concussion, broken teeth, and memory loss. Although the suspect's face was captured on video and a photograph was released, no identification or charges have been made. Hunt supporters and activists are dismayed, with calls for legislation to ban face coverings by saboteurs to aid in identification and prosecution. Wiltshire Police stated the case remains open pending further evidence.

Adam Gadahn, known as "Azzam the American," was a prominent member of Al Qaeda who spoke against the United States. He was killed in January 2014 during a U.S. counterterrorism operation. Gadahn, who was born in 1978 in California, converted to Islam in 1995 and joined Al Qaeda in Pakistan. He became a key English-language propagandist for the group, appearing in numerous videos that called for attacks on American and Western targets. Gadahn was indicted in 2006 for treason and material support to Al Qaeda. He was also featured in videos commemorating the 9/11 attacks and encouraged lone-wolf attacks in the U.S. His final video was released in September 2014.

The passage discusses the phenomenon of Chinese parents who are enthusiastic about raising child prodigies. It highlights a five-year-old boy named Mai Zizhuo, who has been playing basketball since the age of two and a half. A viral video showcasing his impressive basketball skills has gained widespread attention in China. His abilities have earned him many fans, and online comments reflect a mix of admiration, disbelief, and self-reflection. The passage also mentions Yao Ming, a renowned Chinese basketball player, for comparison.

Tom O'Carroll, a former key activist for the Paedophile Information Exchange (PIE), which campaigned for the legalization of child sex in the 1970s and 80s, has joined the supporters of the media pressure group Hacked Off. O'Carroll attended a Hacked Off rally in Parliament on February 25 to lobby MPs for state involvement in media regulation. Hacked Off, formed after the phone-hacking scandal, campaigns against what it sees as biased media standards and seeks a statutory body for press regulation, as recommended by the Leveson Inquiry. O'Carroll's association with Hacked Off is seen as an embarrassment for the group. PIE, which also wanted incest legalized and was linked to the National Council for Civil Liberties (NCCL), was disbanded in 1992. O'Carroll was jailed in 1981 for "corrupting public morals" and later wrote about his attendance at the Hacked Off meeting, which was open to the public.

The passage describes an unusual event during Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week Australia, where the pool at Bondi's Icebergs Club was drained to create a unique catwalk setting. The event featured a monochrome, unisex clothing collection from the brand Ten Pieces, designed to be worn in 20 different ways. Models walked through the empty pool and along the break wall, with spectators gathering from the beach and balcony. The show took place on a warm day, with attendees enjoying the scenic backdrop of the ocean and sun. The event blended fashion and beach culture, attracting both fashion enthusiasts and local beachgoers.

Amir Khan, a Bolton-born boxer, spent a family day at a safari park in Northern California with his wife Faryal Makhdoom Khan and daughter Lamysa. During the visit, he interacted with a rare white tiger, giraffes, and sea lions. Earlier in the week, Khan announced his next fight will be against former light-welterweight world champion Chris Algieri on May 30, ending speculation about his next opponent.

A Palestinian teenager, Mohammed Abu Khdeir, was initially listed on an Israeli memorial wall honoring fallen soldiers and terrorism victims. His family and the organization Almagor opposed his inclusion, arguing his death was a rogue act, not a terror attack. Following complaints, the Israeli national insurance institute decided to remove his name from the memorial wall and its website. A panel of judges is reviewing the case of the three individuals accused of his murder.

The passage describes a video where a young boy uses his cat as a pillow by lying on its belly in the garden. The cat initially remains still but then moves away, prompting the boy to follow and repeat the action. The cat eventually decides he has had enough and goes indoors. Later, the boy and the cat reconcile, with the boy feeding the cat treats.

A police corruption trial in Philadelphia is ongoing, with witness Robert Kushner testifying about his past as a marijuana dealer. Kushner lost his coaching job at Jack M. Barrack Hebrew Academy after revealing that undercover officers stole from him during a 2007 arrest. He claimed the charges were expunged and that he is innocent of later charges. The government's case against the officers is criticized by their lawyers as relying on deceitful witnesses.

An explosion at a chemical plant in Zhangzhou, Fujian Province, China, injured six people, with five hospitalized from broken glass. The plant, which produces paraxylene (PX), a carcinogenic chemical, experienced the blast after an oil leak. Over 600 firefighters controlled the fire. The incident follows a previous explosion in July 2013 and has sparked concerns due to past protests against PX plants. The Zhangzhou plant was originally planned for Xiamen but was moved to a remote location after public backlash in 2007.

Jack Grealish, an Aston Villa teenager and Ireland Under 21 international, has a superstition about wearing his socks low, just above his shinpads, which he intends to keep even after his first Premier League start. He uses children's size shinpads and has not had a kick on his shin yet. Grealish was pleased with his first Premier League start in a tough match against QPR, expressing gratitude for the manager's faith in him and hoping for more starts before the season ends.

Bobbi Kristina Brown, the daughter of Bobby Brown and Whitney Houston, has sustained global and irreversible brain damage and remains unresponsive, according to her grandmother, Cissy Houston. She is no longer in a medically induced coma but does not respond to visitors or familiar voices and has a tracheostomy. Her condition has not changed in nearly three months. While her father, Bobby Brown, claimed her condition had improved and that she is awake and undergoing rehabilitation, her attorney stated that the quality of her life remains uncertain. Bobby Brown was emotional when he made these remarks, and his wife, Alicia Etheredge-Brown, supported his statement about Bobbi Kristina's progress.

Russia is on the brink of reaching the Fed Cup final with a 2-0 lead after Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova defeated Germany's Sabine Lisicki in a closely contested match. Pavlyuchenkova saved a match point and won 4-6, 7-6 (4), 6-3. Svetlana Kuznetsova also won her match against Julia Goerges in straight sets. Both players struggled with their serves, with Pavlyuchenkova having 13 double faults and Lisicki making 63 unforced errors. Russia now needs one more win from Sunday's three matches to secure their first Fed Cup title since 2008.

Residents of New South Wales are being warned to prepare for more flooding and damage as another storm, potentially an East Coast Low, is predicted to hit the region later this week. This storm could bring heavy rain from Thursday through Saturday, following a previous severe weather event that caused significant damage. The State Emergency Service (SES) is concerned that additional storms will hinder cleanup efforts, with over 4,409 of 24,196 jobs still pending. The SES is particularly worried about the Hunter region, which was heavily affected by the previous storm. Meteorologists indicate that the new weather system may bring rain to northern parts of the state but is expected to be less severe than the previous storm. The SES is urging residents to prepare their homes and families to prevent further loss.

Nina Moric, a 38-year-old Croatian model and former wife of Fabrizio Corona, denied claims that she attempted suicide, stating she collapsed due to low blood pressure and was treated in the hospital. She shared photos of her injuries on Instagram and assured her fans she was recovering at home. Italian media had reported she tried to take her own life, with her boyfriend suggesting she was a victim of malicious intent. Moric also addressed past claims of a suicide attempt in 2009. Fabrizio Corona, known as the "king" of Italian paparazzi, was jailed for blackmailing celebrities, though he claimed he only offered photos for sale.

The passage discusses the British public's anticipation for the arrival of Prince William and Kate Middleton's second child, with hopes for a baby princess. A poll revealed that "Diana" is the favorite name for a girl, followed by "Alice" and "Charlotte." For a boy, "James" and "Alexander" were top choices. The public also supports William's decision to take paternity leave. Social media reflects strong support for naming the child after Diana, William's mother.

A suicide bomber attacked a group of protesters in eastern Afghanistan, killing 17 people and injuring dozens, including an Afghan lawmaker. The Taliban denied responsibility, and no other group has claimed the attack. The protesters were heading to a larger rally against the provincial governor. The attack occurred around 10 a.m. local time.

Dani Alves is set to leave Barcelona this summer after rejecting the club's final contract offer. The 31-year-old Brazilian right-back has spent seven successful years at the club, winning four La Liga titles and two Champions League trophies. His agent, Dinorah Santana, confirmed that Alves has refused a three-year contract extension, which required him to play in 60% of the club's matches. She stated that negotiations are over and expressed disappointment that Barcelona had not considered a contract renewal by April.

Pablo Osvaldo, a 29-year-old Argentine footballer currently playing for Boca Juniors on loan from Southampton, has expressed his desire for Italian football legends Andrea Pirlo and Francesco Totti to join him at Boca Juniors. Osvaldo believes that Pirlo and Totti would be a good fit for the club due to their South American style of play and their popularity among fans. He mentioned that the Bombonera stadium would be thrilled to have such players. Pirlo is regarded as one of the best midfielders in the world, while Totti is a legendary figure at Roma.

Lewis Ferguson, an 18-year-old amateur jockey, suffered a dramatic double somersault fall from his horse, Merrion Square, during a race at Wincanton. Despite the severe fall, he only sustained a minor cut on his nose. The incident went viral online, with hundreds of thousands of views. Ferguson was back riding out the same day and remained undeterred, expressing gratitude for his luck and humorously considering a career in gymnastics after his racing career. Fellow jockeys showed concern and watched the replay with him.

James Haskell, the London Wasps captain, dressed as Iron Man for an Instagram post to celebrate the release of "Avengers: Age of Ultron." The movie premiered at Westfield London Shopping Centre, featuring A-list actors like Robert Downey Jr., Chris Hemsworth, and Scarlett Johansson. Haskell, who returned to Wasps in 2012 after playing in France, Japan, and New Zealand, has since surpassed 100 appearances for the club and earned 57 caps for England.

The passage discusses the resurgence of wide-leg trousers as a prominent trend in SS15 fashion. It highlights that the style offers an effortless alternative to skinny jeans, with denim being the easiest way to achieve the look. The trend has made a comeback since the 1970s, with designers like Gucci, Celine, and Stella McCartney showcasing variations. The passage also provides styling tips, such as pairing wide-leg trousers with simple knits, high heels, and avoiding overwhelming fabric. It mentions specific brands like Topshop and Finery London for affordable options and notes that the trend is versatile for all seasons.

The University of Michigan decided to proceed with a screening of the film "American Sniper" despite objections from some students. Over 200 students signed a petition to cancel the showing, citing concerns about the film's portrayal of the Iraq War and its negative impact on the Middle East. However, backlash led to a counter-petition. Vice President for Student Life E. Royster Harper stated that canceling the movie was inconsistent with the university's commitment to freedom of expression. The screening will go on as part of the UMIX social events, with an alternative family-friendly film, "Paddington," also offered. The decision received praise from football coach Jim Harbaugh.

A quokka was injured when two French tourists attempted to set it on fire on Rottnest Island, Western Australia, on April 3. The incident involved igniting an aerosol spray with a lighter, causing flames to contact the animal. The quokka survived but was singed. Detectives investigated, questioned the tourists, and seized video evidence. Both men, aged 18 and 24, were evicted from the island and charged with animal cruelty. They are set to appear in court on April 17. Quokkas are small marsupials found on certain islands off the WA coast, including Rottnest Island.

In this passage, 102-year-old Alice Barker, a former dancer from the 1930s and 1940s, never saw films of herself performing, as her photographs and memorabilia were lost over time. With the help of filmmakers from jazz-on-film.com and volunteers, a video of "Soundies"—early music videos—was created and shown to Barker at her nursing home. She was delighted to see herself dancing again.

The passage discusses the decline in the tradition of washing one's own car in Britain. New data shows that a third of men and three-quarters of women have never washed their own cars, with many opting for car wash services instead. Factors contributing to this trend include the availability of hand car washes, increased leisure activities on Sundays, and the size of modern vehicles. While some people still wash their cars, particularly during holidays, others do it as an excuse to leave the house. Regional and brand differences in car washing habits are also noted, with certain cities and car models being more likely to be washed by their owners.

Martin Skrtel has praised Steven Gerrard's positive impact on his career since joining Liverpool in 2008 and acknowledges Gerrard's significance to the club. Gerrard, set to play in the FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa, aims to end his Liverpool career with a victory and a trip to the final against Arsenal on his birthday. Skrtel believes Gerrard remains one of the best players in the world and synonymous with Liverpool, although he acknowledges the club will be different without him. Skrtel also believes Liverpool has potential replacements for Gerrard and that the team can overcome the challenge of his departure with proper support. Both Gerrard and Skrtel are expected to return to the Liverpool lineup for the match against Villa after serving bans.

At the age of 75, Jack Nicklaus made a hole-in-one on the 130-yard fourth hole during the par-3 contest at Augusta National, adding to his legendary career. This achievement, while notable, was overshadowed by Camilo Villegas, who made two hole-in-ones and came close to winning the tournament. Nicklaus, who first won the Masters in 1963 and earned his sixth green jacket in 1986, is one of five men to complete the career grand slam.

On Wednesday night, tornado sirens were activated in Kansas as multiple storms reported tornadoes, including one near Goddard, which missed the city but posed risks to other areas. Severe weather expert Chad Myers warned that nighttime tornadoes are particularly dangerous. Tornadoes were also reported in southwestern Kansas, near Aetna. In Missouri, a possible tornado was reported in Potosi, causing wind damage and flooding. Social media users shared images of damage, fallen trees, and large hail. Additional storms are expected in the Midwest and surrounding regions on Thursday.

An Oklahoma reserve sheriff's deputy, Robert Bates, pleaded not guilty to second-degree manslaughter after fatally shooting Eric Harris during a weapons sting operation. The incident occurred on April 2 when Bates, who claims the shooting was accidental, mistakenly used a gun instead of a taser. The Harris family expressed disappointment that Bates was granted permission to vacation in the Bahamas during the ongoing investigation. Bates' preliminary hearing is scheduled for July 2. The family's lawyer alleges Bates was unqualified to be on the force and received preferential treatment due to donations and friendship with the sheriff. The Tulsa County Sheriff's Office denies these claims and has re-assigned two deputies involved in the arrest due to threats. One of Bates' lawyers released his training documents, asserting he had proper law enforcement training.

conor mcgregor is preparing for a featherweight title challenge against jose aldo on july 11. he has gotten a new tattoo of a tiger on his stomach, accompanied by the message "if you see the tiger, it's too late. you're food." mcgregor claims aldo lacks the same motivation as him to defend the title, as aldo is making his eighth defense. mcgregor previously grabbed aldo's belt during a promotional tour in dublin, highlighting their competitive and fractious relationship. the fight is set to take place in las vegas, with mcgregor aiming to finally hold the belt for his supporters.

Tony Abbott, the Australian Prime Minister, drew criticism for skolling a schooner of beer at an Australian Rules football event, which anti-drinking campaigners argued glorified binge drinking and linked masculinity with heavy alcohol consumption. Julie Robert, a cultural studies professor, criticized Abbott for not advocating against binge drinking and for setting a harmful cultural precedent. While some, including Health Minister Sussan Ley, defended Abbott's actions, others, like opposition leader Bill Shorten, made light-hearted comments. Dr. Robert noted that such displays of drinking are problematic and that attitudes toward heavy drinking have shifted in recent years. Abbott's actions were compared to those of past leaders, but critics argued he should be a role model for healthier behaviors.

Indiana's Scott County has experienced a significant increase in HIV cases, with 120 confirmed cases and 10 preliminary positive cases, linked to a short-term needle exchange program approved by Governor Mike Pence. The program, which has provided 5,322 clean syringes and collected 1,400 used ones, has seen increased participation due to a mobile unit outreach. The outbreak primarily affects intravenous drug users using the painkiller Opana. While health officials expect the case numbers to rise as more testing occurs, Pence is reviewing whether to extend the 30-day program. The program's future and related legislation allowing needle exchanges in other counties remain uncertain. Governor Pence opposes needle exchanges as an anti-drug policy, while some lawmakers support them as harm-reduction measures. The federal government has banned public funding for such programs, and the state's program lacks financial support, raising concerns about sustainability.

The passage describes an obsessive Arsenal fan who made his girlfriend, Saskia, take a detailed exam on Arsenal FC knowledge. The test included multiple-choice questions, tables, and open-ended questions, with instructions like reading questions twice and using calculators. Saskia scored 87% and received an 'A' grade, which her boyfriend praised, promising not to end their relationship. Despite some mistakes in player positions and squad names, she received creative feedback and double marks for humorous answers. Her results were shared on Twitter, gaining mixed reactions, with some calling the boyfriend a 'legend' and others criticizing the test's intensity. The post inspired some men to quiz their girlfriends, while others questioned the boyfriend's behavior.

Carlos Toro, a 66-year-old former Medellin cartel member who worked as an undercover DEA informant for 27 years, is now facing deportation after retiring. Toro, who provided crucial information leading to the prosecution of drug lords and a former Panamanian dictator, was promised U.S. citizenship in exchange for his cooperation but has not received it. Now living illegally in the U.S., Toro is in a legal limbo, unable to collect Social Security benefits or obtain a passport. He fears for his life if deported, as he believes he would be killed upon returning to Colombia. Despite his contributions to the DEA, the agency has refused to assist him with citizenship, prompting some of his colleagues to offer financial help. Toro remains in hiding as he seeks a solution to his legal status.

A 14-year-old girl in India set herself on fire after being allegedly gang-raped by five men from her village in Uttar Pradesh. She is now receiving treatment at Delhi's Safdarjung Hospital with 70% burns. The incident has sparked renewed attention on sexual assault in India, especially following the banning of a documentary about the 2012 gang rape and murder of Jyoti Singh Pandey, which led to widespread protests and calls for stricter protection for women. The accused men have been arrested, and the case highlights ongoing issues of gender-based violence and societal response in the country.

Manchester United manager Louis van Gaal aims to beat rivals Manchester City in the Sunday derby at Old Trafford but will be without Robin van Persie, who is not fit enough to play. Van Gaal emphasized the importance of the match for improving their league position and avoiding a Champions League qualifying fixture. He also ruled out Luke Shaw from the squad for similar fitness reasons. Van Gaal acknowledged the challenge posed by City but downplayed any desire for revenge after a previous loss. He expressed his anticipation for the derby atmosphere and praised his fans' support.

Arsenal and Liverpool fans protested against rising ticket prices by leaving their seats empty for the first 10 minutes of their Premier League match at Emirates Stadium. The protest followed the announcement of a £5.14 billion TV rights deal, with fans criticizing the high ticket prices, starting at £64. Supporters from both clubs displayed banners inside and outside the stadium, highlighting the disparity between the TV deal and ticket costs. Organizers from both clubs, including Kelvin Meadows and Roy Bentham, criticized the financial practices of football, calling ticket prices extortionate and demanding reductions to retain fans. The protest symbolized a growing unity among fans across clubs, as they expressed frustration over the financial burden of supporting their teams. Further protests were expected after the match.

A newborn baby, Star Reader, was diagnosed with biliary atresia, a life-threatening liver condition, shortly after birth. Her parents, Jade and Matthew Reader, were told that a liver transplant was necessary for her survival. Neither parent was a suitable donor, but Star's maternal aunt, Shanell Reader, a twin sister to Jade, volunteered to donate part of her liver. After undergoing a successful liver transplant in November, Star spent six weeks in the hospital and has since made a good recovery. She now requires regular medical check-ups and anti-rejection medication for the rest of her life. Shanell's selfless act has given Star a chance to live a normal life.

In this passage, it is described that Chelsea players, including Eden Hazard and Nathan Ake, participated in Audi's football challenge. The challenge involved various tasks such as shooting balls into the boot of a car from close range and sinking balls into convertible Audis from long range. Hazard and Ake won the first two rounds, with Hazard and Ake also winning the decider. In the final challenge, Willian and Loic Remy managed to win against Hazard and Ake. Willian accidentally smashed a wing mirror of one of the Audis during the challenge, but it is noted that he won't have to pay for the damage.

A former Fortune 500 executive, Robert Dellinger, caused a high-speed highway crash in December 2013 that killed a Vermont couple and their unborn baby. During his sentencing, Dellinger denied being suicidal at the time of the crash, contrary to prosecutors' claims. The crash, which occurred in New Hampshire, resulted in the deaths of Amanda Murphy and Jason Timmons, who were instantly killed. Dellinger pleaded guilty to negligent homicide and assault, facing 12 to 24 years in prison. His defense cited health issues, including Ambien withdrawal, psychiatric drug overdose, Prozac, and multiple sclerosis. The couple, who met at a home for the elderly, were killed instantly when Dellinger's truck sheared the top of their SUV. Dellinger's wife expressed deep sorrow and offered condolences to the victims' families. A wrongful death lawsuit is also pending.

A woman, Lacey Spears, was convicted of second-degree murder for poisoning her five-year-old son, Garnett-Paul Spears, with salt through his feeding tube while he was hospitalized. She was sentenced to 20 years to life, which was less than the maximum 25 years to life requested by prosecutors. The boy's father, Chris Hill, expressed anger on Facebook, calling for her to be placed in general population and even suggesting she be beaten to death in prison. He criticized her lack of emotion during the sentencing. The judge noted Spears has a mental illness, while prosecutors argued her actions were driven by a need for attention. Spears' lawyer claimed she was a hardworking single mother and blamed the hospital for negligence, planning to appeal the verdict. Prosecutors stated that Spears used her son's medical conditions to gain attention and that her actions directly led to his death. Spears did not testify and her social media posts about her son's health issues were used as evidence.

The passage discusses the arrival of an improved influenza vaccine in Australia, which includes protection against two new strains, H3N2 and B/Phuket, in response to a spike in flu-related deaths in Europe and the United States. The vaccine is arriving a month later than expected due to the updated strains. High-risk groups, including the very young, very old, and most Indigenous Australians, can access free government-funded flu shots starting April 20. Experts, including Dr. Alan Hampson, emphasize the importance of the vaccine, which also protects against H1N1. He notes that the modified vaccine should be a better match for circulating strains and hopes to prevent more deaths. Dr. Hampson encourages people to book their flu shots now, even if they are not in high-risk groups, to protect those around them.

The caretakers of Abraham Lincoln's tomb are defending against criticism from National Geographic Magazine and potential budget cuts that could affect the management of the historic site. This comes as Illinois faces a financial crisis and plans to eliminate the state historic preservation agency, which manages the tomb. The tomb, which is a popular tourist site, has been described by National Geographic as having "all the historical character of an office lobby." Despite this, the tomb has undergone significant renovations and is in excellent physical condition. The site is also commemorating the 150th anniversary of Lincoln's assassination, which adds to the current challenges faced by the caretakers.

The passage discusses the resurgence of 1990s and 2000s fashion trends, highlighting both their nostalgic appeal and their impracticality. It mentions several trends such as chokers, berry-colored lips, round sunglasses, and Calvin Klein logo t-shirts that are currently popular. The return of JNCO's wide-leg 'rave' jeans has caused controversy among those who remember them as impractical. The passage also lists various other trends that have made a comeback, including the bucket hat, camouflage print, double denim, Ugg boots, Daisy Dukes, Juicy Couture tracksuits, colored sunglasses, corsets as outfits, and harem trousers. It notes how these trends were popularized by celebrities in the past and are now being revived by contemporary figures.

During a busy week for trending stories, several notable events were covered. Four rainbows were spotted in the New York area after heavy rain, captured by Amanda Curtis. In rural China, a crackdown on vice has led to a ban on hiring exotic dancers for wakes, forcing families to find new ways to comfort mourners. RDJ expressed frustration when questioned about his private life, mentioning the Kardashian influence on trends like the "Kylie Jenner Challenge" involving lip plumping. A 102-year-old woman, Alice Barker, revisited her past with a prom-posal referencing bombs, sparking debate over racism. Ewan McGregor will portray Lumiere in "Beauty and the Beast," while Johnny Depp's role in "Black Mass" has garnered attention. Additionally, a unique pregnancy announcement referenced "The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air," and a military dad's photobombing of his son was praised for originality.

The Miami Open is becoming a celebration of milestones, with Serena Williams achieving her 700th career victory by defeating Sabine Lisicki in three sets. This victory secured her place in the semi-finals, where she would face Simona Halep. Meanwhile, Andy Murray celebrated his 500th win with a cake. Williams' path to the final was affected by her sister Venus' loss, but she remained focused on the tournament, which is close to her hometown. She eventually faced Halep, who had beaten Sloane Stephens to reach the semi-finals. The match against Lisicki was notable as Williams avenged a previous Wimbledon defeat.

Sabeen Mahmud, a Pakistani activist and café owner in Karachi, was shot and killed by two gunmen after hosting a discussion on sensitive topics related to Baluchistan. Her café, T2F, was known for promoting free speech, human rights, and progressive values. Mahmud's death sparked national mourning and highlighted the dangers of expressing dissent in Pakistan. She was celebrated as a symbol of courage and a voice for marginalized communities. Her killing has drawn attention to the suppression of free speech and the ongoing tensions in Baluchistan. No one has claimed responsibility for her assassination, and the motive remains unknown.

Mangu Ram, an 82-year-old Hindu traditional healer and refugee from West Pakistan, has lived in India's only Muslim-majority state, Jammu and Kashmir, for 70 years without citizenship rights, unable to own property or vote in state elections. He and thousands of others, known as West Pakistan Refugees (WPRs), have faced systemic discrimination and poverty due to their refugee status. With the Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) gaining power in the state, there is hope for change, as the party has pledged to normalize the WPRs' status. However, successive governments have been reluctant to grant them full rights, fearing it would upset the demographic balance in the state. Activists warn that if their hopes are not met, the community may resort to extreme measures to secure their rights.

Yoshinori Muto, a forward for FC Tokyo, is still considering a potential move to Chelsea, with the club having made a £4 million offer. Muto prefers to join a team where he can regularly play and develop his potential. Chelsea's manager, Jose Mourinho, acknowledges Muto but avoids discussing players from FC Tokyo. Mourinho also mentions that commercial interests, including a recent sponsorship deal with Yokohama Rubber, influence Chelsea's transfer policy. FC Tokyo's manager, Ranko Popovic, praises Muto's talent, intelligence, and potential, believing he could succeed at Chelsea.

Australia has dropped its policy of not selecting their best players who are playing overseas, which is a positive move. England, on the other hand, is criticized for its outdated approach, as it should allow its coach, Stuart Lancaster, to pick the best players regardless of where they play. Players like Matt Giteau and Drew Mitchell, who are performing exceptionally well for Toulon, should be considered for the World Cup squad. The article highlights that selecting the best players, even if they are overseas, is essential for success in the World Cup. Examples like Steffon Armitage and Nick Abendanon show that moving overseas can improve a player's performance. The author argues that England should not be restricted by domestic club allegiances and should support players who are performing better abroad. The article also mentions that other teams, like South Africa, continue to select overseas players like Bryan Habana, reinforcing the argument for England to follow suit.

The passage discusses the Firechat app, developed by Open Garden, which allows users to communicate without internet or mobile signal by creating wireless mesh networks using Bluetooth or Wi-Fi Direct. The app, downloaded over five million times, enables messaging through local networks where each phone acts as a node. To enhance the range and reliability of these networks, Open Garden has developed the Greenstone device, an egg-shaped gadget that acts as a beacon to relay messages over longer distances. Greenstone is currently under development, works with Firechat, and can hold up to 1,000 messages with a one-year battery life. It aims to provide resilient communication in areas with no connectivity, such as during events or emergencies.

Lillian Bustle, a burlesque performer from New Jersey, uses her TED Talk to challenge negative perceptions of the word "fat" by embracing it as a positive, body-positive descriptor of her own physique. She also identifies herself with other descriptors like "short" and "wife." Lillian argues that the term "fat" does not have to equate to "ugly," and she highlights the societal programming that leads women to avoid the term. She notes that size discrimination in the workplace has increased significantly over the past 30 years and that young girls often desire to be thinner. However, Lillian remains hopeful, citing studies that show increased exposure to body diversity can lead to greater acceptance and preference for different body types. Through her burlesque performances, she aims to positively expose audiences to diverse body types. Lillian's first performance was empowering, and she encourages others to find moments of courage to boost self-esteem. Despite some negative comments, her TED Talk has received overwhelmingly positive responses, including messages of gratitude and personal transformation.

Theo Walcott, an Arsenal winger, has been frequently seen on the bench throughout the season, with only 17 starts in 33 Premier League games. He recently participated in a photoshoot with fellow teammates and a runway model for Lanvin, the club's official tailor since 2013. Walcott is hoping to make his first start for Arsenal since March 14, as the team prepares for their FA Cup final against Aston Villa.

A collection of props and puppets created by legendary make-up artist Rick Baker will be auctioned off on May 29 at the Hilton Universal City in Los Angeles and on propstore.com. The collection, worth an estimated $746,100, includes items from over 50 productions and features iconic pieces from films such as *Men in Black*, *Batman Forever*, *How the Grinch Stole Christmas*, and others. Notable items include the *Alien Edgar Bug* valued at $40,000, the *Grinch costume* at $8,000, and the *Mikey costume* at $30,000. The auction offers collectors and fans a chance to own pieces of Hollywood history.

A seven-year-old British boy, Carwyn Scott-Howell, died after falling 164ft while skiing in the French Alps. He became separated from his mother and ventured into dense woodland, where he was found by police following his footprints. His family described him as a lively and caring child who loved the mountains and had a strong interest in skiing. The tragedy occurred during what was supposed to be a happy ski holiday in Flaine. Carwyn, who modeled himself after Bear Grylls, is believed to have attempted to reach the resort by walking through the woods. His body was recovered, and his family remains in the Alps while his body is repatriated. The incident has left his family and community deeply affected.

Laura Scurr, a 15-year-old from Whitley Bay, developed anorexia due to intense pressure to be thin, leading her to restrict her food intake to just one piece of fruit a day. Her obsession with achieving a "size zero" figure caused her health to deteriorate severely, resulting in a collapse and hospitalization where she was placed on a heart monitor. Laura's experience highlights the dangers of societal pressures on young girls to be thin. After receiving support from eating disorder organizations and mental health services, she began her recovery journey. Today, Laura has improved her body image and gained confidence, allowing her to reach the semi-final of Miss Teen GB, a competition promoting positive self-image and confidence-building for young girls.

On the day Raheem Sterling showcased Liverpool's new home kit at Anfield, fans made it clear they expect him to stay. The new kit, designed by New Balance, is part of a £300 million four-year deal. Sterling, along with Daniel Sturridge, Martin Skrtel, and Simon Mignolet, unveiled the kit to fans. Sterling had recently rejected a new contract and hinted at potential moves to Arsenal, but Liverpool insists he will remain. The kit features a tribute to the Hillsborough disaster and includes the new balance logo, liverbird, and standard chartered branding. The team also looks forward to the FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa.

The passage describes the creation of the largest single high-definition map of dark matter, produced by researchers from the University of Manchester. This map, which covers 0.4% of the sky, reveals clumps of dark matter and is part of a series that aims to eventually create a 3D view of dark matter across 12.5% of the night sky over five years. The map was made using data from the Dark Energy Camera on the Victor M. Blanco Telescope in Chile, and it helps astronomers study galaxy formation and the nature of dark energy. Dark matter, which constitutes about 85% of the universe's matter, cannot be directly observed but can be detected through its gravitational effects on visible matter.
