The map uses gravitational lensing to show distortions in light caused by dark matter, and it is expected to provide insights into the universe's expansion and the distribution of mass. The project, part of the Dark Energy Survey, is expected to be completed by 2018.

Manchester United have made an official approach for PSV Eindhoven's Memphis Depay, aiming to sign the 21-year-old winger as one of their first summer signings. United manager Louis van Gaal, who previously worked with Depay during Holland's 2014 World Cup campaign, is keen to secure him. Depay, who has scored 20 goals in 26 league games this season, is currently in high demand, with competition from clubs like Paris-Saint Germain. PSV's technical director noted that the asking price has increased significantly since Tottenham's previous bid. Depay, who has been praised by both his manager and fellow players for his talent and potential, is considered by some to be on track to rival the likes of Arjen Robben and even Cristiano Ronaldo in his prime.

In a youth cup match, Chelsea took a commanding 3-1 lead against Manchester City's young side, with Tammy Abraham scoring twice and Dominic Solanke adding a late goal. The match saw several young players from both teams perform, with Chelsea's forwards dominating the attack. Manchester City's defenders, including Tosin Adarabioyo and Jake Clarke-Salter, put up a strong defense, while City's midfielders struggled against Chelsea's pace and movement. The game highlighted the talents of both teams' youth squads, with Chelsea ultimately securing the victory.

Marco Rubio, a Florida Senator and presidential candidate, has stated that people are born with sexual preferences and that same-sex marriage should not be a constitutional right. He supports state legislatures in deciding marriage definitions, believing that courts should not make such decisions. Rubio expressed willingness to attend the same-sex wedding of someone he cares for, even if he disagrees with their choice, emphasizing respect for loved ones. As a Catholic, he believes divorce is wrong but would not stop loving someone who is divorced. Rubio has received significant financial support for his presidential campaign.

Pablo Mandado and Ilze Zebolde, a Spanish and Latvian couple, are embarking on a worldwide cycling journey with no set plans or agenda, driven by a dream to explore the planet. After quitting their restaurant jobs in Manchester, they travel as cheaply as possible, living on less than three euros per day. In 356 days, they have covered nearly 7,000 miles, visiting 16 countries. They rely on free accommodation such as camping, Couchsurfing, and Warmshowers, with food being their main expense. Their route has taken them through Europe, into Turkey, Georgia, and Armenia, with plans to continue into Asia and eventually cycle across the Americas. They embrace the unknown, finding joy in stunning landscapes and the kindness of strangers.

A couple from Texas, who married in 2012, claim that their wedding photographer, James Evans of Premiere Photos, printed a racial slur, "poor n ***** party," on photo booth snapshots from their event. They were not informed of the incident until months later when the bride's sister shared the details. The couple, represented by attorney Cathy Hale, filed a lawsuit under Texas deceptive trade practices act, alleging negligence and breach of contract. Evans denied the allegations, refused to apologize, and claimed there is no evidence linking his company to the offensive caption. Mediation is scheduled, and if unsuccessful, the case will go to trial in July. The couple seeks an apology, not monetary compensation.

Mike Brown, an England full-back, has admitted he will take a cautious approach in recovering from his latest concussion, unsure of when he will return to play for Harlequins. He pulled out of a match against Saracens and is determined not to rush his recovery, citing the risks of prolonged absence, as seen with players like Johnny Sexton. Brown expressed relief at having learned about concussion symptoms through World Rugby modules, which influenced his decision to withdraw from the Ireland game. Meanwhile, George North, a Northampton wing, has been advised not to play again this season after suffering four concussions, and will see a neurosurgeon.

The passage discusses a decline in sexual frequency among British couples, attributed to increased smartphone use and internet access. Professor David Spiegelhalter from Cambridge University suggests that the integration of public and private lives, along with technological connectivity, has led to busier lifestyles and reduced time for intimacy. Research indicates that heterosexual couples now have sex three times a month, compared to five times in 1990 and four times in 2000. Factors such as living alone and constant connectivity are cited as possible causes, with experts noting that work emails and other distractions compete for time, reducing the priority given to sexual activity.

Tibetan mastiffs, once highly valued status symbols in China and capable of weighing up to 80 kg, have experienced a dramatic decline in popularity. Previously, they could command prices up to £1.2 million, but due to the Chinese government's anti-corruption crackdown, their value has plummeted. This has led to a surge in their being sent to slaughterhouses for meat and leather, with some dogs found in poor conditions, even dying from neglect. The decline is also attributed to bans on owning large dogs in major cities and the negative impact of cross-breeding for profit, which has reduced the breed's quality. Urbanization has further decreased their appeal as pets in cities.

A survey of 600 women in Paris found that every woman claimed to have experienced sexual harassment on public transport, with half assaulted before age 18. The report highlights that harassment ranges from verbal abuse to sexual assault and notes that many women are unaware of their experiences due to societal conditioning. It reveals that 60% of women fear attacks on public transport compared to 30% of men. The findings have prompted calls for a campaign to address sexist behavior on buses and trains. The report emphasizes the need for women to feel safe in public spaces and stresses that actions like touching someone's backside are punishable by law. Experts urge better education for both victims and aggressors to change societal norms.

A company called Direct Line, in collaboration with design company Makerversity, organized a competition called #EverydayFix to design products for common everyday problems. Participants identified issues like not being able to sleep, losing keys, and running out of phone battery. Three prototypes were shortlisted: "Snooze," an alarm clock that silences phone notifications for better sleep; "Forget Me Lock," a device that indicates if a door is locked or open; and "Nipper," a small phone charger using household batteries. The public can vote for their favorite product on Twitter, with the winner being developed through a Kickstarter campaign. Other ideas, such as a parking pin and a relay app, were not selected for the shortlist.

A police crime commissioner, Vera Baird, is under investigation by the Ministry of Justice for allocating over £500,000 of public funds to a charity she co-directs, Victims First Northumbria, alongside the force's chief constable, Sue Sim. Critics, including Labour's Keith Vaz, accuse the pair of creating a conflict of interest and a "soap opera" within the force. The charity was established after a decline in the predecessor organization, Victim Support. Sim, who gained attention for her handling of the Raoul Moat manhunt, is retiring in June and had previously faced misconduct allegations. The Ministry of Justice will assess whether any conflict of interest rules were violated. Baird maintains that all procedures were followed and defends her decision.

Three individuals have been sent to prison and two others are awaiting sentencing for their roles in a brutal assault on a 53-year-old man named Greg Valecce. The attack, carried out by a group called the "Tattoo Terrorists," involved beating Valecce, tying him to a chair, and tattooing offensive symbols on his body, including "Rip Pebbles," swastikas, and racist and homophobic imagery. The assault, which occurred in late March 2014 in a basement in Philadelphia, lasted about 42 hours. The perpetrators, including Corry "Corey" Campbell, his girlfriend Sandra Ng, and friend Carl Halin, were charged with aggravated assault, conspiracy, and false imprisonment. Campbell and Halin received 20-year prison sentences, while Ng received 23 months. The victims' cat, Pebbles, had a broken leg, which the perpetrators believed Valecce was responsible for. Valecce, an unemployed drug addict, managed to escape and report the incident. He has since had the tattoos removed but suffers from lasting psychological trauma.

Manchester United have made an official approach for PSV Eindhoven's Memphis Depay, aiming to sign the 21-year-old winger. United manager Louis van Gaal, who previously worked with Depay during Holland's 2014 World Cup campaign, is keen to make him one of his first signings this summer. Depay, who has scored 20 goals in 26 league games this season, is currently in high demand, with competition from clubs like Paris-Saint Germain. PSV's technical director noted that the current bids are higher than the £15 million offer from Tottenham last summer. Depay, who was named in Van Gaal's World Cup squad, has shown impressive skills and potential, with some comparing him to Arjen Robben and even suggesting he could rival young Cristiano Ronaldo.

In a youth cup match, Chelsea took a 3-1 lead against Manchester City's young side, with Tammy Abraham scoring twice and Dominic Solanke adding a late goal. Abraham's performance was highlighted as crucial, though he was substituted due to an injury. Manchester City's players, including Isaac Buckley-Ricketts, Brandon Barker, and others, showed strong performances but were unable to match Chelsea's dominance. The match saw several standout players from both teams, with Chelsea's midfield and defense effectively countering City's attacks.

Marco Rubio, a presidential candidate, stated that people are born with sexual preferences and that same-sex marriage should not be a constitutional right. He supports state legislatures in defining marriage as between one man and one woman, arguing that courts should not decide this issue. Rubio expressed willingness to attend the same-sex wedding of someone he cares for, even if he disagrees with their decision, emphasizing respect for family and personal choices. As a Catholic, he believes divorce is wrong but would not stop loving someone if they were divorced. Rubio has received significant financial support for his presidential campaign.

Pablo Mandado and Ilze Zebolde, a Spanish and Latvian couple respectively, are embarking on an open-ended journey around the world by bicycle. They left their restaurant jobs in Manchester and are traveling as cheaply as possible, living on less than three euros per day. In 356 days, they've covered nearly 7,000 miles, visiting 16 countries. They rely on free accommodations like camping, Couchsurfing, and WarmShowers, with food being their main expense. Their dream is to explore the planet at a leisurely pace, often stopping to take in stunning views. They plan to continue their journey into Asia and eventually cycle across the American continent.

Mike Brown, an England full-back, admitted he would take a cautious approach in recovering from his latest concussion. He remains unsure about his return to play after pulling out of a match against Saracens. Brown is determined not to rush his recovery, citing the risks of extended breaks, as seen with players like Johnny Sexton. He experienced symptoms after a game against France and realized the importance of concussion awareness through online modules, which influenced his decision to pull out of the Ireland match. George North, another player, has been advised not to play again this season after suffering four concussions. Brown emphasized the importance of being honest about symptoms and urged teammates not to play on if they show signs of concussion.

A leading expert, Professor David Spiegelhalter, suggests that smartphone use and increased technological connectivity may be contributing to a decline in the frequency of sexual activity among couples in Britain. Research indicates that heterosexual couples are having sex less frequently, with the average dropping from five times a month in 1990 to three times a month currently. Spiegelhalter attributes this decline to the blurring of boundaries between public and private lives, leading to busier schedules and reduced quality time with partners. He also cites the increasing number of competing demands on people's time, which causes sex to be deprioritized.

Tibetan mastiffs, once highly valued as status symbols in China and commanding prices up to £1.2 million, have experienced a dramatic decline in popularity. This decline is attributed to the Chinese government's anti-corruption crackdown, which reduced the practice of giving mastiffs as gifts, and recent bans on owning dogs over 50 kg in several cities. As a result, many mastiffs are now being sent to slaughterhouses for their meat and leather, with some rescued from cramped, inhumane conditions. The breed's reputation has also been damaged by cross-breeding for profit, leading to a glut of low-quality dogs. Urbanization has further reduced the breed's appeal, as they are not well-suited for city living.

A company called Direct Line, based in Leeds, ran a design competition called #everydayfix to address common everyday problems. Participants were asked to identify their top ten "everyday emergencies," with not being able to sleep being the most reported issue. Three prototypes were shortlisted: "Snooze," an alarm clock that silences phone notifications for better sleep; "Forget Me Lock," a device that indicates whether a door is locked or not; and "Nipper," a small phone charger powered by household batteries. The public could vote for their favorite product on Twitter, with the winner being developed through a Kickstarter campaign. Other proposed solutions that didn't make the shortlist included a parking pin, a relay app for message delivery when a phone dies, and a smart helmet with bone conduction headphones for cyclists.
